questions.text:
All of the following are true statements regarding retinopathy of prematurity except:

(PNA - Post natal age, PMA - Post menstrual age, AP-ROP - Aggressive posterior retinopathy of prematurity)

choices.text: First screening should be done 32 weeks PMA or 4 weeks PNA, whichever is later
For infants less than 28 week, screen at 3 week of postnatal age to detect APROP
Neonates are best examined at ophthalmology OPD and hence should be transported
Screening is done using indirect ophthalmoscopy by an expert ophthalmologist

questions.solution:
Neonates are best examined in the neonatal unit itself under the supervision of the attending neonatologist. It is not recommended to transport infants to the ophthalmic outpatient department for examination.

The first screening examination should be carried out by indirect ophthalmoscopy at 32 weeks PMA or 4 weeks PNA, whichever is later. For infants born at less than 28 weeks, screening is done at 3 weeks PNA to detect APROP. Aggressive posterior ROP ("rush" disease, AP-ROP), if untreated, usually progresses to total retinal detachment (stage 5) within a few days. It is characterized by its posterior location, prominence of plus disease and ill-defined nature of the retinopathy.

questions.text: Which of  the following is a tool used in gene editing:
questions.solution:
Guide RNAs called CRISPRs help to selectively alter or correct DNA sequences.

CRISPR is Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats

  • CRISPR-Cas9 is a genome editing tool and this system enables select bacteria to respond to and eliminate invading genetic material.
  • CRISPRs are transcribed into an RNA sequence that directs the Cas9 to a sequence leading to its cleavage.
  • Gene editing uses an artificial guide RNA that binds Cas9 and is complementary to a DNA sequence of interest and Cas9 induces the break of double-stranded DNA.

One of the first successful diseases used on experimental basis is Sickle Cell Anemia.

Other gene editing tools are:

  • Zinc-finger nucleases (ZNFs)
  • Transcription-Activator Like Effector Nucleases (TALEN)
  • Meganucleases

The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 2020 was awarded jointly to Emmanuelle Charpentier and Jennifer A. Doudna "for the development of the CRISPR/Cas9 gene-editing system, which has for the first time enabled scientists to make precise changes in the long stretches of DNA.

questions.text:
Theme and focus: TNM staging Lead in the question: For each of the clinical scenarios described below, mark the appropriate TNM stage in the given answer option list.
    1. T4b N1 M0
    2. T4b N1 M1
    3. T3 N1 M1
    4. T3 N0 M0
    5. T2 N1 M0
    6. T3 N3a M1
    7. T2 N3a M0
    8. T2 N3b M0
questions.solution:
Case 1:

  • T stage: The size of tumor is > 5cm, so T3. (Note that involvement of dermis alone is not considered as skin involvement and does not qualify as T4).
  • N stage: Two ipsilateral matted lymph nodes in the axilla and one ipsilateral lymph node in infraclavicular region indicates N3a.
  • M stage: Involvement of contralateral lymph node in supraclavicular fossa indicates metastasis. So, M1.

The TNM stage of case 1 is: T3 N3a M1.

Case 2:

  • T stage: The size of tumor is 3 x 2 cm, so T2.
  • N stage: The lymph node shows extranodal extension (ENE +), so, it is N3b
  • M stage: No metastasis, M0

The TNM stage of case 2 is: T2 N3b M0

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of Carcinoma Breast

Tumor (T)

T4

4a – chest wall involvement (except pectoralis major)# 

4b – skin involvement in the form of ulceration, peau d’orange, satellite nodules  

4c – 4a + 4b  

4d – Inflammatory breast carcinoma (typical skin changes involving >1/3rd of breast)*

N1 mic Refers to micrometastasis to Lymph node
N1 Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes
N2A Ipsilateral fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes
N2B Ipsilateral internal mammary without axillary lymph node involvement
N3A Ipsilateral infraclavicular lymph nodes
N3B Ipsilateral internal mammary and axillary lymph nodes
N3C Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph nodes
Distant metastasis (M) Description
M0 Metastasis absent
M1 Metastasis present

 

Stages T, N  M
Stage 0 TisN0 M0
Stage IA T1N0 M0
Stage IB T0,1N1mic M0
Stage IIA T0,1N1 (or) T2N0 M0
Stage IIB T2N1 (or) T3N0 M0
Stage IIIA T0,1,2,3N2 (or) T3N1 M0
Stage IIIB T4 N0,1,2 M0
Stage IIIC

Any T, N3

Stage IV

# Chest wall includes Serratus anterior, Intercostal muscles, Ribs. Pectoralis muscle is not a part of the chest wall.

* Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage 4d) is characterized by the skin changes of brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (peaud’orange) involving >1/3rd of the breast.

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered a benign condition and not included under Tis.

Prefixes for TNM staging:

  • c: clinical staging (e.g. cT1b)
  • p: pathological (histological) staging
  • y: stage following systemic or radiation therapy (either prior to surgery or as a primary treatment)
  • r: staging at the time of retreatment or recurrence for disease progression

Suffix for TNM staging:

  • m: multiple primary tumours of the same histology in the same organ, e.g. T2(m) or T2(5), the latter meaning that there are five primary tumours

Related Pearl: TNM staging of oral cavity cancer - AJCC 8th edition

Primary Tumour (T)
TX Cannot be assessed
Tis Carcinoma in situ
T1

Tumor ≤2 cm, depth of invasion (DOI)  ≤5 mm (DOI is depth of invasion and not tumor thickness)
T2

Tumor ≤2 cm, DOI >5 mm and ≤10 mm;

or tumor >2 cm but ≤4 cm, and ≤10 mm DOI
T3 Tumor >4 cm or any tumor >10 mm DOI
T4 Moderately advanced or very advanced local disease
T4a

Moderately advanced local disease:

Tumor> 4 cms with DOI >10 mm

or tumor invades adjacent structures only (through cortical bone of the mandible or maxilla or involves the maxillary sinus or skin of the face.

Note that superficial erosion of bone/tooth socket (alone) by a gingival primary is not sufficient to classify a tumor as T4
T4b Very advanced local disease; tumor invades the masticator space, pterygoid plates, or skull base and/or encases the internal carotid artery

 

Regional lymph nodes (N) - Clinical
NX Cannot be assessed
N0 No regional lymph node metastasis
N1 Single ipsilateral, <3 cm and ENE (extranodal extension)‐negative
N2  Single ipsilateral lymph node larger than 3 cms but not greater than 6 cms, ENE - negative; Multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, <6 cm and ENE ‐negative ;  Bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, <6 cm and ENE‐negative
N2a Single ipsilateral lymph node larger than 3 cms but not greater than 6 cms, ENE - negative
N2b Multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, <6 cm and ENE ‐negative
N2c Bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, <6 cm and ENE‐negative
N3

Metastasis in a lymph node larger than 6 cms and ENE -negative or metastasis in any lymph node and clinically over ENE +positive
N3a Metastasis in a lymph node >6 cms and ENE‐negative
N3b

Metastasis in any lymph node(s) and clinically overt ENE +positive.


Note:
ENE is as determined by physical examination (e.g., invasion of the skin, infiltration of musculature/dense tethering to adjacent structures, or dysfunction of a cranial nerve, the brachial plexus, the sympathetic trunk, or the phrenic nerve) and supported by radiological evidence, should be present to assign a status of ENE‐positive.

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Breast conservation surgery (BCS)/WLE (wide local excision): Tumour removal with a 3D clearance of a 1 mm margin of normal tissue
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Skin-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope preservation and nipple-areola complex removal
  • Skin+ nipple/areola-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope and nipple-areola complex preservation
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Level I oncoplasty (volume displacement surgery): Tumour excision with wide margins followed by defect repair via dual-plane mobilisation of the breast parenchyma to maintain shape and symmetry
  • Level II oncoplasty (volume replacement surgery): Skin excision and glandular mobilisation involving >20% resection of breast volume
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + axillary lymph nodes (levels I + II ± III) dissection
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + internal mammary lymph nodes dissection
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iverson) mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary and supraclavicular lymph nodes dissection
  • Super radical mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary, supraclavicular and mediastinal lymph nodes dissection.

*Dual-plane mobilisation of breast parenchyma: Mobilisation of the dermoglandular plane and plane between breast parenchyma and pectoralis muscle.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman is currently on oral levothyroxine supplementation. Co-administration of all of the following would require an increase in the dose of her levothyroxine, except:
questions.solution:
Androgen therapy in women, decrease levothyroxine dosage requirements. 

Drugs and other factors that may increase levothyroxine dosage requirements:

  • Impaired levothyroxine absorption
    • Aluminum-containing antacids
    • Proton pump inhibitors
    • Sucralfate
    • Bile acid sequestrants (cholestyramine, colestipol, colesevelam)
    • Calcium carbonate (effect generally small)
    • Phosphate binders (lanthanum carbonate, sevelamer)
  • Increased thyroxine metabolism, CYP3A4 induction
    • Rifampin
    • Carbamazepine
    • Phenytoin
    • Sertraline
  • Impaired T4 → T3 conversion
    • Amiodarone
  • Mechanisms uncertain or multifactorial
    • Estrogen
    • Pregnancy
    • Lovastatin & simvastatin

Drugs and other factors that may decrease levothyroxine dosage requirements:

  • Advancing age (>65 years)
  • Androgen therapy in women

Drugs that may decrease TSH without changing free T4 in levothyroxine-treated patients: Metformin

questions.text: Increase in atrial pressure causes all of the following except:

choices.text: Decrease in plasma atrial natriuretic peptide
Decrease in plasma angiotensin II concentration

questions.solution:
An increase in atrial pressure causes an increase in plasma levels of atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP):

Increased ANP levels can in turn cause:

A decrease in plasma levels of angiotensin II, aldosterone and an increase in sodium excretion.

Related Pearl: Actions of Angiotensin II

Actions of Angiotensin II

Produces powerful arteriolar constriction and a rise in SBP and DBP

Acts directly on the adrenal cortex to increase aldosterone secretion

Facilitates the release of Norepinephrine by a direct action on postganglionic sympathetic neurons

Constricts efferent arteriole, thereby increasing filteration fraction and glomerular filteration rate, when there is decreased renal bloodflow

Direct effect on renal tubules to increase Na+ reabsorption

Acts on brain to decrease sensitivity of baroreceptor reflex, potentiating the pressor effect of AT II

Acts on brain to increase water intake and increase secretion of ADH and ACTH

questions.text:
The following statements are true/false regarding osteoarthritis:
  1. Loss of cartilage causes pain due to direct stimulation of pain receptors in joint cartilage.
  2. It is the second most common cause of arthritis, after rheumatoid arthritis.
  3. Synovial fluid WBC count is usually >2000 cells/μL.
  4. The severity of radiographic changes correlates with the severity of pain.
questions.solution:
Statement 1: False:

Because cartilage is aneural, cartilage loss in a joint does not cause pain due to the direct stimulation of pain receptors in joint cartilage. Thus, pain in OA likely arises from structures outside the cartilage.

 

Statement 2: False

OA is the most common type of arthritis. Its high prevalence, especially in the elderly, and the high rate of disability related to disease make it a leading cause of disability in the elderly.

 

Statement 3: False

Examination of the synovial fluid is often helpful in suspected osteoarthritis, particularly if the inflammatory disease is possible.

The synovial fluid in osteoarthritis is non-inflammatory as suggested by synovial fluid WBC count of <2000 (normal count is <200).

If the synovial fluid white blood cell count is >2000/μL, inflammatory arthritis, gout, or pseudogout is likely, with the latter two being identified by the presence of crystals.

 

Statement 4: False

Innervated structures in the joint include the synovium, ligaments, joint capsule, muscles, and subchondral bone.

Most of these are not visualized by the x-ray, and the severity of radiographic changes in OA correlates poorly with pain severity.

Related Pearl: Joint Involvement in Various Arthritis

 Joint Disorders Joints Commonly Involved

Joints Commonly Spared

 Osteoarthritis

Cervical and lumbosacral spine, PIP, DIP, 1st CMC, hip, knee, 1st MTP, 

 Elbow, Wrist, Ankle, MCP 
Rheumatoid Arthritis Shoulder, Wrist, MCP, PIP, Knee, MTP  DIP 
Ankylosing Spondylitis Sacroiliac joint, intervertebral joints  
Psoriatic Arthritis PIP, DIP Ray distribution* 

*Ray distribution: Joint involvement tends to follow a pattern with all of the joints of one finger involved sparing the adjacent finger completely.

questions.text:
Theme - Triage Lead in question - You have been deployed to a region of natural calamity with mass casualty as part of Disaster Management team and are required to Triage the Patients in the field for determining the order of treatment priority. Choose appropriate colour tag and the corresponding priority hierarchy.
  1. Red, Medium priority
  2. Yellow, Least priority
  3. Black, Low priority
  4. Green, High priority
  5. Red, High priority
  6. Yellow, Medium priority
  7. Black, Least priority
  8. Green,  Low priority
questions.solution:
Scenario 1:

The 27 years old man with an isolated humerus fracture and no other injuries with stable vitals would be classified as yellow, medium priority. Isolated long bone fractures in an otherwise stable are classified as medium priority injuries.

Scenario 2:

The 42-year-old agitated female who is unable to speak with the O2 saturation falling rapidly clearly has airway compromise. Since no other major visible external injuries are noted, immediately re-establishing the airway would be potentially life-saving for the patient. So, she is to be classified as red, high priority.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman presented with progressive dyspnea at rest. Chest x-ray showed significant left-sided pleural effusion. The results of the thoracocentesis and blood tests are shown in the table given below. Which of the following is not a cause of pleural effusion in this case?
Parameter Serum Pleural fluid
Protein 6 g/dL 2.4 g/dL
LDH 150 U/L 120 U/L
pH - 7.1
questions.solution:
Pulmonary embolism cannot be the cause of the above clinical picture.

Pleural fluid analysis and the ratio of pleural fluid lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) to serum LDH (120:150 = 0.8) shows that the fluid is an exudate.

For fluid to be considered an exudate, the fluid needs to meet only 1 of the Light criteria:

  • Ratio of pleural fluid protein to serum protein >0.5 or
  • Ratio of pleural fluid LDH to serum LDH >0.6; or
  • Pleural fluid LDH greater than two-thirds of the upper limit of the reference range for serum LDH).

From the results given in the above table, the protein ratio is less than 0.5, but the LDH ratio is greater than 0.6. Hence, the pleural fluid is an exudate.

The low pH suggests a certain diagnosis. When thoracentesis fluid pH is less than 7.3 (pleural fluid acidosis), diagnostic possibilities include empyema, esophageal rupture, rheumatoid arthritis, trauma, tuberculosis, and malignancy.

Also, if the diagnosis was of pulmonary embolism, a history of sudden onset dyspnea would have been mentioned.

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

Transudative Pleural effusion

  • Congestive heart failure (most common)
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Myxedema 
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Urinothorax
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction

Exudative Pleural effusion 

  • Infections: Tuberculosis, pneumonia, intraabdominal abscess (like- liver abscess)
  • Malignancy: Pleural mesothelioma, metastasis, lymphoma
  • Connective tissue diseases: SLE, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Drugs: Amiodarone, bromocriptine, dantrolene, dasatinib, methysergide, nitrofurantoin
  • Others:
    • Pancreatitis
    • Asbestosis
    • Pulmonary embolism
    • Hemothorax
    • Chylothorax
    • Meigs' syndrome 
    • Dressler syndrome (post-myocardial infarction or cardiac surgery)
    • Yellow nail syndrome 

Related Pearl: Causes of predominantly unilateral pleural effusion

Predominantly right-sided pleural effusion

Predominantly left-sided pleural effusion

Cirrhosis of the liver

(hepatic hydrothorax)

 Acute pancreatitis

Amebic liver abscess

 Aortic dissection
 Meig’s syndrome Esophageal rupture

Cardiac failure

( B/L>>right-sided)

Dressler’s syndrome

questions.text: All of the following will cause a decrease in the amount of anesthetic required, except?
questions.solution:
Hyponatremia, not hypernatremia will cause a decrease in the amount of anesthetic required.

Hyperthermia, upto 42-degree Celcius, causes a decrease in anesthetic required, while Hyperthermia beyond 42 degrees Celcius causes an increased requirement of anesthetic.

Related Pearl: Factors affecting Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC)

Factors increasing MAC Factors decreasing MAC No change in MAC
Hyperthermia >42°C Acute alcohol intoxication  Hyperthyroidism
Chronic alcohol abuse Hypothermia and hyperthermia up to 42°C Hypothyroidism
Acute amphetamine use  Older age (>6 months MAC decreases 6% per decade)  
Drugs: Cocaine, Ephedrine Chronic amphetamine abuse  
Hypernatremia  Drugs: Opioids, Ketamine, Barbiturates, Benzodiazepines, Sympatholytics   
Young age (<6 months; MAC is maximum at 6 months) Hyponatremia, Hypercalcemia  
  Hypotension  
  Hypercarbia, Hypoxia, Metabolic acidosis  
  Pregnancy

questions.text:
The following statements are true or false regarding the polyhydramnios:

1. There is excess production of liquor amnii but its composition is normal.

2. It is diagnosed when the AFI >28 cms and DVP is >4cms

3. Amnion nodosum can cause polyhydramnios

4. On examination, fluid thrill and shifting dullness may be elicited.

5. It is commonly seen in maternal diabetes due to increased fetal diuresis.
questions.solution:
Statements 1 and 5 are true, while the remaining statements are false.

1. There is excess production of liquor amnii but its composition is normal - True

Polyhydramnios is a condition characterized by excessive production of the liquor amnii lead ting to its accumulation exceeding 2000mL. However, the composition of the liquor amnii remains normal.

 

2. It is diagnosed when the AFI >28 cms and DVP is >4cms - False

It is diagnosed on USG when the amniotic fluid index (AFI) is more than 24 cm and the deepest vertical pocket (DVP) is more than 8 cm.

 

3. Amnion nodosum can cause polyhydramnios - False

Amnion nodosum, a condition characterized by failure of secretion by the cells of the amnion covering the placenta, is a cause of oligohydramnios (not polyhydramnios).

Polyhydramnios may be associated with the development of congenital malformations such as:

  • Anencephaly
  • Open spina bifida
  • Esophageal or duodenal atresia
  • Facial clefts and neck masses
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • Aneuploidy

 

 4. On examination, the height of the uterus is more than the period of amenorrhoea. The fluid thrill and shifting dullness may be elicited - False

  • There is no shifting dullness in polyhydramnios. It is seen in ascites. In polyhydramnios, the findings on palpation of the abdomen include:
  • Increased height of the uterus, which is greater than the period of amenorrhea
  • Abdominal girth is above normal
  • Fluid thrill, which can be elicited in all directions over the uterus.
  • Fetal parts are not well defined and the presentation cannot be ascertained. However, external ballottement may be easily done.

 

 5. It is commonly seen in maternal diabetes due to increased fetal diuresis - True

Maternal factors such as diabetes and cardiac or renal diseases may be associated with polyhydramnios.

  • Maternal diabetes causes increased fetal blood sugar that causes increased fetal diuresis leading to hydramnios.
  • Cardiac or renal diseases cause edema of the placenta leading to increased transudation.

Related Pearl: Causes of oligohydramnios and polyhydramnios

Causes

Oligohydramnios

Polyhydramnios

Maternal
  • Undiagnosed rupture of membrane (most common)
  • Spontaneous rupture of membranes
  • Post-dated pregnancy
  • Preeclampsia
  • NSAIDs
  • ACE inhibitors
  • Overt diabetes
  • Gestational diabetes
  • Cardiac disease
  • Renal disease
  • Liver failure

Fetal
  • Fetal anomalies
  • Renal agenesis
  • Urethral defects
    • Posterior valve
    • Obstructive uropathy

 
  • Multiple gestation
  • Neural tube defects
  • Abdominal wall defects
  • Cleft palate
  • Neck masses
  • Esophageal atresia
  • Aneuploidy
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • TTTS

Placental

Failure of secretion:- e.g. Amnion nodosum

Chorangioma of placenta

questions.text:
The physiological changes occurring in the respiratory system during pregnancy include:
  1. A decrease in total lung capacity
  2. A decrease in tidal volume
  3. Increase in respiratory minute volume
  4. Decrease in pulmonary resistance
questions.solution:
1, 3, and 4 are correct. In pregnancy, the tidal volume is increased (not decreased).

Physiological changes in respiratory system during pregnancy:

  • Decrease in total lung capacity: This occurs due to the elevation of the diaphragm by the enlarged uterus.
  • Reduced pulmonary resistance due to the effect of progesterone.
  • Increase in tidal volume and respiratory minute volume, due to the action of progesterone on the respiratory centre and increased sensitivity of the respiratory centre to CO2. As a result, the woman may feel shortness of breath.
  • Increase in the subcostal angle from 68° to 103°.
  • Increase in transverse diameter of the chest by 2 cm and chest circumference by 5-7 cm.
  • Edema and hyperemia of the nasopharyngeal mucosa may occur leading to nasal stuffiness and rarely epistaxis.

Related Pearl: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)

Related Pearl: Hematological changes in pregnancy

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman came to the hospital with complaints of tremors, palpitations, and heat intolerance for the past 3 weeks. She also reported a loss of 3 kgs of weight loss during this period. She is not on any medications or nutritional supplements and has not undergone any imaging or surgical procedures in the past year. On examination, her pulse rate is 110 beats/min. The thyroid gland is slightly enlarged and extremely tender. TSH level is 0.05 mIU/L, free T4 level is 2.8 ng/dL, and radioiodine uptake was less than 1% at 24 hours. ESR is elevated while the leukocyte count is normal. What is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Begin treatment with NSAID or glucocorticoid

questions.solution:
The symptoms and lab results are suggestive of thyrotoxicosis due to subacute (painfull) thyroiditis for which the best next step is aimed at symptomatic relief with NSAIDs. 

Subacute (painful) Thyroiditis:

  • The thyroid hormone levels are increased from the release of the preformed hormone and not from excessive production, and therefore antithyroid medications are not effective.
  • The low iodine uptake and the tenderness of the thyroid confirm the diagnosis of subacute (painful) thyroiditis.
  • Treatment is aimed at symptomatic relief. NSAIDs are often effective for mild-to-moderate disease, but glucocorticoids may be necessary for more severe or refractory pain.

Other options:

Option b: Thyroglobulin is used in the setting of low-iodine-uptake thyrotoxicosis to distinguish between the endogenous and exogenous source of thyroid hormone. As the patient has the enlarged and tender thyroid, there is no reason to suspect the external use of levothyroxine in this case.

Option c: In view of the low iodine uptake and the absence of recent iodine load, this patient’s condition is not suggestive with Graves disease and hence TSI testing is not needed.

Option d: Ultrasonography with color Doppler flow would be useful if the uptake were low in the setting of recent iodine load in order to distinguish thyroiditis from Graves disease, but it is not necessary for the diagnosis in this situation.

Related Pearl: Antibodies seen in some autoimmune thyroid disorders

Antibody Disorder
TSH receptor-stimulating Immunoglobulins (TSI) Graves disease
Anti TPO & Anti Tg antibodies Chronic lymphocytic(Hashimoto) thyroiditis

TRBAb

(maternal transmission)

 Transient congenital hypothyroidism (maternal autoimmune thyroid disease)
  • Anti TPO – Anti thyroperoxidase antibody
  • Anti Tg – Antithyroglobulin antibody
  • TRBAb – TSH receptor blocking antibodies

questions.text: A 34-year-old male who was newly diagnosed with HIV is being evaluated prior to initiation of antiretroviral therapy. Which of the following techniques is used to determine the CD4+ cell count in his peripheral blood?
questions.solution:
Flow cytometry is used to determine the CD4 count in the peripheral blood.

Flow cytometry is a laser based method which analyzes the cells and cell components based on the presence of certain cell surface molecules which are named as per cluster of differentiation (CD) nomenclature.

There are about 300 types of CD molecules. Monoclonal antibodies against specific CD molecules are tagged with fluorescent labels. Incubation of the cells with a variety of different CD labeled antibodies allows the flow cytometric analysis of distinct populations of cells in the mixture.

Flow cytometry is routinely used in identifying CD4-positive cells, CD8-positive cells, B cells, macrophages, and cells expressing a variety of cytokines.

Related Pearl: NACO ART Guidelines- 2021

ART regimen

First-line for:

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who are age >10 years and body weight >30 kg with HIV-1, HIV-2, HIV 1&2 co-infection who have not received any ART 
  • Those with HIV-TB and HIV hepatitis co-infections
  • Pregnant women, pregnant women presenting in active labour and breastfeeding women

Abacavir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz
  • All PLHIV with abnormal serum creatinine values 
  • All PLHIV with bodyweight less <30 kg

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz /Lopinavir /Ritonavir
  • Women of childbearing age group who do not wish to take Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who were on the previous recommended regime (Tenofovir+Lamivudine+Efavirenz) to be counselled to switch to new regime. Continue older regime if response is good
  • Women in child-bearing age group to be counselled about Dolutegravir with opt-out option before switching to new regime

*PLHIV: People living with HIV

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

 

 

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix

questions.text: Identify the test which is being demonstrated in the video given below:
questions.solution:
The video shows an examination being performed with the knee flexed to about 20 degrees which indicates that it is the Lachman test. The presence of free gliding indicates that it is a positive Lachman test.

Lachman test: The patient’s knee is flexed to 20 degrees.  The lower part of the thigh is grasped with one hand and the upper part of the leg with the other hand. The joint surfaces are shifted backward and forward upon each other.  If the knee is stable, there should be no gliding. The presence of gliding indicates the laxity of the anterior cruciate ligament.

Other options:

Anterior and posterior drawer test: The test is performed with the patient’s knees flexed to 90 degrees, and the feet resting on the examining bed. The examiner then grasps the upper part of the leg with both hands and rocks it forward and backward. Excessive anterior movement denotes anterior cruciate laxity (anterior drawer test) Excessive posterior movement denotes posterior cruciate laxity (posterior drawer test). 

McMurray’s test: The test is used to identify torn meniscus. The knee is flexed as far as possible and the joint is stabilized with one hand. With the other hand, the examiner rotates the leg medially and laterally. If there is a clicking sound while rotating the leg, the test is positive. The sound is produced due to the trapping of the loose tag of the torn meniscus between the articular surfaces.

Related Pearl: Unhappy triad of knee joint

It is also called O'Donoghue's triad/ terrible triad/ horrible triad of the knee. It mostly occurs in football, basketball & rugby players, due to a lateral blow to the knee.

It is characterized by injury to: 

  • Medial meniscus
  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Tibial collateral ligament

(Mnemonic – MAT)

The image below shows the unhappy triad of the knee joint on MRI (PDW SPIR):

  1. Rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament
  2. Rupture of the medial collateral ligament
  3. Inner meniscal tear (image shows complex rupture of the posterior horn).

questions.text: Cerebral blood flow is regulated by all except _______
questions.solution:
Normal cerebral blood flow is maintained despite the fluctuations in blood pressure due to autoregulation.

Cerebral Blood Flow:

  • Normal cerebral blood flow→ 50-65mL/100g of brain tissue/min
  • For entire brain CBF→750-900mL/min (15% of the resting cardiac output)
  • Factors that increase CBF
    • Cerebral metabolic rate
    • ↑ Arterial Pco2
  • 70% increase in Paco2 (80mmHg)  approximately doubles the CBF
    • ↑ H+ ion concentration
    • Hypoxia
    • Substances released from astrocytes that cause local vasodilation- NO, K+, adenosine, etc

Role of intracranial pressure

  • Monro-Kellie doctrine 
    • Because brain tissue and spinal fluid are essentially incompressible, the volume of blood, spinal fluid, and brain in the cranium at any time must be constant
    • More importantly, cerebral vessels are compressed when intracranial pressure rises
    • Any change in venous pressure promptly causes a similar change in intracranial pressure

Related Pearl: Blood Pressure and its determinants

Type of Blood Pressure

Determinant

Systolic BP (SBP)

Stroke volume (directly proportional)

Compliance of aorta (inversely proportional)

Diastolic BP (DBP)

Elastic recoil of aorta/major vessels (directly proportional)

Pulse pressure (PP)

Ratio of stroke volume to compliance of the arterial tree

Mean blood pressure (MAP)

Cardiac output

Total peripheral resistance

questions.text: Which of the following lesions in tuberous sclerosis show hyperplastic blood vessels and sebaceous glands of immature hair follicles on histopathological examination?
questions.solution:
Angiofibromas show hyperplastic blood vessels and sebaceous glands of immature hair follicles on histopathological examination.

The characteristic findings of various lesions of tuberous sclerosis are as follows:

Ash leaf macules: They are ovoid or leaf-shaped hypopigmented macules. Histopathology will show abnormal melanocytes that have reduced tyrosinase activity. Electron microscopy would reveal defective melanization of melanosomes.

The following image shows an ash-leaf macule:

Periungual fibromas (Koenen’s tumor): They are smooth, firm, flesh-colored outgrowths emerging from the nail folds. These lesions classically have a distal part with loose collagen and many blood vessels and a larger proximal part composed of dense collagen bundles and fewer capillaries. The following image shows Koenen's tumor - 

Angiofibromas: they are red-brown, telangiectatic papules, commonly found in naso‐labial furrows to the cheeks and chin, and are occasionally found in the ears. They show hyperplastic blood vessels and sebaceous glands of immature hair follicles on histopathological examination. Angiofibromas were previously misnamed as adenoma sebaceum.

Shagreen patches: It is an irregularly thickened, elevated, skin-colored plaque, usually in the lumbosacral region. They show an excess of collagen and no other characteristic change. Hence, cannot be identified on the basis of histopathology alone as most other lesions also have an excess of collagen.

Other important features of tuberous sclerosis are multiple retinal nodular hamartomas, cortical tuber, subependymal nodule, subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, etc.

questions.text: All of the following are biophysical predictor of pre term labour except
questions.solution:
Uterine contractions (UC) > 4/hr (not 2 hrs) is a biophysical predictor of preterm labor.

 

Predictors of preterm labor:

Clinical predictors:

  • History of prior preterm birth
  • Multiple pregnancy
  • Presence of genital tract infection
  • Symptoms of Pre term labor

Biophysical predictors:

  • Uterine contractions (UC) > 4/hr
  • Bishop score > 4
  • Cervical length (TVS) < 25 mm

Biochemical predictors:

  • Fetal fibronectin (fFN) in cervicovaginal discharge 
  • Others IL-6, IL-8, TNF-α

questions.text: In which of the following surgeries would you expect the least surgical site infection rate?

choices.text: Removal of urinary stones in a patient who has no UTI

questions.solution:
A surgical site infection (SSI) rate is the least in clean wounds, i.e in operations where there is no inflammation and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, and uninfected urinary tracts are not entered. Among the given options, only option b, uncomplicated hernia surgery is a clean wound.

Elective cholecystectomy and removal of urinary stones in a patient who has no UTI are examples of clean contaminated wound.

Emergency appendectomy is a contaminated wound

SSI rates relating to wound contamination with and without using antibiotic prophylaxis.

Related Pearl: Surgical wound classifications as defined by ACS NSOP

  • Clean: Uninfected operative wounds in which no inflammation is encountered and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, and uninfected urinary tracts are not entered
  • Clean/Contaminated: Operative wounds in which the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tract is entered under controlled conditions and without unusual contamination
  • Contaminated: Open, fresh, accidental wounds; operations with major breaks insterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract and incisions in which acute, nonpurulent inflammation is encountered
  • Dirty: Old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue and wounds that involve existing clinical infection or perforated viscera

questions.text: You would suspect the presence of publication bias in a metaanalysis if you notice:
questions.solution:
The presence of an asymmetric funnel plot would indicate publication bias.

Related Pearl: Funnel Plots

  • A funnel plot is basically a scatter plot of individual studies which are used in systematic reviews and meta-analysis. It plots their precisions and results.
  • In a funnel plot, each dot represents an individual study.
  • The y-axis is usually the standard error or another estimate of precision and the x-axis is the outcome, usually the odds ratio.
  • Higher powered studies are placed towards the top and the lower powered ones towards the bottom such that the plot resembles an inverted funnel or a pyramid.
  • This shape is expected as different studies have different standard errors and other estimates.
  • A symmetrical funnel plot is shown in Fig. A. in the image below.
  • These funnel plots are used in meta-analysis to check for bias like publication bias or other reporting bias.
  • In the case of bias being present, an asymmetrical funnel plot results, as shown in Fig. B. of the image below.

Related Pearl: Forest Plot

  • A forest plot is used to present the results of a meta-analysis.
  • It is also called blobbogram.

Interpretation of forest plots: 

  • The rectangles represent the single studies
  • The size of the rectangle is proportional to the sample size
  • The horizontal line on either side - confidence interval, the longer the lines, the wider the confidential interval, the less reliable the study results
  • The vertical solid line - the “line of no effect", which represents the odds ratio or relative risk. If it is the odds ratio, then the vertical line would be at 1. No difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1). 
  • The location of the result - whether it favours the intervention (the statin drug) or not
  • A diamond shows the overall pooled result where all the individual studies are combined together and averaged
  • Lateral corners of the diamond represent the confidence interval, if these corners do not cross 'the line of no effect', then there is an overall statistically significant effect. If the diamond touches the vertical line, the overall result is not statistically significant.
  • The vertical dashed line represents the overall pooled estimate which represents the meta-analysed measure of effect.

Let's understand with an example - 

  • For study A- it has a wide horizontal line that crosses the line of null effect with a black box that is to the right of the vertical line. This most likely demonstrates a small scale study with few participants where the point estimate result favours the control used in the study. But because the study contains the null value in its 95% confidence interval, it is likely to have a p-value >0.05 and not be statistically significant.
  • For study B- it has quite a narrow line that does not cross the line of null effect with a black box that is to the left of the vertical line and is bigger than study A. This most likely demonstrates a larger study with more participants compared to study A, where the result favours the intervention used. Because the 95% confidence interval does not contain the null value, this study is likely to have a p-value <0.05 and hence the differences observed in the study can be regarded as statistically significant.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not correct regarding the Schultze method of placental separation?

choices.text: The separation begins at the centre of the placenta.
The fetal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.
The maternal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.
There is a formation of retroplacental clot.

questions.solution:
The below image A shows the Schultze method of placental separation. In this method, the fetal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.

Placental separation occurs during the third stage of labor. There are two mechanisms by which placental separation may occur:

A. Central separation of the placenta, known as Schultze method

B. Marginal separation of the placenta, known as Mathews-Duncan method.

Schultze method:

The process of separation begins at the center of the placenta (fetal surface). Consequently, this central part descends first and becomes visible at the vulva. During this phase, blood gathers in a membranous sac located behind the placenta, resulting in the creation of a retroplacental clot. Bleeding does not happen until the placenta is fully expelled

Mathews-Duncan method:

Placental separation begins at the periphery of the placenta, leading to the maternal surface becoming visible first. Blood gathers between the membranes and the uterine wall and is discharged through the vagina. Unlike the previous method, there is no development of a retroplacental clot, resulting in significant bleeding during this type of placental separation. However, it is less frequent compared to the Schultze method.

questions.text: Maximum penetration is seen with:
questions.solution:
Gamma rays show maximum penetration.

When a nucleus disintegrates, it will emit radiation either as photons (X or gamma rays) or as high-velocity particles. Gamma rays are a form of electromagnetic radiation (EMR) similar to X-rays, however, distinguished from the latter by the fact that they are emitted from an excited nucleus. Gamma radiation is highly penetrating and interacts with matter through ionization via two processes, the photoelectric effect, and Compton scattering.

Related Pearl: Ionising and penetrating ability of radiation

  • Penetration power: Gamma rays > X-rays > Beta particle > Alpha particle (helium ion)
  • Ionising or tissue damaging ability: Alpha particle (helium ion) > Beta particle > X-ray > Gamma ray
  • Alpha waves have the highest molecular mass

Related Pearl: Radioprotectors and Radiosensitizers

Radioprotectors:

Radioprotectors are substances that protect normal tissues from the effect of radiation. These include:

  • Zinc oxide
  • Pentoxifylline
  • Estramustine
  • Amifostine
  • Chlorhexidine (radiation-induced stomatitis)
  • Potassium iodide (for thyroid against radioactive iodine)
  • Melatonin
  • Antioxidants

Radiosensitizers:

Radiosensitizers make the tumor more susceptible to the action of radiotherapy. These include:

  • Oxygen
  • Cisplatin
  • 5 FU
  • Gemcitabine
  • Nitroimidazoles

Radiation potentiators:

The following drugs potentiate the action of radiation when used in conjunction: 

  • Doxorubicin
  • Dactinomycin

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Machado-Joseph disease?

choices.text: The mean age of onset is 25 years
Type III MJD is also known as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis- parkinsonism-dystonia type
Patients usually have normal intellectual function
Pathologically, sparing of inferior olives differentiates it from other dominant ataxias

questions.solution:
Type III is also known as ataxic–amyotrophic type.

Machado–Joseph disease or spinocerebellar type 3 has a mean age of onset at 25 years. It has 3 types:

  • Type I: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis- parkinsonism-dystonia type
  • Type II: Ataxic type
  • Type III: Ataxic–amyotrophic type

Patients usually have a normal intellectual function.

Pathologically: Loss of neurons in the corpus striatum, pars compacta of the substantia nigra, the dentate nucleus of the cerebellum, and the red nucleus is seen. Loss of Purkinje cells and granular cells are also seen in the cerebellar cortex. Sparing of inferior olives distinguishes it from other dominantly inherited ataxias.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman came to the emergency department with complaints of epigastric pain, nausea, and vomiting. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She has been taking aspirin 75 mg daily, lisinopril 5 mg daily, and atorvastatin 40 mg daily. Her heart rate is 110 beats per minute, blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg, and the temperature is 98.6°F. On examination, the patient has moderate epigastric tenderness and reduced bowel sounds. Laboratory test results are as follows. What is the next step?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen with IV contrast

questions.solution:
The next step of management includes IV fluids and bowel rest.

  • The clinical presentation and the elevated levels of amylase and lipase suggest acute pancreatitis most likely due to gallstone disease as AST and ALT were moderately elevated.
  • The most important initial step in the management of patients with acute pancreatitis is hydration to ensure pancreatic perfusion and thereby decrease the risk of pancreatic necrosis.
  • Early fluid resuscitation (one-third of the total 72-hour fluid volume administered within 24 hours of presentation, 250–500 mL/h initially) reduces the risk of SIRS.
  • Food and liquids are restricted by mouth, bed rest is advised.
  • Meperidine may be given to reduce pain.
  • Oral fluid and food intake are resumed when the patient is free of pain and has bowel sounds.

Other options:

Option a: CT scan of the abdomen with IV contrast medium may be indicated later in the clinical course to evaluate for pancreatic necrosis, but it is not indicated at the initial presentation.

Option b: Ultrasonography of the abdomen is done but only after IV fluid resuscitation has been initiated.

Option c: The patient does not have cholangitis (absence of fever, pain localizing to right upper quadrant, and jaundice), so there is no indication for emergent ERCP.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in Acute Pancreatitis

Radiographic findings of acute pancreatitis are non-specific.

The sentinel loop is seen in an X-ray. It is a focal area of adynamic ileus close to an intra-abdominal inflammatory process. A sentinel loop in the upper abdomen indicates pancreatitis.

The sentinel loop sign may aid in localizing the source of inflammation. For example, a sentinel loop in the upper abdomen may indicate pancreatitis, while one in the right lower quadrant may be due to appendicitis.

Colon cut-off sign: Functional spasm at the splenic flexure due to the extension of inflammation to phrenicocolic ligament via transverse mesocolon.

The X-ray given below shows sentinel loop sign (marked as '1') and colon cut-off sign (marked as '2') in a patient with acute pancreatitis:

 

Renal halo sign: Edema around the kidney due to the involvement of paranephric fat resulting in:

  • Obliteration of psoas shadow
  • Localised ground-glass appearance

Related Pearl: Computed Tomography Severity Index (CTSI)/Balthazar Scoring for Acute Pancreatitis

Balthazar Score
Balthazar Grade Appearance on CT CT Grade Points
Grade A Normal CT 0 Points
Grade B Focal or diffuse enlargement of the pancreas 1 Point
Grade C Pancreatic gland abnormalities and peripancreatic inflammation  2 Points
Grade D  Fluid collection in a single location 3 Points
Grade E Two or more sites of fluid collection and/ or gas bubbles in, or adjacent to, the pancreas 4 Points

 

Necrosis Score  
Necrosis Percentage CT grade points
No necrosis 0 points
0 to 30% necrosis 2 points
30 to 50% necrosis 4 points
Over 50% necrosis 6 points

The numerical Computed Tomography Severity Index (CTSI) has a maximum of 10 points, and it is the sum of the Balthazar grade points and pancreatic necrosis grade points. 

CTSI score 0-3: Mild pancreatitis

CTSI score 4-6: Moderate pancreatitis

CTSI score 7-10: Severe pancreatitis

 

Related Pearl: Assessment of severity of acute pancreatitis

  • Bedside Index for Severity of Acute Pancreatitis (BISAP) includes:
    • Blood urea nitrogen, > 25 mg/dL
    • Impaired mental status, Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score <15
    • Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)
    • Age > 60 years
    • Pleural effusion
      One point is given for each. BISAP score ≥ 3 indicates severe pancreatitis.
  • Harmless Acute Pancreatitis Score (HAPS)
    If all the following are present then it is considered non-severe, i.e., no death, no need for dialysis, and no need for ventilation:
    • Absence of rebound tenderness or guarding
    • Normal hematocrit
    • Normal serum creatinine

  • Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation (APACHE II)
    • A score of 8 or more is considered to be severe
    • Can be done at admission and repeated any time
    • Complex, not specific for AP, and based on the patient’s age
  • Ranson’s score
  • Modified Glasgow criteria - 3 or more positive criteria, the disease is considered to be severe
  • Atlanta classification

questions.text:
Assertion: The islands of adenomyosis do not participate in the proliferative and secretory cycles in response to ovarian hormonal stimulation.
Reason: The ectopic foci of the glands and stroma in adenomyosis originate from the basalis layer.

choices.text: Assertion and reason are true, and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion and reason are true, but the reason is incorrect explanation of assertion
Assertion is independently true and reason is independently false
Assertion is independently false and reason is independently true
Both assertion and reason are independently false

questions.solution:
Assertion and Reason are true, and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion.

Adenomyosis is a condition in which there is a presence of ectopic pieces of endometrial tissue embedded within the uterine myometrium. These islands of ectopic tissue are derived from the basalis layer of the endometrium.

Because the cells of the basalis layer do not respond to the ovarian hormonal stimulation, the islands of ectopic endometrial tissue derived from the basalis layer do not participate in the proliferative and secretory cycles.

The patients are usually asymptomatic and this may be seen in about 60% of the women around the age of 40 years. However, some patients may typically complain of severe secondary dysmenorrhea and heavy menstrual bleeding.

questions.text:
Theme and focus: Causes of neurological signs

Lead in the question: For each of the following case scenarios, pick the appropriate cause from the list.

    1. Middle cerebral artery infarction
    2. Anterior cerebral artery infarction
    3. Posterior cerebral artery infarction
    4. Vertebrobasilar ischemia
    5. Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord
    6. Syringomyelia
    7. Cord compression
    8. Tabes dorsalis
questions.solution:
Case 1: Tabes dorsalis is a manifestation of syphilis, which occurs 10-35 years after primary infection. It occurs due to the degeneration of dorsal columns and nerve roots. The signs and symptoms include:

  • Impairment of proprioception and vibration sense
  • Argyll Robertson pupils
  • Muscular hypotonia Hyporeflexia
  • Hyporeflexia

Case 2: Abulia (lack of initiative), contralateral lower limb paresis, and urinary incontinence are all associated with carotid system and are seen in anterior cerebral artery infarction.

Case 3: The above clinical features are suggestive of sub-acute degeneration of the spinal cord. The condition is associated with vitamin B12 deficiency.

Pattern

Infectious (leprosy, Lyme, hepatitis B, C, or E, HIV, CMV), HNPP, tumor infiltration

With involvement of single nerves/regions:

May be any of the above but also could be compressive mononeuropathy, plexopathy, or radiculopathy

Asymmetric proximal and distal weakness with sensory loss

Polyradiculopathy or plexopathy due to diabetes mellitus

Meningeal carcinomatosis or lymphomatosis

Hereditary plexopathy (HNPP, HNA), idiopathic

questions.text: An infant is brought with a history of vomiting and poor feeding. A musty odor is noted in the baby. Guthrie test was done and it was found to be positive. All are true regarding this disease except

choices.text: White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency

questions.solution:
The given scenario of an infant with a history of vomiting and poor feeding with a musty odour is suggestive of phenylketonuria (PKU). Tryptophan deficiency is not a feature of this disorder. The deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase causes PKU. 

Characteristic clinical findings in Phenylketonuria:

  • Mental retardation
  • Failure to walk or talk
  • Seizures
  • Hyperactivity
  • Tremor
  • Microcephaly
  • Failure to grow
  • Deficiency of pigmentation (fair hair, light skin color, and blue eyes)

The Guthrie bacterial inhibition test is a screening test for phenylketonuria. This test uses a phenylalanine requiring strain of Bacillus subtilis. The ferric chloride test is also used as a screening test for PKU. Tandem mass spectrometry is the gold standard investigation.

Related Pearl: Phenylketonuria

  1. BH4 - tetrahydrobiopterin (or sapropterin, a synthetic form of BH4)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding operative vaginal delivery using ventouse:

choices.text: The cup is placed over the flexion point closer to the anterior fontanelle
The chignon persists for several weeks
Traction is applied between uterine contractions
A vacuum of 0.2 kg/cm2 is induced and is gradually raised upto 0.8 kg/cm2

questions.solution:
The ventouse extraction begins by slowly initiating a vacuum of 0.2 kg/cm2. This takes about 2 minutes. The pressure is then gradually increased to at the rate of 0.1 kg/cm2 per minute until the effective vacuum of 0.8 kg/cm2.

Ventouse is an instrument used in operative vaginal delivery by creating a vacuum between it and fetal scalp. The instrument consists of:

  • Suction cup
  • Vacuum generator
  • Traction tubing device

The suction cup is placed on the fetal head at a point near the occiput, called the flexion point, which is an imaginary point on the sagittal suture, located about  6 cm from the center of the anterior fontanel or about 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanel. Thus the flexion point is closer to the posterior fontanel.

 

Once the cup is placed over flexion point, the vacuum is generated and traction is applied.

Traction:

  • The traction is applied at a right angle to the cup and should be synchronous to the uterine contractions.
  • Between the uterine contractions, the traction is released
  • The traction is made using one hand along the axis of the birth canal, while the fingers of the other hand are placed against the cup to note the correct angle of traction, rotation, and advancement of the head.

Traction should be abandoned if:

  • There is no decent of the presenting part with each pull
  • Delivery is not imminent after three pulls.

Under any circumstances, the traction should not exceed for more than 30 minutes. Once the head is delivered, the vacuum is reduced by opening the screw-release valve and the cup is then detached.

An artificial caput succedaneum (chignon) is produced due to the sucking. It usually disappears within a few hours.

Related Pearl: Caput succedaneum and Cephalohematoma

Indicators Caput Succedaneum Cephalhematoma
Location Presenting part of the head The periosteum of skull bone and bone
Time of appearance  Immediately after birth Several hours after birth
Cause Prolonged labor, causing venous stasis and edema  Instrumental delivery, causes rupture of emissary veins in skull
Extent of movement Both hemispheres; crosses the suture line Individual bones; do not cross the suture lines
Period of absorption 2-4 days 2 weeks to 3 months
Treatment None

Supportive.

It can cause neonatal jaundice

questions.text: A 15-year-old child was brought to the emergency with 2nd-degree deep burns. The weight of the child is 60 kg. Which of the following fluid rates is recommended for burn resuscitation and what is the target urine output respectively?

choices.text: 2 ml RL x kg x % TBSA and 1 ml/kg/hr
3 ml RL x kg x % TBSA and 1 ml/kg/hr
3 ml RL x kg x % TBSA and 0.5 ml/kg/hr
2 ml RL x kg x % TBSA and 0.5 ml/kg/hr

questions.solution:
According to Parkland’s formula, the recommended fluid rate for children >14 years and adults is 2 ml RL x kg x % TBSA  and the target urine output for children weighing >30 kg and adults is 0.5ml/kg/hr.

Second-degree burns (Partial-thickness burns) result in damage to the epidermis and dermis. Depending on the extent of the dermal involvement, they can further be divided into superficial or deep.

  • Superficial: Involve the epidermis and upper part of the dermis (papillary). These injuries are red, moist, and extremely painful and blisters are present. The capillary return is clearly visible when the injured skin is blanched. Sensations are normal. They heal without scarring.
  • Deep: Involve the epidermis and the deeper dermis. These injuries are less painful and sensation is reduced. The capillaries do not blanch on pressure. They can lead to hypertrophic scarring.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: An intern attempts to insert a Foley catheter in an elderly male patient. However, in the first attempt, he meets resistance while advancing the catheter and fails at few more attempts with a smaller size catheter. Which of the following is the next best step?

choices.text: Attempt to pass a larger size catheter

questions.solution:
The next best step would be to examine the urethral anatomy using cystoscopy.

Cystoscopy is used to assess the urethra for size, strictures, false passage, or bladder neck stenosis. This facilitates the placement of a guidewire beyond any identified stricture over which a Councill catheter can be placed.

Other options

Option A: A suprapubic catheter is inserted only if all the attempts at urethral catheterization including flexible cystoscopy guidance are unsuccessful.

Option C: Attempting to pass a larger catheter in a patient who is suspected to have a stricture causes further trauma. However, a smaller bore catheter would be the appropriate choice.

Option D: An internal urethrotomy is a procedure that is done in cases where the urethral stricture is diagnosed. It uses an optical urethrotome to cut the fibrotic stricture under visual control.

questions.text:
Arrange the following physical changes in the sequence in which they occur during pubertal development in girls.
  1. Adrenarche
  2. Menarche
  3. Thelarche
  4. Mature sexual hair and breasts
  5. Peak height velocity
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of physical changes that occur during pubertal development in girls is as follows:

  1. Thelarche denotes the onset of pubertal breast development and is the first physical sign of puberty.
  2. Adrenarche or pubarche: Appearance of axillary or pubic hair.
  3. Maximal growth or peak height velocity.
  4. Menarche: Onset of menstrual periods
  5. Adult pattern of pubic hair and mature breasts.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient has NYHA class III heart failure with dyspnea, pedal edema and K+ levels of 5.5 mg% and creatinine 1.1 mg%. Which of the following drugs can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a patient with symptomatic heart failure and K+ levels of 5.5 mg%. She requires a diuretic for symptom control. Furosemide can be given safely as it causes hypokalemia.

Other options:

Option A: Digoxin is not used as a first-line drug in the management of symptomatic heart failure.

Options B and C: Spironolactone (K+ sparing diuretic) and enalapril (ACE inhibitor) can cause hyperkalemia.  

The first step in managing acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF) is addressing the factors that caused the decompensation. They include nonadherence to medications, dietary indiscretion, medication use that exacerbates heart failure, coronary ischemia, arrhythmias, valvular heart disease, infection, and pulmonary thromboembolism.

Volume management is crucial in ADHF. Intravenous loop diuretics are used to relieve congestion. The effectiveness of diuretic therapy can be assessed by changes in weight, improvement in symptoms, and clinical examination findings. Natriuretic peptide levels can also help assess the adequacy of therapy and predict risk.

Cardiorenal syndrome, characterized by the interplay between heart and kidney dysfunction, is a common complication of ADHF. Diuretic therapy should be carefully managed to avoid worsening renal function in patients with elevated right-sided filling pressures. In cases of severe low cardiac output, inotropic therapy or mechanical circulatory support may be necessary to preserve or improve renal function temporarily.

Vasodilators like nitroglycerin, sodium nitroprusside, and nesiritide (recombinant BNP) are used to reduce filling pressures and systemic vascular resistance. 

Inotropic therapy with drugs like dopamine and milrinone is used to increase myocardial contractility and improve cardiac output in patients with low-output ADHF. Dopamine has dose-dependent effects on different receptors, while milrinone is a phosphodiesterase-3 inhibitor.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in heart failure

questions.text: Glucosamines are used in which of the following conditions:
questions.solution:
The combined use of glucosamine sulfate and chondroitin sulfates in the treatment of degenerative joint disease has become an extremely popular supplementation protocol in arthritic conditions of the joints.

  • Glucosamines are amino sugars which form the major component of glycosaminoglycans. (GAG’s are tandem repeats of amino sugar and uronic acid)
  • GAG’s combine with proteins to form proteoglycans
  • One such proteoglycan is aggrecan containing several GAGs (hyaluronic acid, chondroitin sulphate, and keratan sulphate) and both link and core proteins
  • Aggrecan is the major proteoglycan in cartilage
  • Hence, from this we can deduce that glucosamines being a major part of GAG’s and proteoglycans such as aggrecan are protective against arthritis.

questions.text: The following statements are true/false regarding the supracondylar fracture of the humerus:
questions.solution:
All of the above statements are true.

Supracondylar fracture of the humerus is the most common fracture in children.

Mechanism of injury: It is a hyperextension injury due to a fall on the outstretched hand. The distal segment is more commonly displaced posteriorly.

The anterior displacement may rarely occur in case of direct fall on the point of elbow with the joint in flexion.

Clinical features: The child is in pain and the elbow is swollen. The passive extension of the joint may be pain free. The bony landmarks are disturbed and the ‘S’ deformity is seen.

Complications:

Neurovascular injury: The radial nerve, median nerve (particularly the anterior interosseous branch) or the ulnar nerve may be injured. The loss of function in most cases is temporary and the child recovers in 3-4 months.

Brachial artery is the most common vessel to be injured.

Malunion: Malunion is common with backwards or sideways tilt. Uncorrected sideways tilt and rotation commonly leads to varus deformity (or rarely valgus) of the elbow. This is usually permanent and will not improve with growth. The deformity is corrected by supracondylar osteotomy usually once the child reaches skeletal maturity.

questions.text: The conversion of calcidiol to calcitriol occurs in which part of the kidney?
questions.solution:
The conversion of 25-hydroxycholecalciferol (calcidiol) to the active form 1, 25-dihydroxycholecalciferol (calcitriol) occurs in the cells of the proximal tubule.

Various steps involved in synthesis of 1, 25-dihydroxycholecalciferol:

  • On exposure to sunlight, the 7-dehydrocholesterol present in the skin gets rapidly converted into pre-vitamin D3 which is then slowly converted to vitamin D3.
  • The vitamin D3 may also be ingested in the diet.
  • Vitamin D3 is then transported in the plasma, bound to vitamin D-binding protein (DBP).
  • In the liver, vitamin D3 is converted to 25-hydroxycholecalciferol (calcidiol) by an enzyme 25-hydroxylase.
  • The 25-hydroxycholecalciferol (calcidiol) is converted to an active form 1, 25-dihydroxycholecalciferol (calcitriol), in the cells of the proximal tubules of the kidney, by an enzyme 1α-Hydroxylase.
  • 1, 25-dihydroxycholecalciferol (calcitriol) is the most active form of vitamin D.
  • Another less active form called 24, 25-dihydroxycholecalciferol may also be formed in the kidneys by the action of enzyme 24-Hydroxylase.

Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman had an episode of tonic-clonic seizure after which she was brought to the emergency department. On examination, the patient is febrile and appears slightly confused. Neurologic and physical examination findings are normal. Laboratory test results are as below, and the peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
Investigations reports:
Hemoglobin: 7.8 g/dL
Platelet count: 45000/mm3
Leukocyte count: 9000/mm3
PT: 12 seconds
aPTT: 35 seconds
S. creatinine: 2.8 mg/dL
questions.solution:
Therapeutic plasma exchange is the treatment of choice for thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).

The laboratory tests show anemia and thrombocytopenia. Leukocyte count, PT, and aPTT are normal. Serum creatinine is elevated. The peripheral smear shows schistocytes on the blood smear. All of these findings are suggestive of TTP.

Other options:

  • Red blood cell transfusion may sometimes be indicated, however, it does not address the underlying pathogenesis of TTP.
  • Platelets are contraindicated because of the possibility of worsening the TTP.
  • Hemodialysis is indicated only If there is severe renal impairment. 

 

 

Note that TTP is a distinct entity and not the same as ITP

questions.text: Arrange the following corrections in the order in which they are done in the management of congenital talipes equinovarus.
Which of the following is the best clinical indicator to monitor the adequacy of therapy for a patient with shock?
questions.solution:
The urine output is the best clinical indicator to monitor the adequacy of therapy for a patient with shock.

The level of consciousness is an important marker of cerebral perfusion, however, brain perfusion is maintained until the very late stages of shock. Hence, it is a poor marker of the adequacy of resuscitation.

Related Pearl: Classification of hemorrhagic shock

Parameters Class I Class II Class III Class IV

Pulse rate <100 100–120 120–140 >140
Blood pressure Normal Normal Decreased Greatly decreased
Pulse pressure Normal or increased Decreased Decreased Decreased
Respiratory rate 14–20 20–30 30–40 >35
Mental status Slightly anxious Mildly anxious Anxious, confused Confused, lethargic
Urine output (mL/hr) >30 20–30 5–15 Minimal

 

Related Pearl: Compensatory responses to hemorrhagic shock

  • Baroreceptor reflex
  • CNS Ischemic response
  • Reverse stress relaxation
  • ↑ secretion of renin by kidneys and formation of Angiotensin II
  • ↑ secretion of ADH
  • ↑Norepinephrine and epinephrine
  • Compensatory mechanisms that return the blood volume back toward normal, including
    • Absorption of large quantities of fluid from the intestinal tract
    • Absorption of fluid into the blood capillaries from the interstitial spaces of the body
    • Conservation of water and salt by the kidneys
    • Increased thirst and increased appetite for salt
