questions.text: In which of the following cases can you do a delayed cord clamping?

choices.text: Non-vigorous baby of an HIV negative mother
Vigorous baby of an HIV positive mother
Non-vigorous baby of an HIV positive mother

questions.solution:
For Vigorous baby of an HIV positive mother, one can attempt delayed cord clamping

A baby is considered vigorous if all of the following if normal -

  • Heart rate > 100,
  • Good breathing
  • Good tone

Non-vigorous babies require urgent resuscitation and hence early cord clamping is done. 

Note:

According to AIIMS Protocols in Neonatology 2ed, Published in 2019 (Page 36, Table 4.1)

In uncomplicated preterm birth, delayed cord clamping(DCC) should be attempted for a minimum time of 60 seconds after delivery for preterm infants not requiring immediate resuscitation after birth. DCC must be done even if the mother has HIV infection. 

But as per the NATIONAL TECHNICAL GUIDELINES ON ANTI RETROVIRAL TREATMENT from NACO, published in October 2018, (Page 52) early cord clamping is advised.

questions.text:
Arrange the various thyroid cancers mentioned below in order from best to worst prognosis:
  1. Papillary
  2. Follicular
  3. Hurthle cell cancer
  4. Lindsey tumor
  5. Anaplastic cancer
questions.solution:
The papillary carcinoma has the best prognosis, followed by the lindsey tumor which is the  follicular variant of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. It is followed by follicular tumor. The anaplastic cancer has the worst prognosis.

So, the correct order of prognosis from best to worst is:

Papillary > Lindsay tumor > Follicular > Hurthle cell Cancer  > Anaplastic cancer.

Related Pearl: Gene alterations in thyroid cancer

Type of Thyroid Carcinoma  Mutations
Papillary Carcinoma

BRAF mutation

RET/PTC rearrangement

MET

NTRK1 fusion gene

GDNF - glial derived neurotropic factor
Follicular carcinoma  

RAS mutation

PIK3CA mutation

PTEN mutation

PAX8/PPAR1 fusion gene
Medullary carcinoma  RET mutation
Follicular adenoma  

TSH-R mutation

Gsα (GNAS) mutation

Ras mutation (<20% cases)

PAX8/PPARγ1 fusion (<10% cases)

PTEN
 Anaplastic carcinoma  

CTNNB1 (β-catenin)

TP53 inactivation

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

It is more common in iodine-deficient areas. It is associated with p53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS, miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346).

It commonly presents as solitary thyroid nodules and the mean age of presentation is 50 years. It can also occur in long-standing cases of multinodular goitre.

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.

Histological findings:

  • Encapsulated
  • Uniform microfollicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumour thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere. The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumour recurrence, as they are undetectable after complete treatment.

questions.text: A patient treated with an alkylating agent A, for the treatment of steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome. This drug A is also used as part of the regime for treating NHL. He now starts passing blood in the urine. A drug B, is used for treating the ‘Bloody urine’. All of the following statements are correct regarding the drugs A&B except?

choices.text: Blood in urine is due to acrolein produced by metabolism of drug A
Both drugs A & B can be administered oral or IV
Hemorrhagic myocardial necrosis can be caused by high dose therapy with drug A
Fluid restriction is advised during high dose treatment with drug A to reduce side effects

questions.solution:
Drug A is cyclophosphamide and Drug B is MESNA. Vigorous intravenous hydration, not fluid restriction is advised during high-dose treatment with cyclophosphamide to reduce hemorrhagic cystitis.

Cyclophosphamide is used for the treatment of steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome and is also used as part of the regime for treating NHL. Both cyclophosphamide and MESNA can be administered orally as well as intravenously. MESNA is used to treat hemorrhagic cystitis caused by cyclophosphamide metabolite acrolein.

Hemorrhagic myocardial necrosis may occur after high-dose therapy with total doses greater than 200 mg/kg.

Mesna Dosing - 60% of drug

questions.text:
Theme and Focus: Meningitis

Lead in question: For each of the following clinical scenarios described below, identify the causative organism.

a) Neisseria meningitidis

b) Cytomegalovirus

c) Streptococcus pneumoniae

d) Streptococcus agalactiae

e) Campylobacter jejuni

f) Haemophilus influenzae b

g) Pasteurella multocida

h) Naegleria fowleri
questions.solution:
The causative organisms for the diseases described above are as follows:

Case 1: d) Streptococcus agalactiae

Case 2: f) Haemophilus influenzae b

Case 3: h) Naegleria fowleri

 

Case 1:

  • The most common causes of meningitis in infants less than 1 month of age are E. coli K1, Group B Streptococcus, and Listeria monocytogenes. Among these, only Group B streptococcus is catalase-negative, while E. coli and listeria are catalase positive.
  • Among these Group B streptococcus (Streptococcus agalactiae) is the most common cause of neonatal meningitis, and is routinely screened in pregnant women at 35–37 weeks of pregnancy.
  • GBS colonizes the intestinal tract and can spread to the vagina. The presence of GBS in the vagina can be asymptomatic or can lead to amnionitis and endometritis.
  • GBS may also cause urinary tract infections in pregnant women.
  • Neonates can be exposed to the bacterium in utero, or during or after birth.
  • In utero exposure can lead to premature birth and subsequent early-onset disease.
  • Shortly after birth, infants with early-onset disease manifest with signs of sepsis, meningitis, or pneumonia.

Case 2:

  • Organisms that cause meningitis in children include Streptococcus pneumoniae (all age groups), Neisseria meningitidis (infants to 5 years of age), and H. influenzae b (6months to 5 years of age).
  • The cultural characteristics described in the question are shown by Haemophilus.
  • H. influenzae b grows on chocolate agar (which supplies necessary nutrients from lysed red blood cells) or as satellite colonies surrounding β-hemolytic colonies of S. aureus on blood agar.

Case 3:

  • The given clinical picture in the question and the lack of bacterial and fungal elements in the gram stain are suggestive of amoebic meningoencephalitis caused by Naegleria fowleri.
  • The organism is transmitted during the summer months in warm ponds, swimming pools or streams.
  • It invades the nasal passages of swimmers, travels via the olfactory nerve, and reaches the central nervous system.
  • It can lead to severe hemorrhagic meningoencephalitis seen in fatal infections. 
  • Mortality rates are especially high, largely because the disease is rare and progresses rapidly.
  • Motile trophozoites (directional movement) can be observed in a wet mount preparation of centrifuged CSF.
  • Treatment includes amphotericin B.

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms of various protozoa

questions.text:
Match the following scores given in column A with appropriate conditions in column B:
Column A Column B

1. Glasgow prognostic score

 a. Acute pancreatitis

2. Glasgow outcome score

 b. Liver cirrhosis

3. Glasgow-imrie severity criteria

 c. Wound infection (SSI)

4. Glasgow-Blatchford score

 d. Recovery after head injury
  e. Cancer outcome
  f. Upper GI bleeding
questions.solution:
Glasgow prognostic score:

  • It is used to predict the cancer outcome based on the measurement of CRP and albumin.
  • One point each assigned for albumin <3.5g/dL and CRP >10mg/L. The minimum score is 0 and the maximum score is 2.
  • A modified Glasgow prognostic score (mGPS) has been developed, where, isolated hypoalbuminemia is not assigned any score, i.e., patients with low albumin are assigned a score of 0 if CRP is low. However, if hypoalbuminemia is accompanied by an elevated CRP, then one point is assigned for each making a score of 2.
  • An mGPS of 0 or 1 is associated with an increased survival rate while mGPS of 2 is associated with reduced survival.

Glasgow outcome score:

  • The Glasgow outcome score is used to quantify the degree of recovery achieved after head injury.
Functional status Score
Good recovery 5
Moderate disability 4
Severe disability 3
Persistent vegetative state 2
Dead 1

Glasgow-Imrie severity criteria

  • The Glasgow-Imrie Criteria is used to determine the severity of pancreatitis based on 8 laboratory values. It is a modification of the Ranson score for acute pancreatitis.

Glasgow-Blatchford score:

  • The score is used to predict the risk of upper GI bleeding.
  • It includes the patient’s blood urea, hemoglobin, blood pressure, and other clinical parameters to predict the need for therapeutic intervention with transfusion, endoscopy, or surgery.
  • Another score used for upper GI bleed is Rockall score

Related Pearl: Glasgow scale for assessment of severity of acute pancreatitis

Within 48 hours

  • Age >55 years
  • White blood cell count >15 × 109/L
  • Blood glucose >10 mmol/L (no history of diabetes)
  • Serum urea >16 mmol/L (no response to intravenous fluids)
  • Arterial oxygen saturation (PaO2) <8 kPa (60 mmHg)
  • Serum calcium <2.0 mmol/L
  • Serum albumin <32 g/L
  • LDH >600 units/L

Related Pearl: Glasgow-Blatchford score For UGI bleed

  • Total score ranges from 0 to 23.
  • Hemoglobin value scores differs for men and women.
  • Scores of 6 or more were associated with a greater than 50% risk of needing an intervention.

Related Pearl: Assessment of severity of acute pancreatitis

  • Bedside Index for Severity of Acute Pancreatitis (BISAP) includes:
    • Blood urea nitrogen, > 25 mg/dL
    • Impaired mental status, Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score <15
    • Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)
    • Age > 60 years
    • Pleural effusion
      One point is given for each. BISAP score ≥ 3 indicates severe pancreatitis.
  • Harmless Acute Pancreatitis Score (HAPS)
    If all the following are present then it is considered non-severe, i.e., no death, no need for dialysis, and no need for ventilation:
    • Absence of rebound tenderness or guarding
    • Normal hematocrit
    • Normal serum creatinine

  • Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation (APACHE II)
    • A score of 8 or more is considered to be severe
    • Can be done at admission and repeated any time
    • Complex, not specific for AP, and based on the patient’s age
  • Ranson’s score
  • Modified Glasgow criteria - 3 or more positive criteria, the disease is considered to be severe
  • Atlanta classification

questions.text: The major neurotransmitter and the neuroanatomical area concerned with delirium are:
questions.solution:
The major neurotransmitter to be involved in delirium is acetylcholine, and the major neuroanatomical area is reticular formation.

The reticular formation of the brainstem is the principal area for the regulation of attention and arousal. The major pathway implicated in delirium is the dorsal tegmental pathway - projecting from the mesencephalic reticular formation to the tectum and thalamus.

The correlation between several delirium-inducing factors and decreased acetylcholine activity in the brain has been well-established by studies. Iatrogenic delirium can result from multiple anticholinergic drugs being prescribed simultaneously.

Another proposed mechanism, mainly for the delirium associated with alcohol withdrawal, is the hyperactivity of the locus ceruleus and its noradrenergic neurons. Other neurotransmitters that have been implicated are serotonin and glutamate.

questions.text: Subcortical arteriosclerotic encephalopathy that causes white matter infarction while sparing the overlying gray matter is also called as ______

choices.text: Familial multisystem taupathy with presenile dementia

questions.solution:
Binswanger's disease is also known as subcortical arteriosclerotic encephalopathy.

It is characterized by the presence of many small white matter infarctions that spare the cortical regions. Binswanger's disease was previously considered to be rare, but the advent of MRI has revealed that the condition is more common than previously thought.

Other options:

  • Pick's disease (frontotemporal dementia) presents with early personality changes and loss of social restraints initially followed by memory loss. The patient eventually becomes mute, immobile and incontinent.
  • Familial multiple system tauopathy with presenile dementia is a recently discovered type of dementia. It shares some similarities with Alzheimer's disease but it is not associated with the senile plaques seen with Alzheimer's disease. As in Alzheimer's, tau protein builds up in neurons and glial cells of persons with familial multiple system tauopathy eventually killing brain cells. The symptoms of the disorder include short-term memory problems and difficulty maintaining balance and walking and usually appear in patients in their 40s/50s.
  • Delirium occurring in a patient with dementia is known as beclouded dementia

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of dementia

Condition Features
Alzheimer’s disease
  • Insidious onset
  • Short-term memory loss
  • Language deficits and spatial disorientation
  • Later, personality changes
Vascular Dementia
  • Stepwise decline
  • Early executive dysfunction
  • Cerebral infarction &/or deep white matter changes on neuroimaging
Frontotemporal dementia
(Pick’s disease)
  • Early personality changes
  • Apathy, disinhibition & compulsive behaviors
  • Frontotemporal atrophy on neuroimaging
Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Visual Hallucination
  • Spontaneous parkinsonism
  • Fluctuating cognition
Normal-pressure hydrocephalus
  • Gait abnormalities 
  • Urinary Incontinence
  • Dementia
  • Dilated ventricles on neuroimaging
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
(Prion disease)
  • Behavioral changes
  • Rapidly progressive
  • Myoclonus and/or seizures

questions.text: A patient presented with a vesicle on his shin. Microscopy with Tzanck smear showed giant cells. The causative agent is:
questions.solution:
Vesicles on the shin and giant cells on Tzanck smear suggest the diagnosis of Herpes zoster.

Tzanck smear:

  • Cytological examination of skin blisters.
  • After rupturing the roof of the blister, the floor is scraped blade, and material is transferred onto a microscopic slide and fixed.
  • Slides are stained with Giemsa, Wright’s stain, or toluidine blue and examined under the microscope:

Vaccinia, orf, milker's nodules and variola  Acantholytic cells with Guarneiri Bodies

questions.text: A 65 years old male presents with a gradual decline in vision. All of the following can be causes except:
questions.solution:
Retinal detachment involving macula causes a sudden painless loss of vision. The rest can cause a gradual decline in vision.

The causes of sudden painless loss of vision are:-

  • Central retinal artery occlusion
  • Massive vitreous hemorrhage
  • Retinal detachment involving macula
  • Ischemic central retinal vein occlusion

questions.text:
Mark the following statements true or false regarding the Demographics of India:
  1. India is currently in the Late expanding phase
  2. The demographic gap is currently negative
  3. Dependency ratio is > 50%
  4. Demographic bonus is due to declining fertility
  5. Population growth rate is 1.2% as per SRS data
questions.solution:
• India is currently in the Late expanding phase - True
    • Currently, India is in stage 3 i.e. Late expanding stage of the demographic cycle.
  • The demographic gap is currently negative - False
    • As mentioned before India is in stage 3 of the demographic cycle which has a positive demographic gap (negative demographic gap is a feature of stage 5: Declining phase)
  • Dependency ratio is > 50% - True
    • As of 2016, the dependency ratio of India is 52%
  • Demographic bonus is due to declining fertility - True
    • The term demographic bonus denotes the decline in the dependency ratio due to declining fertility. The term demographic burden is used to denote the increase in the total dependency ratio during any period of time mostly caused by an increased old-age dependency ratio.
  • Population growth rate is 1.2% - True
    • The population growth rate is 1.2% as per SRS 2018 data. 

Related Pearl: Demographic Aspects of India

UN Data (2021)

  • India’s population was 1,393,409,000 (1.39 Billion) 
  • In 2021, India ranked 2nd in the list of countries with the highest population
  • Almost 34.5% of India’s population is urban
  • The population growth rate was 1%

SRS Statistical Report (2020)

Vital statistics according to the Sample Registration System data released by the Registrar General of India:

  • Infant mortality rate (IMR) in India - 28 per 1000 live births
  • The crude birth rate (CBR) - 19.5
  • The crude death rate (CDR) was 6.0

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of progressive shortness of breath and a dry cough. A chest X-ray reveals the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The chest x-ray shows a pattern of lymph node enlargement seen in sarcoidosis.

The characteristic pattern of lymph node enlargement in this condition is called the Garland triad or 1-2-3 sign, or pawnbroker's sign. The lymph nodes involved are:

  1. Right paratracheal nodes
  2. Right hilar nodes
  3. Left hilar nodes

Image showing a pattern of lymph node enlargement (1-2-3 sign):

questions.text: Which of the following patients do not fall under the Pulmonary embolism rule-out criteria (PERC)?

choices.text: Patient with an age of 54 years
Patient presenting with a heart rate of 80 bpm
Postmenopausal female not under estrogen therapy
Patient with no history of surgery requiring hospitalisation within the last 4 weeks

questions.solution:
Patients with an age <50 years are included in PERC, not those aged >50 years.

Pulmonary embolism rule-out criteria (PERC) lists out certain factors. For patients with a Modified Wells Score ≤ 4, all of these criteria need to be met to exclude the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism (PE), following off anticoagulation, and search for alternative diagnoses.

  • Age < 50 years
  • Heart rate < 100 bpm
  • Oxyhemoglobin saturation on room air ≥ 95%
  • No prior history of venous thromboembolism
  • No recent (within 4 weeks) trauma or surgery requiring hospitalization
  • No presenting hemoptysis
  • No estrogen therapy
  • No unilateral leg swelling

Related Pearl: Clinical prediction for pulmonary embolism: Well’s, Modified Well’s and Pulmonary Embolism Rule out Criteria (PERC)

Signs/symptoms Score
Clinical signs of DVT 3
Diagnosis other than pulmonary embolism is less likely 3
Heart rate >100 bpm 1.5
Immobilization for >3 days or surgery in the last 4 weeks 1.5
Past history of DVT/pulmonary embolism 1.5
Hemoptysis 1
Malignancy 1

Three-level score probability:

Well's criteria Score
Low <2
Moderate 2-6
High >6

Two-level score probability:

Modified Well's criteria Score
Pulmonary embolism unlikely ≤4
Pulmonary embolism likely >4 

 

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

questions.text: A metal factory worker suffers from noise-induced hearing loss. Which of the following structures will be affected?
questions.solution:
Noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL) damages the outer hair cells, starting in the basal turn of the cochlea. Outer hair cells are affected before the inner hair cells.

NIHL occurs after chronic exposure to less intense sounds. The damage caused by noise trauma depends on the frequency of noise (frequency of 2000 to 3000 Hz causes more damage) intensity, duration of the noise, and preexisting ear disease.

The audiogram in noise-induced hearing loss shows a typical notch at 4000Hz both for air and bone conduction known as acoustic dip/boiler's notch. Patients at this stage complain of high-pitched tinnitus and difficulty hearing in noisy surroundings. Pre-employment and annual audiograms for persons working at places where noise is above 85 dB (A) help in the early detection of NIHL. 

The human ear can hear frequencies from about 20 to 20,000 Hz. Below 20 Hz, the vibrations are infra-audible, and above 20,000 Hz, they are ultra-sonic. Pure tone audiometry can detect only up to 8000 Hz.

Extended high-frequency audiometry is recommended for early detection of hearing loss, as it can identify hearing impairments before the frequencies necessary for speech comprehension are affected. Distortion product otoacoustic emissions is a more sensitive tool than conventional audiometry, particularly in children under 5 years old for early detection of hearing loss. 

A noise of 90 dB(A) SPL (acceptable noise levels, sound pressure level), 8 hours a day for 5 days per week is the maximum safe limit as recommended by the Ministry of Labour. As per WHO, 85 dB(A) is considered the highest safe exposure level up to a maximum of 8 hours. 

The silence zone extends to a distance of 100 meters around the premises of hospitals, nursing homes, educational institutions, and courts.

Permissible limits of noise as per the noise pollution (Regulation and Control) rules: 

Zone/Area Day (6 am to 10 pm) limits in dB(A) Night (10 pm to 6 am) limits in dB(A)
Industrial 75 70
Commercial 65 55
Residential 55 45
Silence 50 40

Noise levels are measured in dB(A), which prioritizes middle-range frequencies for assessing noise-induced hearing loss while giving less weightage to low and high frequencies.

The image below shows an acoustic dip at 4000Hz: 

Other options: 

Option A: Crista ampullaris is a thickened ridge of neuroepithelium in the ampullated end of semicircular ducts.

Option B: Macula is the sensory epithelium of the utricle

Option C: Cupula is a gelatinous mass extending from the surface of the crista (peripheral receptor located in the ampullated end of semicircular ducts) to the ceiling of the ampulla, into which project the cilia of sensory hair cells. 

Related Pearl: Effects of Noise Exposure

  • Auditory effects
    • Auditory fatigue appears at 90 dB and is greatest at 4000 Hz. Whistling and buzzing in ear occurs with auditory fatigue.
    • Temporary deafness or hearing loss occurs after a single exposure to a noise, usually at a frequency range of 4000 – 6000 Hz. It disappears after 24 hours following noise exposure.
    • Permanent hearing loss can result after continuous or repeated exposure to noises around 100 dB. It occurs commonly as occupational hearing loss.
    • Exposure to noise above 160 dB may rupture the tympanic membrane and cause permanent hearing loss.
  • Non-auditory effects
    • Interference with speech occurs when sound has a frequency of 300 – 500 Hz
    • Annoyance is a psychological response to noise which can greatly affect efficiency and concentration
    • Noise has also been known to cause some physiological changes like increased blood pressure, intracranial pressure, increased sweating, etc.

questions.text: All of the following indicate MgSO4 toxicity in a patient receiving anti-convulsive MgSO4 therapy, except:
questions.solution:
Overdose of MgSO4 is associated with loss of patellar reflex. Hyperreflexia is not seen in MgSO4 toxicity.

MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia. It can also be used as a tocolytic to stop preterm labor. The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4-7 mEq/L. 

Patients must be monitored for the signs of magnesium toxicity:

  • Loss of deep tendon reflexes
  • Decreased respiratory rate at <12 breaths/min (Option B)
  • Urine output <30 mL/h
  • Chest pain and heart block 
  • Visual changes, flushing, muscle paralysis, slurred speech, Somnolence, and drowsiness (Option C, D)

The following clinical features occur with the overdosage of MgSO4.

Clinical response Serum levels of magnesium (mEq/L)
Loss of patellar reflex 8-12
Warmth and flushing 9-12
Somnolence 10-12
Slurred speech 10-12
Paralysis and respiratory difficulty 15-17
Cardiac arrest 30-35

Management of magnesium toxicity is as follows:

  • Stop magnesium therapy
  • Estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels
  • Intravenous injection of calcium gluconate 10 mL (10% solution)

questions.text: A G2P1 lady with 37 weeks of gestation is in active labor. You assist your labor room resident in giving a pudendal block. The resident explains that you have to approach the nerve by identifying a particular surface landmark. The landmark for this nerve block is:
questions.solution:
The ischial spine is the landmark for the pudendal nerve block. This is because the pudendal nerve is accessible here as it passes below the sacrospinous ligament at the level of attachment of the ligament to the ischial spine.

Sensory nerve fibers of the pudendal nerve arise from S2, S3, and S4 nerves. Pudendal nerve blocks in combination with local anesthetic are used to provide perineal anesthesia during the second stage of labor.

Here, a special needle (Koback)  and a guide (Iowa trumpet) are used. The needle is placed transvaginally underneath the ischial spine on each side and is advanced 1 to 1.5 cm through the sacrospinous ligament. 10 mL of 1% lidocaine or 2% chloroprocaine is used for the procedure.

The pudendal nerve block can be used for:

  • Analgesia during the second stage of labor. A pudendal block is used when there are contraindications to epidural/ spinal anesthesia or if there is a need for low vaginal and perineal anesthesia.
  • Episiotomy repair
  • Minor procedures of the lower vagina and perineum.
  • Instrumental delivery.

The complications of the procedure are accidental intravascular injection, retro-psoas abscess, subgluteal abscess, and retroperitoneal hematoma.

Also, note that the pudendal block does not impact the cervix or upper vagina and is ineffective for pain relief associated with uterine manipulation.

The below image shows the technique of localizing the pudendal nerve and administering a pudendal nerve block transvaginally.

Nerve/Nuclei Nerve Roots/Cranial Nerves

Radial nerve C5C6C7C8T1
Musculocutaneous nerve C5C6C7
Phrenic nerve C3C4C5
Nucleus ambigous 9, 10, 11 cranial nerve nuclei
Nucleus tractus solitarious 7, 9, 10 cranial nerve nuclei

questions.text:
Necroptosis is involved in which of the following processes:

1.     Physiological mammalian growth plate formation

2.     Reperfusion injury

3.     Cellular death in steatohepatitis

4.     Neurodegeneration related to Parkinson’s disease

5.     Host defense against cytomegalovirus infection
questions.solution:
Necroptosis is now recognized as an important death pathway that is involved in both physiologic and pathologic conditions.

Physiologically, necroptosis occurs during the formation of the mammalian bone growth plate. Pathologically, it is associated with cell death in steatohepatitis, acute pancreatitis, reperfusion injury, and neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson’s disease.

Necroptosis also serves as a backup mechanism in the host defense against certain viruses like the CMV, which encode caspase inhibitors as it causes caspase-independent programmed cell death.

questions.text: Identify the picture
questions.solution:
The given Fundus fluorescein angiography(FFA) image depicts the flower petal pattern that is seen in Cystoid macular edema.

Cystoid Macular edema(CME) is a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform(Henle’s) layer and the inner nuclear layer of the retina following a break in the blood-retina barrier.

CME can manifest in the following conditions 

  • Post cataract surgery- Pseudophakics (called Irvine-Gass syndrome) 
  • Topical prostaglandins side effect(especially in diabetics)
  • Niacin(Vitamin B3) toxicity
  • Epinephrine(especially in Aphakia)
  • Uveitis
  • Retinitis pigmentosa
  • Central and branched retinal venous occlusion
  • Diabetic retinopathy
  • Retinopathy of prematurity

Clinical features include sudden painless diminution of vision, blurring of vision and metamorphosis such as micropsia.

In CME, on fundoscopy, a honeycomb appearance and on FFA, flower petal pattern can be seen. On Optical coherence tomography(OCT), loss of foveal depression and intraretinal cystoid spaces can be seen.

Treatment of CME is by treatment of causative factor, administration of anti-prostaglandins such as NSAIDS(ketorolac) preoperatively and topical or systemic steroids.

The below given OCT image shows intraretinal cystoid spaces seen in CME.

 

Option A:Macular hole is a partial or full-thickness hole seen in the neurosensory retina of the foveal region. It could be idiopathic, senile or caused due to trauma or CME. There is a decrease in vision and metamorphopsia seen in this condition. Amsler’s grid testing shows a central scotoma. FFA shows absent foveal reflex with a macular hole.

An OCT image of a full-thickness macular hole is shown below:

Option B: smoke stack pattern is seen on FFA in central serous retinopathy(CSR). CSR is the spontaneous serous detachment of the sensory neuroretina in the foveal region with or without retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) detachment occuring due to choroidal vascular hyperpermeability.

On FFA it is initially seen as an ink-blot pattern or smoke stack pattern of hyperfluorescence which then spreads to take the configuration of mushroom or umbrella pattern.

The below given images depict the smoke stack pattern and mushroom pattern respectively.

Option D:Age related Macular degeneration (ARMD) also known as senile macular degeneration is a chronic and progressive bilateral degenerative disorder of the macula that affects older individuals >50 yrs. ARMD generally starts as dry ARMD which is characterized by the presence of drusen and gradually progresses to the advanced form known as wet ARMD whose hallmark is choroidal neovascularization with additional findings such as geographic atrophy.

Drusen are extracellular eosinophilic deposits between retinal Pigment Epithelium and Bruch’s membrane. The below given FFA image shows stars in sky appearance of Drusen.

questions.text: A patient has normal comprehension and repetition of speech but impaired naming and fluency. He has _______.
questions.solution:
The symptoms described in the question suggest that the patient has anterior transcortical aphasia.

Anterior transcortical aphasia (transcortical motor aphasia) occurs in damage to the supplemental motor area and/or connections to the frontal perisylvian speech area. This commonly occurs in infarcts involving the anterior cerebral artery or anterior—middle cerebral artery watershed area—hence also referred to as anterior transcortical aphasia. Patients have normal comprehension and repetition, but impaired naming and fluency.

Conduction Preserved Impaired Impaired Preserved
Anterior (nonfluent) transcortical Preserved Preserved Impaired Impaired
Posterior (fluent) transcortical Impaired Preserved Impaired Preserved
Isolation Impaired Echolalia Impaired No purposeful speech
Anomic Preserved Preserved Impaired Preserved except for word finding pauses
Pure Word Deafness Impaired only for spoken language Impaired Preserved Preserved
Pure Alexia Impaired only for reading Preserved Preserved  Preserved

(word blindness)

(the person may be able to see words and even know that they are words but not be able to interpret their meanings)

 Angular gyrus

All components of the language network are interconnected with each other and with

surrounding parts of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes. Damage

to this network gives rise to language impairments resulting in aphasia.

questions.text:
Assertion: A person is more susceptible to vibrio cholera infection when he/she consumes contaminated food rather than contaminated water.
Reason: Cholera is an invasive infection.

choices.text: Assertion and reason are true, and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion and reason are true, but the reason is incorrect explanation of assertion
Assertion is independently true and reason is independently false
Assertion is independently false and reason is independently true
Both assertion and reason are independently false

questions.solution:
Assertion is independently true and reason is independently a false statement, as cholera is not an invasive infection. The V cholerae does not enter the bloodstream but remain within the intestinal tract.

V. cholera is susceptible to acid. Therefore, a person who consumes contaminated water need to ingest as many as 10^10 or more V cholerae to become infected. However, when he/she consumes contaminated food, as few as 10^2–10^4 organisms are sufficient to cause infection due to the buffering capacity of the food.

Thus, a person who consumes contaminated food is more likely to get infected by V cholerae than a person who consumes contaminated water.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text:
Mark the following statements true or false regarding cerebellar cortex:

1. Dendrites of one Purkinje cell makes synaptic contact with up to 10 climbing fibers while each climbing fiber stimulates only one Purkinje cell.

2. Each mossy fiber stimulates thousands of Purkinje cells through Golgi cells

3. Granule cells are the only excitatory cells in the cerebellar cortex

4. The axons of Golgi cells, stellate cells, and basket cells inhibit the Purkinje cells

5. Lugaro cells inhibit Golgi cells
questions.solution:
All of the above statements are false.

1. Dendrites of one Purkinje cell makes synaptic contact with up to 10 climbing fibers while each climbing fiber stimulates only one Purkinje cell - False

The climbing fibers are the terminal fibers of the olivocerebellar tracts. These fibers ascend through the layers of the cerebellar cortex and terminate in the molecular layer and divide repeatedly. The dendrites of one Purkinje cell has a synaptic connection with only one climbing fiber, while each climbing fiber synapses with dendrites of 1 to 10 Purkinje cells.

 

2. Each mossy fiber stimulates thousands of Purkinje cells through Golgi cells - False

Each mossy fiber stimulates thousands of Purkinje cells through the granule cells (not Golgi cells).

 

3. Granule cells are the only excitatory cells in the cerebellar cortex - False

  • Granule cells and unipolar brush cells are excitatory while all other cells in the cerebellar cortex are inhibitory in nature.
  • The axons of the granule cells (called parallel fibers) cause excitation of thousands of Purkinje cells, and also stimulates the stellate and basket cells present in the molecular layer; and Golgi cells present in the granular layer.
  • The unipolar brush cells are also present in the granular layer. They receive excitatory input from the mossy fiber and stimulates the adjacent granule cells.

 

4. The axons of Golgi cells, stellate cells, and basket cells inhibit the Purkinje cells - False

  • The stellate and basket cells inhibit the Purkinje cells, while the Golgi cells inhibit the granular cells.

 

5. Lugaro cells inhibit Golgi cells - False

  • The Lugaro cells are cigar-shaped neurons lying at the level of Purkinje cells. They inhibit the stellate, basket and Purkinje cells.

Related Pearl: Cerebellar Circuitry

Cerebellar circuitry includes:

Afferents- Climbing and mossy fibers

  • Climbing fibers -
    • Origin - contralateral inferior olivary nucleus in the medulla oblongata
    • Terminates on - Purkinje cell
  • Mossy fibers -
    • Origin - multiple sources in the spinal cord and brainstem
    • Terminates on - Granule cell

Intrinsic components

  • Granule cell backward inhibition - done by Golgi cells- prevent transmission from mossy fibers to the granule cells
  • Purkinje cells forward inhibition- done by stellate and basket cells

Efferents -

  • The output from the cerebellar cortex - from Purkinje cells inhibitory output to the deep cerebellar nuclei
  • The output from the cerebellum - from deep cerebellar nuclei
    • Globose, emboliform, and dentate - via superior cerebellar peduncle
    • Fastigial - via inferior cerebellar peduncle

 

Related Pearl: Cerebellar peduncles and their connections

Peduncle Afferent fibers Efferent fibers

Superior cerebellar peduncle

Anterior spinocerebellar tract
  • Globose - emboliform-rubral pathway
  • Dentatothalamic pathway
Middle cerebellar peduncle -Largest, most lateral and only afferent Corticopontocerebellar pathway -
Inferior cerebellar peduncle
  • Posterior spinocerebellar tract
  • Cuneocerebellar tract
  • Olivocerebellar tract
  • Reticulocerebellar tract
  • Trigeminocerebellar tract
  • Vestibulocerebellar tract
  • Fastigial vestibular pathway
  • Fastigial reticular pathway

questions.text: Identify the procedure performed to manage a patient with chronic pancreatitis:
questions.solution:
The image shows a distal pancreatectomy with Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy indicative of the Duval procedure.

It is a drainage procedure for chronic pancreatitis. It was developed on the basis of a presumption that a single stricture of the duct of Wirsung near the ampulla was responsible for the obstructive pathology and terminal drainage would treat the condition.

This procedure has high rates of failure due to restenosis and segmental obstruction of the pancreas due to progressive scarring.

Related Pearl: Surgical procedures for chronic pancreatitis

Duval procedure: Distal pancreatectomy with Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy

Puestow procedure: Resection of tail followed by longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy

Partington and Rochelle modification of Puestow procedure: Elimination of resection of the pancreatic tail

A longitudinal pancreatotomy shows segmental stenosis of the pancreatic duct and the presence of intraductal calculi in a patient with chronic calcific pancreatitis. Following mobilization of a Roux limb of the jejunum, a longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy is performed to permit extensive drainage of the pancreatic duct system.

Related Pearl: Resection and Hybrid Surgical Procedures for Chronic Pancreatitis

Beger’s procedure: Duodenum-preserving pancreatic head resection (DPPHR)

  • The completed resection after transection of the pancreatic neck and subtotal removal of the pancreatic head, with preservation of the distal common bile duct and duodenum (Marked A).
  • Completion of the reconstruction of the anastomosis to the distal pancreas and to the proximal pancreatic rim by the same Roux limb of the jejunum.

Frey’s procedure:

  • The local resection of the pancreatic head with longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (LR-LPJ) provides complete decompression of the entire pancreatic ductal system. Reconstruction is performed with a side-to-side Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy.

Warren’s modification of Beger’s procedure:

Berne modification (Beger + Frey) involves excavation of the central portion of the head without formal division of the neck.

(image below)

Hamburg modification of Frey’s procedure

Note:

Surgical treatments for chronic pancreatitis

Resection

  • Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Kausch–Whipple procedure)
  • Pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy (Traverso–Longmire)
  • Beger procedure
  • Near-total or total pancreatectomy

Decompression/Drainage

  • Duval procedure
  • Puestow–Gillesby procedure
  • Partington–Rochelle procedure (Puestow)
  • Izbicki procedure

Hybrid (resection+decompression)

  • Frey procedure
  • Hamburg modification
  • Berne modification

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the modified WHO partogram?

choices.text: Right side of alert line indicates immediate referral to First Referral Unit (FRU)
Alert and action line are separated by a difference of 4 hours
Each small square in partogram is equal to 1 hour
Partograph recording should be started once the cervical dilatation reaches 4 cm

questions.solution:
Each small square in a modified WHO partogram is equal to 30 minutes. Each small square in a composite WHO partogram is equal to 1 hour.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a GPCR?
questions.solution:
Muscarinic receptors are G-protein-coupled receptors among the given options.

M1, M2, M3, M4, and M5 are the muscarinic Ach receptors.

  • M1 and M3 act through Gq protein and activate IP3/DAG causing increased cytosolic calcium.
  • M2 and M4 act through Gi protein and inhibit adenylyl cyclase causing increased potassium conductance.

Nicotinic receptors and GABA-A are examples of ion channel coupled receptors.

Insulin receptor is a tyrosine kinase receptor.

Metabotropic (mGluR)

GABA

Ligand-gated (GABA A and GABA C)

GPCR (GABA B)

Acetylcholine

Muscarinic – GPCR

Nicotinic – Ligand

Norepinephrine

GPCR

GPCR (except 5HT3 which is ligand gated)

Dopamine

questions.text: Given below is a histological section of the lung. Identify the structure marked X.
questions.solution:
The structure marked X in the above image is the lumen of the alveolar duct, which are tiny ducts that connect the respiratory bronchioles to alveolar sacs, each of which contains a collection of alveoli (small mucus-lined pouches made of flattened epithelial cells).

The coloured strips in the above image represent the location of different cells/structures in the trachea and bronchial tree.

On entering the lung, the principal bronchus divides into secondary, or lobar bronchi. Each lobar bronchus divides into tertiary, or segmental bronchi which further divides into the lobular bronchioles and then into terminal bronchioles.

Terminal bronchioles represent the most distal parts of the conducting passage. Each terminal bronchiole ends by dividing into respiratory bronchioles. Each respiratory bronchiole ends by dividing into a few alveolar ducts. Each alveolar duct ends in a passage, the atrium, which leads into a number of rounded alveolar sacs. Each alveolar sac is studded with a number of air sacs or alveoli.

questions.text: The mother of a newborn in your unit is extremely sick and is unable to feed her baby. The relatives have arranged a breast milk donor and wish to feed the baby using the device shown in the image. This method of primary feeding can be recommended in newborns with a gestational age of _______
questions.solution:
The given image shows paladai. It can be used as a primary feeding method during routine feeding in neonates born at gestational age 32-34 weeks only. Sick mothers or mothers with contraindications to breastfeeding can feed their child using paladai. The milk can either be expressed breastmilk or they can resort to using undiluted cow milk or formula feeds. 

<32 weeks will not have the coordination between swallowing and breathing. So, paladai can only be used occasionally.

>34 weeks will have a completely mature sucking pattern when breastfeeding becomes more preferred.

Choice of initial feeding methods in low-birth-weight (LBW) infants

Gestational Age Feeding Skill Matured Method of Feeding
<28 weeks No proper sucking effort. No propulsive motility of the gut IV Fluids
28-32 weeks

Sucking Bursts develop

No coordination between suck/swallow and breathing

 Oro-gastric/ Nasogastric tube feeding with occasional spoon/ paladai feeding
32-34 weeks Slightly mature sucking pattern. Coordination between breathing and swallowing begins Feeding by spoon/paladai/cup
>34 weeks Mature sucking pattern. More coordination between breathing and swallowing Breastfeeding

questions.text:
During a dexamethasone suppression test, which of the following factors may lead to a false-positive result?
  1. Phenobarbitone
  2. Pregnancy
  3. Phenytoin
  4. Rifampin
  5. OCPs
questions.solution:
Overnight dexamethasone suppression test is a screening test for ACTH-independent hypercortisolism from an adrenal nodule.

Dexamethasone 1 mg is given orally at 11 pm and serum is collected for cortisol determination at 8 am the next morning; a cortisol level less than 1.8 mcg/dL, is a negative result and excludes Cushing syndrome.

Some other conditions listed below may cause lack of suppression of cortisol levels and yield a false positive result of dexamethasone suppression test:

  • Antiseizure drugs (eg, phenytoin, phenobarbital, primidone)
  • Rifampin
  • Estrogen, during pregnancy or as oral contraceptives or HRT

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Exogenous causes (iatrogenic)

  • Prolonged administration of glucocorticoids (most common cause of Cushing's)

Endogenous causes

  • ACTH independent (primary hypercortisolism)
    • Adrenocortical adenoma 
    • Adrenocortical carcinoma 
    • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia
  • ACTH dependent (secondary hypercortisolism)
    • Cushing’s disease: ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma (most common cause of endogenous Cushing's)
    • Paraneoplastic causes: Ectopic ACTH secreting tumors
      • Small-cell lung carcinoma
      • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
      • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
      • Pheochromocytoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, malaise, and pharyngitis. On examination, splenomegaly was present and lymph nodes were normal. Peripheral smear showed a predominance of lymphocytes. The heterophile antibody test result is negative. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Fever, malaise, pharyngitis, splenomegaly with lymphocytosis suggest infectious mononucleosis. Cytomegalovirus is the most common causative agent of heterophile-negative infectious mononucleosis.

Patients may develop CMV infectious mononucleosis spontaneously or after transfusion of leukocyte-containing blood products. They present with fever, malaise, pharyngitis and splenomegaly. Cervical lymphadenopathy is rare. Some patients develop rubelliform rashes after exposure to ampicillin. Unlike EBV mononucleosis, heterophile antibodies are negative. This condition is less severe than the infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).

questions.text: The enzyme that catalyzes a reversible reaction in the gluconeogenesis pathway is:
questions.solution:
Phosphoglycerate kinase catalyzes a reversible reaction, i.e, the interconversion of 3-phosphoglycerate and 1,3 bisphosphoglycerate.

In gluconeogenesis, irreversible enzymes—glucose 6 phosphatase, fructose 1,6 bisphosphatase, and phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase—circumvent the 3 nonequilibrium reactions.

The enzymes can be remembered using the mnemonic Pathway Produces Fresh Glucose.

questions.text:
Assertion: The size of polysome correlates positively with the length of the mRNA molecule in an unrestricted system.
Reason: Ribosome particles cannot attach to an mRNA any closer than 35 nucleotides apart.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both the assertion and reason are true statements but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false statement
Assertion is false but the reason is true statement
Both assertion and reason are false statement

questions.solution:
Polysomes are assemblies of multiple ribosomes bound on an mRNA, i.e, many ribosomes can translate the same mRNA molecule simultaneously.

In an unrestricted system, the number of ribosomes attached to an mRNA (and thus the size of polyribosomes) correlates positively with the length of the mRNA molecule because the ribosome particles cannot attach to an mRNA any closer than 35 nucleotides apart due to their relatively large size.

questions.text: The method that can be used to estimate the likelihood of further survival at any time:
questions.solution:
Life table analysis allows the estimation of the likelihood of further survival at any time.

Example:- if a patient has survived for 3 years since diagnosis of colon cancer, how likely is he to survive for a further 3 years.

Note: Kaplan-Meir analysis and Kaplan-Meir plot are distinct.

questions.text: The incorrect statement regarding Wolfram syndrome is:-

choices.text: The usual age of presentation is between 5-21 years
Diabetes mellitus is usually the first manifestation followed by optic atrophy
Diabetes insipidus and deafness are also associated
Visual prognosis is usually good and life expectancy is normal

questions.solution:
The visual prognosis is poor and the life expectancy is usually significantly reduced in Wolfram syndrome.

Wolfram syndrome also referred to as DIDMOAD (diabetes insipidus, diabetes mellitus, optic atrophy, and deafness).

  • Three genetic forms are recognized, caused by mutations in WFS1, CISD2 or mitochondrial DNA mutation. The inheritance is AR, AD or via the maternal mitochondrial line.
  • Presentation is usually between the ages of 5 and 21 years with diabetes mellitus being the first manifestation, followed by visual problems.
  • Optic atrophy is diffuse and severe and may be associated with disc cupping. The Prognosis is typically poor (final VA is <6/60).
  • Systemic abnormalities, apart from DIDMOAD, are highly variable. These include anosmia, ataxia, seizures, mental handicap, short stature, endocrine abnormalities, and elevated CSF protein.
  • Life expectancy is usually significantly reduced.

questions.text: The level of agreement between repeated measurements of the same variable is assessed using:
questions.solution:
The test-retest method is used to assess the level of agreement between repeated measurements of the same variable. It is a measure of reliability/precision.

Ex:- To determine reliability the same test is repeated on two separate occasions for the same study group. It is quantified in terms of the correlation between the measurements made at different times.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: The minimum period for which medical records are required to be maintained for an inpatient is?
questions.solution:
According to the MCI Notification 2016, medical records of an inpatient is required to be maintained for a period of 3 years.

The MCI notification states the following regarding the maintenance of medical records:

  • Every physician shall maintain the medical records pertaining to his / her indoor patients for a period of 3 years from the date of commencement of the treatment in a standard proforma laid down by the Medical Council of India.
  • Medical records, when requested, should be issued within 72 hours.
  • A Registered medical practitioner shall maintain a Register of Medical Certificates including full details of certificates issued.

questions.text: The following statements are true/false regarding chronic myeloid leukemia (CML):
questions.solution:
Allogenic stem cell transplantation is first-line therapy: False

  • Allogeneic stem cell transplantation is now offered as second or third-line therapy after the failure of TKIs.

Current therapy includes the use of a tyrosine kinase inhibitor: True

  • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors, such as imatinib, nilotinib, and dasatinib are currently used in the treatment of CML.

Half of the afflicted individuals are children: False

  • The median age at diagnosis is 55–65 years. CML is uncommon in children.

The disease is driven by a mutation in the HFE gene: False

  • Mutations of the HFE gene are associated with primary hemochromatosis.
  • Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is a clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorder. The disease occurs due to the BCR-ABL1 chimeric gene product, a constitutively active tyrosine kinase, that occurs due to a reciprocal translocation between the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22, t(9;22) (q34;q11.2), also called the Philadelphia chromosome.

questions.text:
Assertion: Decrease in GFR due to loss of functional nephrons, causes a rise in plasma creatinine concentration, which is then maintained at an elevated level.

Reason: Following reduced GFR, the creatinine excretion rate is transiently decreased, but eventually is elevated, returning to normal

choices.text: Assertion and reason are true, and the reason is correct explanation of assertion
Assertion and reason are true, but the reason is incorrect explanation of assertion
Assertion is true and reason is false
Assertion is false and reason is true
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.solution:
Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion.

The creatinine excretion rate is calculated by the formula:

Creatinine excretion rate = GFR x Plasma creatinine concentration.

  • When there is a decrease in GFR, the creatinine excretion rate decreases initially.
  • As a result, there is a rise in plasma creatinine concentration.
  • Due to an increase in plasma concentration of creatinine, the excretion rate slowly rises until a point when the rate of creatinine production equals the rate of excretion.
  • Therefore, despite the reduction in GFR, the creatinine excretion rate returns to normal, however, the plasma creatinine concentration is elevated.

questions.text: Which of the following Darrow Yannet diagram is suggestive of adrenal insufficiency?
questions.solution:
The Darrow Yannet diagram shown in image 4 depicts adrenal insufficiency. In adrenal insufficiency, there is hypo-osmotic volume contraction.

Darrow Yannet diagrams depict the change in plasma osmolarity and plasma volume in various conditions. The dotted line in the diagram is the change after either addition or removal of fluid.

Adrenal insufficiency is characterized by aldosterone deficiency which leads to increased sodium loss (loss of hyperosmotic fluid). This results in:

  • The osmolarity of extra-cellular fluid (ECF) decreases.
  • ECF volume decreases because of the loss of volume.
  • Water shifts into the intracellular fluid (ICF). As a result, ICF osmolarity decreases until it is equal to ECF osmolarity, and ICF volume increases.
  • So, loss of hypertonic fluid causes hypotonic volume contraction.

The image given below shows Darrow Yannet diagrams of various conditions:

Diagram 1 - The addition of isotonic saline (0.9% normal saline) to ECF does not cause any fluid shift from the ICF. Hence, it only leads to an increase in ECF volume without causing any change in osmolarity.

Diagram 2 - The addition of excess NaCl to ECF pulls the fluid from ICF into the ECF. This results in a decreased volume of ICF, increased volume of ECF, and increased osmolarity in both ECF and ICF.

Diagram 3 - SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate secretion of anti-diuretic hormone) is associated with euvolemic hyponatremia. This leads to a decrease in the osmolarity of the ECF. This causes a fluid shift from the ECF to the ICF until the osmolarity of both compartments becomes equal. The fluid influx also leads to a decrease in the ICF's osmolarity. Therefore, the net effect is an increase in extracellular volume, an increase in intracellular volume, and a fall in osmolarity in both compartments.

Diagram 4 - Adrenal insufficiency is associated with hypo-osmotic volume contraction. Due to a deficiency of aldosterone, there is a decrease in both plasma volume and osmolality.

Related Pearl: Body Fluids Compartments

  • In ECF, a third specialized compartment, called the transcellular compartment (not shown in flow chart), is quantitatively small and includes the cerebrospinal, pleural, peritoneal, pericardial, synovial, intraocular and digestive fluids. Altogether it constitutes about 1-2 L.
  • The ECF volume/intracellular fluid volume ratio is larger in infants and children than it is in adults, but the absolute volume of ECF in children is, of course, smaller than in adults. Therefore, dehydration develops more rapidly and is frequently more severe in children.
  • All solutes and water that enter or leave the body do so via the ECF.
  • The ICF and ECF are in osmotic equilibrium. Water moves between these compartments only when an osmotic pressure gradient exists.
  • Equilibration of ICF and ECF osmolality occurs primarily by shifts in water and not shifts in solutes.

questions.text: A Forensic Examiner receives the following skull of a victim of mob violence. Which of the following conclusions he makes is correct:

choices.text: The victim could have suffered blunt force trauma
It is not possible to determine the sequence of injuries from fracture pattern
The victim could only have suffered from a gun-shot wound as indicated by Puppe’s rule
Fracture pattern in skull injuries are random and offer no clue upon examination

questions.solution:
Puppe’s Rule is true for all blunt injuries to the skull, and it is of particular importance in Gunshot wounds. But the rule is not limited to gunshots.

Puppe’s rule:

A new fracture Line does not cross an existing fracture line which can be used to determine the sequence of injuries.

In this scenario, the sufferer has been a victim of mob violence and the sequence of injuries would be as mentioned below.

  •  Correct sequence of the injuries in this would be 1->2->3

Note - Puppe's rule is applicable to any multiple blunt force trauma causing skull fractures.

questions.text: While performing a caloric test, what type of nystagmus would you expect on cold water irrigation?

choices.text: Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side
Vertical nystagmus towards the same side
Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side
Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side

questions.solution:
In caloric testing, cold water irrigation produces horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side of irrigation. The direction of nystagmus can be remembered by the mnemonic, COWS (cold–opposite, warm–same). 

The mechanism for the nystagmus is the creation of a temperature gradient by the cold water, which pulls the cupula away from the utricle, causing nystagmus towards the oppsite side. As the horizontal semicircular canal is closer to the outer ear canal, most of the response comes from it and the nystagmus is horizontal.  

The Fitzgerald–Hallpike test (bithermal caloric test) is done to assess this phenomenon. The patient lies in a supine position with head tilted forward at a 30° angle, ensuring the horizontal canal becomes vertical. Alternatingly, water at temperatures of 30°C and 44°C (7° below and above normal body temperature, respectively) is irrigated into the ears for a duration of 40 seconds each. The examiner closely observes the patient's eyes for the emergence of nystagmus until its endpoint is reached. The time taken from the start of irrigation to the endpoint of nystagmus is recorded and plotted on a calorigram.

If no nystagmus is evoked from either ear, the test is repeated with water at a temperature of 20°C for a duration of 4 minutes before labeling the labyrinth dead. A 5-minute interval should be allowed between testing each ear to ensure accurate results.

questions.text: A man is brought to the ER with a depressed skull fracture and a clean overlying scalp laceration. There are no focal neurological deficits. CT scan revealed that the degree of depression was less than the thickness of the adjacent skull bone. What is the next step in the management of the patient?

choices.text: Surgically elevate the depressed segment and close the laceration with sutures
Provide prophylactic antibiotics and discharge the patient
Apply dressing and discharge the patient

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the next step is to close the laceration with suture.

The management of the depressed skull fractures:

  • The first step is to order a CT scan to know the degree of depression and to exclude the presence of an intracranial hematoma or contusion.
  • The depressed fracture is elevated and managed as an open fracture (surgery) if:
    • The degree of depression is greater than the thickness of the adjacent skull
    • The wound is are open and grossly contaminated
    • There are focal neurological deficits
  • Less severe depressed fractures are managed by the closure of the overlying scalp laceration, if present.

Related Pearl: NICE Guidelines for CT in Head Injury

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Guidelines for Computed Tomography (CT) in Head Injury

Indications for CT imaging within 1 hour of the following risk factors being identified:

  • Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) <12 on initial assessment
  • GCS <15 at 2 hours after injury on assessment in an emergency department
  • Focal neurological deficit
  • Suspected open, depressed, or basal skull fracture
  • More than one episode of vomiting
  • Post-traumatic seizure

Indications for CT imaging within 8 hours:

  • Age >65 years
  • Bleeding or clotting disorders
  • Dangerous mechanism of injury (e.g., fall from a height of >1 meter/5 stairs, road traffic accident)
  • Retrograde amnesia >30 minutes

questions.text: Atropine is indicated in all of the following poisonings except _____.
questions.solution:
Endrin is an organochloride pesticide that causes neurotoxicity. There is no antidote available and only symptomatic treatment is done.

Parathion and TIK20 are organophosphates and baygon is a combination of organophosphate and carbamate. For all of these, atropine is the drug of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site of ectopic parathyroid gland?
questions.solution:
The most common site of the ectopic parathyroid gland is paraesophageal.

The common sites of ectopic parathyroid glands are

  • Paraesophageal - most common
  • Mediastinal 
  • Intrathymic 
  • Intrathyroidal 
  • Carotid sheath 
  • High cervical or undescended 

Ectopic parathyroid is the most common cause of persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism. In such cases, treatment involves surgical removal of the gland.

questions.text:
Mark the following statements as true or false regarding necroptosis and pyroptosis:

a. Inflammation is present in both

b. Pyroptosis is also known as programmed necrosis

c. Necroptosis is a caspase-independent programmed cell death

d. Necroptosis begins similar to the intrinsic pathway of apoptosis

e. Abortive HIV infection can lead to pyroptosis
questions.solution:
a. Inflammation is present in both - True

Both necroptosis and pyroptosis are accompanied by inflammation, as is necrosis. Only apoptosis is noninflammatory.

b. Pyroptosis is also known as programmed necrosis - False

Necroptosis, not pyroptosis, is also known as programmed necrosis

c. Necroptosis is caspase-independent programmed cell death - True

Unlike apoptosis, necroptosis does not result in caspase activation and hence it is also referred to as “caspase-independent” programmed cell death.

d. Necroptosis begins similar to the intrinsic pathway of apoptosis - False

Necroptosis begins similar to the extrinsic, not intrinsic, pathway of apoptosis, i.e. by receptor-ligand interaction. The most well studied is the TNF-TNFR mediated pathway. The pathway is as below:

e. Abortive HIV infection can lead to pyroptosis - True

Non-cytopathic (abortive) HIV infection causes pyroptosis by the activation of the inflammasome pathway. Inflammatory cytokines and cellular contents released during this process potentiate the recruitment of new cells and increase the numbers of cells that can be infected. This form of cell death may play an important role in the spread of the infection.

Pyroptosis is a process of cell death that is different from apoptosis and necrosis. It is involved in the clearance of necrotic and infected cells.

  • This type of programmed cell death is dependent on caspase 1 and caspase 11.
  • Cells infected by microbes → activation of inflammasome complex → activation of the caspase-1 → generation of biologically active IL-1 → fever, inflammation, leukocyte recruitment.
  • Caspase-1, along with caspase-11, also causes the death of infected cells.

Pyroptosis differs from apoptosis by the following features:

  • There is cellular swelling.
  • Cell membrane damage is present.
  • There is inflammation.
  • Caspase 1 and caspase 11 are involved.

questions.text: A child presents to the OPD alone, seeking treatment for a minor medical condition. A general physical examination can be performed with just the child’s consent, only if the child is older than ______.
questions.solution:
A general physical examination can be performed, exclusively by the child's consent, if that child is older than 12 years of age.

According to section 89 of the I.P.C, a child under 12 years of age and an insane person cannot give valid consent to suffer any harm which may result from an act done in good faith and for their benefit. In these cases, the consent of the parent or guardian should be taken. If they refuse, the doctor cannot treat the patient even to save the patient's life.

Additionally, a father giving consent for an operative procedure on the child in good faith and for the child's benefit, though the said procedure is risky, cannot be held responsible if the child dies.

questions.text: The package description of a drug states that 500mg of paracetamol is present in each unit of the tablet formulation, but in reality, each unit contains only 200mg. What is the terminology used to refer to these kinds of drugs?
questions.solution:
A drug stating that 500mg of paracetamol is present in each tablet, but contains only 200mg is a misbranded drug, according to the CDSCO (Central drugs standard control organization).

The drug and cosmetics act initially passed in 1940 and amended in 2016 provides a definition of misbranded, spurious, and adulterated drugs.

A drug is considered misbranded if it fulfills any of the following three conditions:

  • If the appearance of the drug has been altered to conceal physical damage or make it appear of greater therapeutic value than it actually is (or)
  • If it is not labeled in the prescribed manner (or)
  • If the label or container of the drug makes a false or misleading claim about the drug. In this case, the packet states that there is 500 mg of paracetamol present as opposed to the 200 mg that is actually present.

A drug is considered spurious if it fulfills the following conditions:

  • If the drug is imported under a name that belongs to another drug (or)
  • If the drug is an imitation of another drug with the intent to deceive (or)
  • If the label depicts a manufacturer that is either fictitious or a real company with no ties to the product (or)
  • If it has been substituted wholly or in part by another drug or substance.

A drug is considered adulterated if it fulfills the following conditions:

  • If it consists wholly or in part of any filthy, putrid, poisonous, or decomposed substance (or)
  • If it has been manufactured under unsanitary conditions (or)
  • If it bears a coloring other than the one prescribed (or)
  • If it has been mixed with any substance that may reduce its quality or strength.

*Note: The term counterfeit drugs is a broad term and is used by the WHO. This may also be conceived to include misbranded, spurious, or adulterated drugs. However, the term misbranded drugs would be a more appropriate answer here since it is likely that the reference used is from CDSCO.

questions.text:
The complications associated with refeeding syndrome are:
  1. Hyperkalemia
  2. Hypomagnesemia
  3. Hypercalcemia
  4. Hypophosphatemia
questions.solution:
Hypomagnesemia and hypophosphatemia, both occur in refeeding syndrome.

1 and 3 are false as, hypokalemia and hypocalcemia (NOT hyper), are complications of refeeding syndrome.

Refeeding syndrome is a fatal condition that can occur with rapid and excessive feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition which may be due to:

  • Starvation
  • Alcoholism
  • Delayed nutritional support
  • Anorexia nervosa
  • Massive weight loss in obese patients

With excessive refeeding, there is a shift in metabolism from fat to carbohydrate substrate which stimulates excessive insulin release. As a result, there is an increase in the cellular uptake of electrolytes, particularly phosphate, magnesium, potassium, and calcium.

Hence the metabolic abnormalities include:

  • Hypophosphatemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypocalcemia

These electrolyte disorders can result in myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, respiratory dysfunction, liver dysfunction, seizures, confusion, coma, tetany, and death.

The condition may be prevented by instituting the caloric repletion slowly and gradually increasing it over the first week.

Related Pearl: Complications of total parenteral nutrition

A. Related to nutrient deficiency

  • Hypocalcaemia/hypophosphatemia/hypomagnesaemia/hypoglycemia (refeeding syndrome)
  • Chronic deficiency syndromes (essential fatty acids, zinc, mineral and trace elements)

B. Related to overfeeding

  • Excess glucose: Hyperglycemia, hyperosmolar dehydration, hepatic steatosis, hypercapnia, increased sympathetic activity, fluid retention, electrolyte abnormalities
  • Excess fat: Hypercholesterolemia and formation of lipoprotein X, hypertriglyceridemia, hypersensitivity reactions
  • Excess amino acids: Hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, hypercalcemia, aminoacidemia, uremia

C. Related to sepsis

  • Catheter-related sepsis
  • Possible increased predisposition to systemic sepsis

D. Related to IV line

  • On insertion: Pneumothorax, damage to adjacent artery, air embolism, thoracic duct damage, cardiac perforation or tamponade, pleural effusion, hydro mediastinum
  • Long-term use: Occlusion, venous thrombosis

E. Related to motility

  • Cholestasis
  • Gallstones

questions.text: A physician recorded diastolic BP in 125 women aged 18 – 60 years and found the mean to be 70 mmHg with standard deviation of 10mmHg. Using z-scores, find the 5th percentile value.
questions.solution:
The z value for the 5th percentile is -1.645.

Using the formula for z scores, z = (X- µ)/σ, we get X = zσ + µ.

In this scenario, X = (-1.645 x 10) + 70 = -16.45 + 70 = 53.55 = 53.6.

Related Pearl: Z Scores

  • Z score indicates the position of any element in a distribution in terms of how many standard deviations it lies from the mean of the distribution.
  • It is also called the standard score.
  • If it lies above the mean, its z score will be positive and if it lies below it, the z score will be negative.
  • For example, if an element lies 1.5 standard deviations below the mean, its z score will be -1.5 and if it lies 0.5 standard deviations above the mean, its z score will be +0.5.
  • The formula for calculating z scores is z = (X- µ)/σ, where x is the element’s value, µ is the mean and σ is the standard deviation. From this, we can also calculate the actual value of the element.
  • Some of the z-values for commonly used percentiles:
