questions.text:
Match the following myeloproliferative neoplasms with their respective genes involved.

Column A:

  1. Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia
  2. Chronic Neutrophilic Leukemia
  3. Chronic Eosinophilic Leukemia
  4. Primary Myelofibrosis

 

Column B:

  1. JAK2
  2. t[9;22]
  3. t[15;19]
  4. PDGFRa
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

  1. CML Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia - B. t[9;22] 
  2. CNL Chronic Neutrophilic Leukemia  - C. t[15;19]
  3. CEL Chronic Eosinophilic Leukemia - D. PDGFRa
  4. Primary Myelofibrosis - JAK2

 

CML is the consequence of the balanced translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22 (t[9;22]).

CNL has been associated with a t(15;19) translocation.

CEL occurs with a deletion or balanced translocations involving the PDGFRa gene.

By contrast, in polycythemia vera (PV), primary myelofibrosis (PMF), and essential thrombocytosis (ET), erythroid or megakaryocytic hyperplasia predominates and their natural histories are measured in decades and transformation to acute leukemia is uncommon in the absence of chemotherapy.

PV, PMF, and ET are characterized by driver mutations that directly or indirectly constitutively activate JAK2, a tyrosine kinase essential for the function of the erythropoietin andthrombopoietin receptors and also utilized by granulocyte colony stimulating factor receptor.

WHO classification of chronic myeloproliferative neoplasms:

  1. Chronic myeloid leukemia, bcr-abl–positive
  2. Chronic neutrophilic leukemia
  3. Chronic eosinophilic leukemia, not otherwise specified
  4. Polycythemia vera
  5. Primary myelofibrosis
  6. Essential thrombocytosis
  7. Mastocytosis
  8. Myeloproliferative neoplasms, unclassifiable

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a right-sided blurring of vision for 3 months. The blurring is more for near vision and is not progressive. The right pupil is larger than the left and doesn’t react to light. On applying 0.1% pilocarpine, the right pupil becomes smaller than the left. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features suggest a diagnosis of Adie’s tonic pupil. This condition is usually unilateral and is caused by damage to the postganglionic parasympathetic neurons supplying the pupillary sphincter. The following findings are seen in the affected eye.

  • The affected pupil is larger and doesn’t react to light.
  • On applying a weak solution of pilocarpine (0.1%), the affected pupil becomes smaller than the other pupil due to denervation supersensitivity.
  • The affected pupil constricts very slowly on testing the near reflex due to aberrant innervation of the pupillary sphincter by ciliary muscle nerve fibers.

It is more common in young women and its etiology is uncertain. It may follow a viral illness. Absent knee jerk on the same side may be associated with this condition in which case it is known as Holmes - Adie Syndrome.

questions.text:
In a 26-year-old male that has been fasting, which of the following enzymes are likely to be active?
  1. Hormone-sensitive lipase
  2. Acetyl CoA carboxylase
  3. Phosphoenol pyruvate carboxykinase
  4. β-hydroxy β-methylglutaryl-CoA reductase
  5. Glycogen phosphorylase
questions.solution:
During fasting, the enzymes involved in catabolism (energy generation) - glycogen breakdown by glycogen phosphorylase, hormone-sensitive lipase to mobilize free fatty acids, phosphoenol pyruvate carboxykinase involved in gluconeogenesis are more active.

Those enzymes that are involved in anabolism (energy storage) - β-hydroxy β-methylglutaryl-CoA reductase involved in cholesterol synthesis, and acetyl CoA carboxylase involved in fatty acid synthesis are less active.

Dietary Reference Intakes

  • Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) - The average daily dietary intake that is sufficient to meet the requirements of almost all individuals in a group
  • Estimated Average Requirement (EAR) - A nutrient intake value that is estimated to meet the requirements of half the individuals in a group

questions.text: The X-ray image given below shows which type of Salter-Harris fracture?
questions.solution:
The above X-ray shows a fracture of the medial malleolus, with the fracture line in the epiphysis, below the physis. So it is a type III Salter-Harris fracture.

Salter-Harris classification is used to classify the injuries of the physis based on the radiological appearances. 

In a type III Salter-Harris fracture, the fracture splits the epiphysis and divides transversely to the other side through the hypertrophic layer of the physis. This damages the growth plate and results in growth disturbance. This type of fracture needs an accurate reduction to restore the joint surface.

Related Pearl: Types of Salter–Harris fractures- Mnemonic

There are nine types of Salter-Harris fractures. Among these, types I to V are more common.

The mnemonic "SALTER" can be used to help remember the first five types.

TYPE  MNEMONIC DESCRIPTION
Type I S = Slip/straight across Transverse fracture through the growth plate
Type II A = Away The fracture lies away from the joint. A fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis
Type III L = Lower The fracture is below the physis in the epiphysis.
Type IV TE = Through Everything  A fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis
Type V R = Rammed (crushed)  A compression fracture of the growth plate

Rarer types VI to IX have been added subsequently.

  • Type VI - Injury to the perichondral structures
  • Type VII - Isolated injury to the epiphyseal plate
  • Type VIII - Isolated injury to the metaphysis, with a potential injury related to endochondral ossification
  • Type IX - Injury to the periosteum that may interfere with membranous growth

questions.text: The most common type of small noncoding RNA is:
questions.solution:
The piwi-interacting RNAs (piRNAs) are the most common type of small noncoding RNA. They are believed to have a role in post-transcriptional gene silencing.

  • long intervening noncoding RNAs (lincRNAs) regulate the activity of chromatin “writers,” the factors that modify histones and thereby control gene expression.
  • snoRNAs are important in the maturation of rRNA and the ribosome assembly.
  • microRNAs (miRs) are small noncoding, single-stranded RNAs. They are approximately 22 nucleotides in length and mediate RISC(RNA-induced silencing complex) induced sequence-specific inhibition of mRNA translation.

questions.text: The oxygen delivery device shown in the image is:
questions.solution: The device shown in the image is an Oxygen Hood. It is used to deliver higher concentrations of oxygen than available at room air to newborn babies.

questions.text: A patient had an injury over his hand while gardening. After a few days, the skin became infected and painful. The culture of the wound on blood agar showed yellow-colored colonies, which showed effervescence when hydrogen peroxide is added to blood-agar as shown below. Which of the following organisms is most likely?
questions.solution:
The characteristic golden yellow coloured colonies on blood agar and catalase-positive reaction suggest the growth of Staphylococcus aureus. The catalase converts hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen, which causes effervescence on the media.

questions.text: In an amenorrheic patient who underwent pituitary ablation for a craniopharyngioma, which of the following is most likely to result in an ovulatory cycle?

choices.text: Human menopausal or recombinant gonadotropin, followed by human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)

questions.solution:
A patient with pituitary ablation would require the administration of human menopausal or recombinant gonadotropin, followed by human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) to result in an ovulatory cycle.

Because the pituitary gland is ablated, the patient cannot produce endogenous gonadotropin. Therefore, she would require exogenous gonadotropin in the form of human menopausal gonadotropin (hMG), which contains an extract of urine from postmenopausal women with follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) in various ratios.

Recombinant human FSH (rhFSH) is also available.

Carefully timed administration of hCG, which takes the place of an endogenous LH surge, will be needed to complete oocyte maturation and induce ovulation.

Endogenous or exogenous GnRH cannot stimulate the release of FSH or LH in this woman because the pituitary gland is nonfunctional. 

Other options:

Option A: Clomiphene citrate acts by competing with endogenous circulating estrogens for estrogen-binding sites in the hypothalamus. Therefore, it blocks the normal negative feedback of endogenous estrogens and stimulates the release of endogenous GnRH. However, the pituitary will not respond in this patient.

Options B and C: Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) acts on the pituitary to stimulate the release of FSH and LH. Since this patient has undergone pituitary ablation, GnRH cannot act on the pituitary and the patient will not respond to this treatment.

questions.text: A primigravida delivered a healthy baby at 39 weeks of gestation. The mother is positive for HBsAg and negative for HBeAg. What is the next most appropriate step for the infant?

choices.text: Both active and passive immunization right after birth
Passive immunization soon after birth and active immunization at 1 year
Only passive immunization soon after birth
Only active immunization soon after birth

questions.solution:
Infants born to HbsAg-positive mothers should receive both Hepatitis B immunoglobulin and HB vaccine.

These have to be administered intramuscularly at separate sites within 12 hours of birth, followed by 2nd and 3rd dose of vaccine at 1 and 6 months respectively.

Mothers with an HBV DNA viral load >200,000 IU/mL should receive an anti-viral such as telbivudine, lamivudine, or tenofovir during the 3rd trimester, especially if they had a previous child who developed chronic HBV after receiving HBIG and the hepatitis B vaccine.

As per the updated recommendations by WHO, pregnant women testing positive for HBV infection (HBsAg+ve) with HBV DNA ≥ 200,000 IU/mL should receive Tenofovir prophylaxis from the 28th week of pregnancy until birth, to prevent mother-to-child transmission of HBV. This is in addition to three-dose hepatitis B vaccination in all infants.

Related Pearl: Pattern of nuclear body suggests the type of antibody present in patient’s serum.

Five basic patterns of nuclear fluorescence is recognized for anti-nuclear antibodies:

Staining pattern Antigen
Homogenous or diffuse nuclear staining Antibodies to chromatin, histones, and occasionally double-stranded DNA
Rim or peripheral staining Antibodies to double-stranded DNA, and sometimes to nuclear envelope proteins
Speckled pattern

One of the most commonly observed patterns of fluorescence, the least specific. 

Antibodies to non-DNA nuclear constituents such as Sm antigen, ribonucleoprotein, and SS-A and SS-B reactive antigens.
Nucleolar pattern

Few discrete spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and represent antibodies to RNA.

Seen in systemic sclerosis.
Centromeric pattern

Seen in systemic sclerosis

Often contain antibodies specific for centromeres, which give rise to this pattern.

questions.text: A clinical trial was done between two groups to measure their blood pressure after treatment. Which of the following tests would be appropriate to use?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, two groups are being compared independent of each other. Hence, students t test/ unpaired t test should be used.

T tests are used if 2 groups are being compared. If the same group is compared before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: True statement about the phenomenon seen in the image below:

choices.text: The cells being engulfed is destroyed immediately
A cell engulfs the cell of same type
The cell being engulfed undergo division inside the host cell
The above condition helps in the destruction of dead cells

questions.solution:
The above image showing a cell within a cell is termed as emperipolesis.

Emperipolesis is a condition where living and intact state hematopoietic cells are seen in the cytoplasm of a host cell without any damage. Both of these cells remain viable without any physiological or morphological changes. The cells taken in are neutrophils, lymphocytes, and plasma cells. The host cells may be a megakaryocyte, monocyte, endothelial cell, fibroblast, or malignant cells. The engulfed cell is enclosed in a membrane-bound vacuole in the cytoplasm of the host cell. Internalized cells appear to continue living within the host cell for brief periods of time. Sometimes they even undergo division within the vacuole.

Phagocytosis differs from emperipolesis as the engulfed cells are dead or dying cells or other materials from the extracellular space  (Option A and D). Phagocytosis also uses the host cell cytoskeleton to form pseudopodia and engulf the dead material. 

Entosis is a phenomenon where a cell engulfs a cell of the same type (Option B). While cells that are internalized by this mechanism are initially viable, the majority of them undergo a non-apoptotic form of cell death.

questions.text: In the given breathing pattern, what are the points with the highest PCO2 in pulmonary blood and the highest PCO2 of the neurons in the respiratory center respectively?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the Cheyne-Stokes respiration. The highest PCO2 of pulmonary blood and the neurons in the respiratory center are denoted by points 1 and 2 respectively.
 
Cheyne-Stokes respiration is a pattern of periodic breathing. It is characterized by periods of hyperventilation with gradual waxing and waning of the tidal volume separated by equal periods of apnea. It occurs during sleep and in patients with severe heart disease or brain injury.
In the Cheyne-Stokes pattern, the depth of respiration corresponds to the PCO2 in the respiratory center. The maximum depth of respiration occurs when the PCO2 in the respiratory center is maximum. (Point 2)
 
The CO2 of the pulmonary blood takes several seconds before it is transported to the brain. Therefore, when there is excessive ventilation, the CO2 washes away, and PCO2 is decreased in the blood. After a delay, the PCO2 in the respiratory center is decreased and ventilation is inhibited. 
 
During the phase of apnea, the PCO2 of the pulmonary blood starts rising, however, the ventilation does not begin immediately. After some delay, at the time when the PCO2 in the pulmonary blood reaches the maximum, the PCO2 in the respiratory center starts rising, and at this point (Point 1) the ventilation begins.
 
The image given below shows different types of breathing patterns.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are false regarding GIST?
  1. Carney triad includes gastric GIST, pulmonary chondroma, and extra-adrenal paraganglioma.
  2. Location of the tumor is the most important prognostic factor.
  3. Succinyl dehydrogenase negative GIST are c-KIT & PDGFRA negative.
  4. DOG-1 is the most specific marker
  5. SDH deficient GIST have primary resistance to imatinib
questions.solution:
Only statement 2 is false. The prognosis of the GIST depends on the number of mitotic figures in histopathology, not on the location of the tumor.

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) are mesenchymal tumors arising from the intestinal cells of Cajal. It is seen in the 5th to 6th decade of life and has equal preponderance among males and females.

The GIST may occur as sporadic cases or as part of familial syndromes.

Familial syndromes associated are:

Carney’s triad:

  • Gastric GIST
  • Pulmonary chondroma
  • Extra-adrenal paraganglioma

Carney-Stratakis syndrome also called Carney dyad:

  • GIST
  • Paraganglioma

The gastric GIST in carney’s triad is succinyl dehydrogenase negative, and have primary imatinib resistance. The drugs used in imatinib-resistant GISTS are sunitinib and sorafenib.

The GIST may range from benign to malignant. Fletcher’s classification is used, which is based on the size of the tumor and the number of mitotic figures.

Risk of recurrence Largest tumor dimension (cm) Mitoses, per 50 hpf
Very low risk <2 <5
Low risk 2-5 <5
Intermediate risk <5 6-10
  5-10 <5
High risk >5 >5
  >10 Any mitotic rate
  Any size >10

Immunohistochemistry:

  • CD117 (C-KIT +ve): Most common marker
  • CD34
  • DOG-1: The most specific marker
  • Platelet-derived growth factor receptor alpha (PDGFRA) receptor mutations.

Succinyl dehydrogenase negative GIST are c-KIT & PDGFRA negative.

 

Note: GIST is the most common variety of visceral STS.

Related Pearl: Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST)

M/C mesenchymal tumor of GIT arising from interstitial cells of Cajal (pacemaker cells of GIT). Stomach is the m/c site.

GISTs express:

  • c-KIT (CD117)
  • PDGF receptor A
  • CD34
  • SDH

Clinical Features:

  • Peaks at 60 years of age.
  • M/C symptom: Upper GI bleeding
  • Other symptoms: Pain, lump, perforation, incidental finding
  • Carney's Triad: Sporadic GIST, Paraganglioma, Pulmonary chondroma

Management:

  • IOC for primary GIST: CECT abdomen
  • IOC for recurrent GIST: PET-CT
  • IHC markers: CD117/C-KIT (M/C), DOG 1 (most specific), CD 34
  • Route of metastasis: Hematogenous

The following image shows microscopy of GIST composed of spindle-shaped tumor cells:

  • Fletcher's classification (Tumor size & No. of mitotic figures) is used to classify the tumors according to their malignancy risk.
  • Prognosis is determined by: Mitotic index, tumor size & location of tumor (Stomach GISTs are less aggressive).
  • Complete surgical resection is the mainstay treatment. For unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic GISTs, imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can be used.

questions.text: Given below is the histological section of the cornea. Identify the structures marked X and Y in the image.
questions.solution:
The structures marked X and Y are the endothelium and Bowman's membrane, respectively.

The human cornea has five layers. From the anterior to posterior, the layers of the human cornea are as follows:

  1. Corneal epithelium - It is the outermost layer made up of non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. It is continuous with the conjunctival epithelium.
  2. Bowman's layer - The anterior-limiting lamina lies behind the corneal epithelium. It contains a dense mass of collagen (mainly type I collagen fibrils) set in a matrix similar to that of the substantia propria.
  3. Corneal stroma (also substantia propria) - It is a thick, transparent middle layer, consisting of regularly arranged collagen fibers along with sparsely distributed interconnected keratocytes.
  4. Descemet's membrane - It is a thin acellular layer that serves as the modified basement membrane of the corneal endothelium, from which the cells are derived. This layer is composed mainly of collagen type IV fibrils.
  5. Corneal endothelium - The endothelium covers the posterior surface of the cornea and consists of a single layer of squamous cells.

The sixth layer called Dua’s layer or pre-Descemet’s layer has been recently discovered, located between the stroma and the Descemet’s membrane.

  3. Muscle for whispering - B. Lateral cricoarytenoid
  4. Tensor of vocal cords - F. Cricothyroid

Related Pearl: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

  • All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)
  • All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)

Vocalis is known as the modulator of larynx because, the anterior part of the vocalis muscle can tense the vocal cord, and its posterior part can relax the vocal cord.

questions.text: All of the following parameters are typically increased in chronic severe aortic regurgitation except:
questions.solution:
Diastolic blood pressure falls (not increased) in aortic regurgitation.

  • Aortic regurgitation causes an increase in the LV end-diastolic volume (increased preload).
  • The total LV stroke volume also increases in an attempt to maintain the effective LV stroke volume (total LV stroke volume – regurgitant volume).
  • To achieve this, the LV must dilate. As the LV dilates, the wall tension increases to maintain the systolic pressure as dictated by LaPlace’s law, and as a result, the LV afterload is increased.
  • During diastole, as a large volume of blood leaves the systemic circulation to regurgitate into the LV, the diastolic pressure falls, often equilibrating with the LV pressure in severe cases.
  • As the systolic pressure is maintained and the diastolic pressure falls, the pulse pressure is increased.
  • Coronary perfusion is reduced as it occurs primarily during diastole and depends on the gradient between aortic pressure and LV pressure through the coronaries. This explains why patients with severe AR may manifest anginal symptoms.

Related Pearl: Causes of Valvular Heart Disease

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding the PAX6 gene except?

choices.text: PAX6 deletion usually causes autosomal dominant aniridia
Isolated PAX6 Deletion causes sporadic aniridia and Wilms tumor
Involved in patients with WAGR syndrome

questions.solution:
Isolated PAX6 deletion causes sporadic aniridia but is not associated with an increased risk of Wilm’s tumor.

PAX6 gene is located on Ch11p13 and isolated deletions result only in sporadic aniridia. It is autosomal dominant in 2/3rd of the people.

Constitutional deletions of Ch11p13 as seen in WAGR syndrome involve deletions of both WT1 and PAX6 genes. It is associated with Wilms tumor, aniridia, genital anomalies, and mental retardation. Their lifetime risk of developing Wilms tumor is 33%.

questions.text: All of the following are the risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus except:
questions.solution:
Barrett’s esophagus is a risk factor for adenocarcinoma of the esophagus, not squamous cell carcinoma.

The risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus include:

  • Smoking
  • Alcohol
  • Smoked food/fish
  • Achalasia
  • Plummer-Vinson syndrome
  • CREST syndrome :
    • Calcinosis
    • Raynaud phenomenon
    • Esophageal abnormalities
    • Sclerodactyly
    • Telangiectasia
  • Tylosis
  • Acid/Alkali ingestion

The risk factors for adenocarcinoma of the esophagus include:

  • Smoking
  • Alcohol
  • Obesity
  • GERD
  • Barrett’s esophagus

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text: Which of the following can be used to store blood for up to 35 days?
questions.solution:
Citrate dextrose phosphate adenine-1 (CDPA-1) can be used to store blood for up to 35 days. It helps in improving ATP synthesis during storage. Hence, it increases the shelf life.

The disadvantage of using CDPA-1 is that it increases uric acid stone formation.

The shelf life of storage with other components are:

  • Acid Citrate dextrose – 21 days
  • Citrate-phosphate dextrose – 21 days

questions.text:
True regarding the mechanism of MgSO4 in neuroprotection is:

A. Anti-inflammatory effect

B. Vasodilation

C. Decreasing Free radical Injury

D. Inhibition of calcium influx into cells

choices.text: A, B, C & D are correct

questions.solution:
Effect of MgSO4 induced neuroprotection is multipronged involving intracellular processes like inhibition of calcium influx into cell, anti-inflammatory effects, vasodilatation and decreasing free radical injury.

Indications:

  • <31 weeks gestation with imminent preterm birth - active labor with ≥4 cm of cervical dilation, with or without PPROM
  • Planned preterm deliveries for fetal or maternal indications

 

The drug is administered as a 4 g IV loading dose, over 30 minutes, followed by a 1 g/hr maintenance infusion until birth for a maximum of 24 hours.

Mothers should be monitored for respiratory depression.

questions.solution:
The correct match of specific reversal agents for anticoagulants is:

Ciraparantag is a potential reversal agent for all of the direct anticoagulants, and is currently under development.

Ustekinumab is a monoclonal antibody used in the treatment of psoriasis, crohns and ulcerative colitis.

questions.text:
Mark the following True or False regarding pathologic calcification:
  1. Dystrophic calcification is seen in areas of caseous and coagulative necrosis but not in liquefactive necrosis
  2. The macroscopic appearance of calcium deposition is site specific 
  3. Pathologic calcification is associated with iron and magnesium deposition
  4. Dystrophic calcification is associated with normal calcium levels while metastatic calcification is associated with hypercalcemia
  5. Hypercalcemia accentuates dystrophic calcification
questions.solution:
A. Dystrophic calcification is seen in areas of caseous and coagulative necrosis but not in liquefactive necrosis - False

Dystrophic calcification can be seen in areas of necrosis, whether they are of coagulative, caseous, or liquefactive type, and also in foci of enzymatic necrosis of fat.

B. The macroscopic appearance of calcium deposition is site specific - False

Whatever be the site of deposition, the calcium salts appear macroscopically as fine, white granules or clumps, and are often felt as gritty deposits.

C. Pathologic calcification is associated with iron and magnesium deposition - True

Pathologic calcification is defined as the abnormal tissue deposition of calcium salts, together with smaller amounts of iron, magnesium, and other mineral salts.

D. Dystrophic calcification is associated with normal calcium levels while metastatic calcification is associated with hypercalcemia - True

Serum calcium is usually normal in dystrophic calcification, while hypercalcemia is associated with metastatic calcification.

E. Hypercalcemia accentuates dystrophic calcification - True

Hypercalcemia though usually is associated with Metastatic calcification, it also accentuates dystrophic calcification.

questions.text:
Assertion:-
HLA-B27 associated hypopyon is immobile and slow to absorb.
Reason:-
In Behçet disease, the hypopyon contains minimal fibrin and shifts according to the patient’s head position.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both the assertion and reason are true but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false
Assertion is false but the reason is true
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.solution:
Hypopyon is common in HLA-B27-associated acute anterior uveitis. It has a high fibrin content which makes it immobile and slow to absorb.

 

The hypopyon contains minimal fibrin and so characteristically shifts according to the patient’s head position in Behcet’s Disease.

questions.text:
Match the following leukodystrophies with their corresponding abnormalities.

Column A

1.     Lysosomal arylsulfatase A deficiency

2.     GFAP gene mutations

3.     Translation initiation factor eIF2B mutations

4.     ABCD1 peroxisomal transporter

 

 

Column B

a. Alexander disease

b. Adrenoleukodystrophy

c. Metachromatic leukodystrophy

d. Vanishing white matter leukoencephalopathy

e. Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease
questions.solution:
Metachromatic leukodystrophy is an autosomal recessive disease that results from a deficiency of the lysosomal enzyme arylsulfatase A.

Mutations in intermediate filament proteins such as GFAP cause Alexander disease

A mutation in genes for various subunits of translation initiation factor eIF2B results in vanishing white matter leukoencephalopathy.

Adrenoleukodystrophy is an X-linked recessive disease associated with mutations in a member of the ATP-binding cassette transporter family of proteins (ABCD1), which is involved in the transport of molecules into the peroxisome.

Mutations in genes that encode proteins required for myelin formation result in Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease. It is a rare, X-linked recessive disorder characterized by central nervous system dysmyelination. Proteolipid protein gene (PLP1) located at Xq22 is affected, leading to the failure of axon myelination by oligodendrocytes in the central nervous system.

questions.text:
The contraindications for noninvasive ventilation are:

a. Cardiac arrest

b. Respiratory arrest

questions.solution:
The contraindications of Non-invasive ventilation are:

  • Cardiac arrest
  • Respiratory arrest

  • Severe gastrointestinal bleed
  • Hemodynamic instability
  • Unstable angina and myocardial infarction
  • Facial surgery or trauma
  • Upper airway obstruction
  • High-risk aspiration and/or inability to protect airways
  • Inability to clear secretions

questions.text: The following image depicts the life cycle of:
questions.solution:
The above image depicts the life cycle of Onchocerca volvulus.

The life cycle of Onchocerca volvulus is completed partly in humans, the definitive host, and partly in female black flies, the intermediate host.

During a blood meal, the female blackfly ingests the microfilariae from the skin and lymphatics of an infected person. It is within the vector that the microfilariae develop into first-stage larvae and subsequently into third-stage infective larvae.

When the infected black fly bites another person, it introduces third-stage filarial larvae into the skin of the human host.

They penetrate into the bite wound and develop into adult worms in the subcutaneous tissues within subcutaneous nodules called onchocercomas or live freely in the tissues.

The adult worm can live in the human host for about 15 years while the microfilariae for about a year.

Other options:

Option A: Loa loa completes its life cycle in humans, the definitive host and in mango flies/day biting flies of the genus Chrysops, which are the intermediate hosts/vectors. The microfilariae develop into third-stage larve in the vector. Its life cycle is shown in the image below:

Option B: Leishmania donovani completes its life cycle in the female sandfly, the vector and in definitive hosts which include man, dog and other mammals. The promastigote form in the midgut of the sandfly is the infective form. Its life cycle is shown in the image below:

Option C: Wucheraria bancrofti passes its life cycle in partly in humans, the definitive host and in female Culex mosquitoes, the intermediate hosts. Its life cycle is shown in the image below:

questions.text:
Dementias can be caused/associated with infections by:
  1. Cryptococcus
  2. Treponema pallidum
  3. VZV
  4. HIV
questions.solution:
Infectious dementias can be caused due to infections by HIV, Varicella, Treponema pallidum and Varicella-Zoster Virus is associated with vascular dementias.

Interestingly, VZV is the only human virus that can replicate in cerebral arteries and produce vasculopathy. This occurs mainly in the elderly and immunocompromised patients paving way for vascular dementias. Also, the Varicella zoster virus is the only virus proven to cause transient ischemic attacks and stroke in humans.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl was referred to the medicine OPD for the evaluation of a sudden syncopal attack that occurred while she was waiting for a bus. History revealed that she had felt hot and clammy before she lost consciousness. After some time she regained consciousness and was fully oriented. There were no similar episodes in the past. On examination, there are no abnormal physical findings. No orthostatic symptoms or signs were noted. Peripheral pulse and neurological examination were normal. No significant family history noted. ECG was normal.  What is your advice?

choices.text: Prescribe β blocker to prevent future episodes of syncope

questions.solution:
Reassure the patient. As part of initial evaluation, resting ECG is recommended for all patients. No further testing is required for patients with a normal initial evaluation, including unremarkable history and normal physical examination, absence of cardiac disease or any other significant comorbidities and a normal baseline ECG.

Other options:

Tilt-table testing is not required unless the vasovagal syncope is suspected where the diagnosis is unclear after initial evaluation, or if syncope is recurrent. In the above patient, this was her first syncopal attack, and her general physical examination findings were all normal.

Increased salt intake and volume replacement are unnecessary unless symptoms are recurrent.

Use of β-blocker therapy in most patients with neurocardiogenic syncope is not associated with a decrease in symptoms and is not routinely recommended, even for patients with recurrent episodes.

questions.text:
Theme and focus: Placental abnormalities

Lead in the question: For each of the following case scenarios described below, select the type of abnormal placenta from the given answer option list.

    1. Placenta accreta
    2. Placenta previa
    3. Vasa previa
    4. Membranous placenta
    5. Fenestrated placenta
    6. Succenturiate placenta
questions.solution:
The correct answers are as follows: Case 1: a) Placenta accreta Case 2: f) Succenturiate placenta Case 3: b) Placenta previa

Case 1: Placenta accreta is a condition in which the placenta is anchored to the uterine myometrium. As a result, it cannot be easily separated and even though a portion of the placenta may be removed, the other parts may still remain attached, causing hemorrhage.

 

Case 2: Succenturiate placenta is a condition that is characterized by the presence of small accessory placental lobes that develop in the membranes at a distance separated from the main placenta. After the delivery, these accessory placental lobes may be retained and cause uterine atony and postpartum hemorrhage.

Case 3: Placenta previa is a condition in which the placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment very near or over the internal os. The patient presents with sudden painless hemorrhage in the antepartum period. The bleeding is caused due to the tearing of the placental attachments at the time of the formation of the lower uterine segment or with cervical dilation.

The factors increasing the risk of placenta previa include previous cesarean section, multiparity, Increased maternal age (> 35 years), prior curettage and maternal smoking.

 

Other options:

  • Vasa Previa occurs when there is a velamentous insertion of the cord and the fetal vessels in the membranes are located ahead of the presenting part.
  • The fenestrated placenta is a condition where the central portion of the placenta is missing.
  • The membranaceous placenta is a condition where all the fetal membranes are covered by villi, and the placenta develops as a thin membranous structure.

questions.text:
Theme and focus: Jaundice

Lead in question: For each of the following case scenarios, pick the appropriate cause of jaundice from the above answer option list.

  1. Cholestatic jaundice
  2. Hepatitis A
  3. Criggler najjar syndrome
  4. Hemolytic jaundice
  5. Gilbert’s syndrome
  6. Chronic hepatitis
  7. Hepatitis B
  8. Primary biliary cholangitis
questions.solution:
Case 1: Elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin which are further increased after a 48-hrs of fasting is diagnostic of Gilbert’s syndrome. It is an inherited metabolic disorder resulting in increased unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The disease occurs due to a decrease in uridine diphosphate (UDP) glucuronyl transferase. Patients usually have episodes of jaundice that are triggered by stress such as acute illness, fasting, or exercise. The condition does not require treatment.

 

Case 2: The clinical features and the presence of high levels of alkaline phosphatase and bilirubin, and antimitochondrial antibodies are all suggestive of primary biliary cholangitis. It is a progressive non-suppurative cholangiohepatitis, with the destruction of small interlobular bile ducts. The term “primary biliary cholangitis” has replaced “primary biliary cirrhosis” because many patients do not have cirrhosis. The disease is common in women aged 40-60 years.

The patients present with fatigue, pruritus. Examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. In late stages, jaundice, steatorrhoea and portal hypertension findings may be seen.

Laboratory findings reveal normal blood counts, elevated alkaline phosphatase, cholesterol (especially HDL), and bilirubin. Antimitochondrial antibodies are present in 95% of patients, and serum IgM levels are elevated.

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following phases of the hair cycle starting with the phase corresponding to hair growth:
  1. Catagen
  2. Anagen
  3. Telogen
  4. Kenogen
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of hair growth is Anagen, Catagen, Telogen, and Kenogen. 

The hair cycle is a repetitive sequence of growing and resting phases of hair follicles. Anagen is the active period of hair growth. The duration of this phase determines the final length of the hair.

Epithelial cell division declines and ceases at the end of the anagen phase and hair follicles enter into an involutiontary phase called catagen. The proximal end of the hair shaft keratinizes to form a club-shaped structure and the lower part of the follicle is involuted by apoptosis during this phase.

The telogen phase is the time gap between the completion of follicular regression and the onset of the next anagen phase.

The shedding of club hair occurs through an active process termed as exogen.

In the human scalp, kenogen indicates the interval in which the hair follicle remains empty after the telogen hair has been shed and before a new anagen hair emerges.

Related Pearl: Hair Cycle

Hair follicles undergo a repetitive sequence of growth and the rest is known as the hair cycle. Hair Cycle is usually described under three phases: Anagen, Catagen, and Telogen.

1. Anagen

  • The period of active hair growth is known as anagen and the duration of this phase is responsible for determining the final length of the hair.
  • The entry of a resting hair follicle into anagen is heralded by the onset of mitotic activity in epithelial cells overlying the dermal papilla at the base of the follicle (the secondary epithelial germ).
  • Under normal circumstances, 80–90% of hair follicles on the human scalp are in anagen at any one time.
  • Anagen can continue for several years.

Fig 1. Scalp hair follicle in the anagen II stage of development

Fig 2.  Anagen hair bulb. Co, hair cortex; Cu, hair cuticle; DP, dermal papilla; DS, dermal sheath; He, Henle layer; HM, hair matrix; Hu, Huxley layer; IRSCu, inner root sheath cuticle; Me, melanocyte; ORS, outer root sheath

2. Catagen

  • At the end of anagen, epithelial cell division declines and ceases, and the follicle enters an involutionary phase known as catagen.
  • During catagen, the proximal end of the hair shaft keratinizes to form a club-shaped structure and the lower part of the follicle involutes by apoptosis.
  • The basement membrane surrounding the follicle becomes thickened and corrugated to form the ‘glassy membrane’.
  • It lasts for about 10 days.

Fig 3.  Human hair follicle in mid-catagen. There is a prominent glassy membrane surrounding the regressing epithelial column. The dermal papilla is rounded and condensed. 

3. Telogen

  • It is the time period between catagen and the next anagen.
  • It lasts for about 3 months.
  • Club hair is eventually shed through an active process called exogen.
  • In the human scalp, hair follicles may remain in a state of latency, also known as kenogen, for a pro­longed period after the club hair is shed.

questions.text: True about the device given below is:

choices.text: Holding period of 160 degree Celsius for 2 hours
Spores of Clostridium tetani act as control

questions.solution:
The above image shows the autoclave machine. It is a method of sterilization by moist heat.

Autoclave machine:

  • High penetrative power
  • Temperature - 1210C for 15 min
  • Spores of Bacillus stearothermophilus acts as a control.

 Hot air oven:

It is a method of sterilization by dry heat.

  • Holding period of 1600C for 2 hours is used to sterilize glassware, swabs, glass syringes, scalpel, forceps, scissors.
  • Cutting instruments in ophthalmic surgery – 2 hours at 1500C.
  • Spores of Clostridium tetani act as a control.

questions.text:
Identify the true statements regarding keratostylohyoidal syndrome.
  1. More common in females
  2. Classically seen in post-tonsillectomy patients
  3. Usually unilateral
  4. Palpable mass/bulge may be present in the tonsillar fossa
  5. Pain is exacerbated by rotation of the head
questions.solution:
Eagle syndrome, which is also known as keratostylohyoidal syndrome is usually bilateral, not unilateral.

Eagle syndrome:

Also called the kerato-stylohyoidal syndrome is characterized by an elongated styloid process or calcified stylohyoid ligament.

Etiology: Usually, this condition is seen post-tonsillectomy or post pharyngeal trauma. It is more common in Females (3:1).

Clinical Presentation:

  • Commonly bilateral
  • Presentation 1: Classic Eagle syndrome
    • Dull and persistent pharyngeal pain often referred to the ear.
    • Pain exacerbated by rotation of the head.
    • A palpable mass or a bulge in the tonsillar fossa.
    • Other associated symptoms like dysphagia, foreign body sensation, tinnitus and cervicofacial pain may be seen.
  • Presentation 2: Stylocarotid syndrome
    • Compression of the internal or external carotid artery by medially or laterally rotated styloid process.

Treatment: Styloidectomy in those not responding to conservative treatment with analgesics.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in red color, in the image below:
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above image is sigmoid sulcus.

  • The sigmoid sulcus is a wide groove, present anteriorly, in the mastoid part of the temporal bone.
  • It contains the sigmoid sinus.
  • Superiorly the sigmoid sulcus is continuous with the transverse sulcus.
  • Inferiorly, it crosses the occipitomastoid suture and grooves the jugular process of the occipital bone.

Other options:

Option a:  Pre-chiasmatic sulcus (also called chiasmatic groove or optic groove) is a transverse groove in the sphenoid bone, between the optic canals. The optic chiasma lies over the pre-chiasmatic sulcus.

Option c: Carotid sulcus is a shallow groove in the lateral wall of the body of the sphenoid. It contains the internal carotid artery.

Option d: Transverse sulcus is the groove for transverse sinus in the occipital bone, as shown below.

questions.text:
The virulence factors of Candida albicans include:
  1. Polysaccharide capsule
  2. Phospholipase
  3. Phenol oxidase
  4. Secreted aspartyl proteinase
questions.solution:
Phospholipase (PLB1) and secreted aspartyl proteinases (SAP) are virulence factors of candida albicans, while the polysaccharide capsule and laccase (phenol oxidase) are the virulence factors of cryptococcus neoformans.

Virulence factors of candida species:

  • Agglutinin-like sequence (ALS) surface glycoproteins bind to the host cell membrane receptors and mediate attachment to the epithelial and endothelial cells.
  • Secreted aspartyl proteinases (SAPs) degrade host cell membranes and destroy immunoglobulins.
  • Phospholipase (PLB1) secreted by the yeasts and pseudohyphae.
  • Fungal biofilm, which is protected by the extracellular matrix material prevents the penetration of the host’s immune response and antifungal drugs.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.solution:
Galectin 10, is an eosinophilic protein that forms needle-like Charcot Leyden crystals, seen in bronchial asthma.

  • Creola Bodies are clusters of ciliated columnar cells that slough off from the Bronchial mucosa of a patient with asthma.
  • Schauman Bodies are large basophilic concentric calcifications formed within the cytoplasm of giant cells.

questions.text: The cardiovascular adverse effects that is (are) associated with SGLT2 inhibitors:

choices.text: Mild hypertension when used in young patients
Mild hypotension when used in elderly
Increased risk for major cardiovascular events

questions.solution:
The use of SGLT2 inhibitors is associated with mild hypotension in the elderly.

Urine glucose losses cause mild diuresis, which can lead to hypotension and associated symptoms in a small percentage of older patients.

Trials indicate that empagliflozin and canagliflozin reduce the risk of major cardiovascular events. Other side effects associated with SGLT 2 inhibitors are lower urinary tract infections, genital mycotic infections & increase the risk of fractures that may cause hypoglycemia if used with hypoglycemic agents.

Related Pearl: Cut-off points in diagnostic tests

  • Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
  • Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Sensitivity (True-positive rate): High sensitivity indicates low false-negative rate.

Specificity (True-negative rate): High specificity indicates low false-positive rate.

questions.text:
Which of the following are part of CASPAR criteria?
  1. Personal history of psoriasis
  2. Presence of typical psoriatic nail dystrophy
  3. Positive test result for rheumatoid factor
  4. History of dactylitis
  5. Juxta-articular new bone formation in the foot seen radiographically
questions.solution:
A negative test for the rheumatoid factor is included in the CASPAR (Classification of Psoriatic Arthritis) criteria used for diagnosing psoriatic arthritis, not a positive test. 

Psoriatic arthritis is a seronegative inflammatory arthritis that is destructive to the joints, associated with moderate to severe psoriasis. It usually develops before 40 years of age.

A diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis can be made from the Classification Criteria for Psoriatic Arthritis (CASPAR) criteria, if there is an inflammatory articular disease of a joint, enthesis or spine, along with >=3 of the following criteria:

  1. Current or history of psoriasis/ family history of psoriasis
  2. Typical psoriatic nail involvement
  3. Rheumatoid factor negative
  4. Current or history of dactylitis
  5. Radiological evidence of juxta-articular new bone formation
 
Given below is an X-ray showing the 'pencil-in-cup' appearance of the metacarpophalangeal joints

Wright & Moll Classification of Psoriatic Arthritis

  • Arthritis of the DIP joints
  • Asymmetric oligoarthritis
  • Symmetric polyarthritis
  • Axial involvement such as spine and sacroiliac joints
  • Arthritis mutilans, a destructive form of arthritis

Psoriatic arthritis should be managed by a rheumatologist. Early treatment and interventions are necessary to prevent irreversible joint damage. The Group for Research and Assessment of Psoriasis and Psoriatic Arthritis (GRAPPA) management guidelines for psoriatic arthritis states the use of the following drugs in:

  • Peripheral arthritis: NSAIDs/ steroid injection/ Systemic treatments - methotrexate, cyclosporin/ biologicals
  • Dactylitis: NSAIDs/ Steroid injection
  • Axial disease / Enthesitis: NSAIDs / Physiotherapy / Biologicals

Newer drugs approved for the treatment of Psoriatic arthritis include:

Class of drug Drugs
Anti-TNF α

- Infliximab (only iv drug, rest all are s/c)
- Etanercept 
- Adalimumab 
- Golimumab
- Certolizumab
Anti-IL-17 - Secukinumab 
Anti-IL-23 - Ustekinumab 

Related Pearl: Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

I. In Mild Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • Coal tar
  • Dithranol
  • Potent topical steroid
  • Vitamin D analogue

Second line

  • Local NB-UVB or PUVA
  • Excimer laser

II. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • NB-UVB or PUVA

Second line

  • Acitretin
  • Apremilast
  • Ciclosporin
  • Fumaric acid esters (where available)
  • Methotrexate

Third line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Secukinumab
  • Ustekinumab

III. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis with Psoriatic Arthritis

First line

  • Apremilast
  • Methotrexate

Second line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Ustekinumab

Third line

  • Combination therapy

Related Pearl: Types of Psoriatic Arthritis

Types of Psoriatic Arthritis - Mnemonic

“SODA”

S  —  Symmetrical Polyarthritis

         Spondylitis/Sacroiliits

O —  Oligoarticular Asymmetrical 

D —  DIP(Distal Interphalangeal/Classic Type)

A —  Arthritis Mutilans

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

questions.text: The incorrect statement regarding the planned targets for NVBDCP is:

choices.text: Eliminate malaria from all low and moderate transmission states by 2022
Reduce the incidence of malaria to less than 2 cases per 1000 population per year by 2024
Interrupt indigenous transmission of malaria throughout the entire country by 2027
Prevent the re-establishment of local transmission and maintain national malaria-free status by 2030

questions.solution:
According to the National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016), the planned target is to reduce the incidence of malaria to less than 1(not 2) case per 1000 population per year by 2024.

The Framework has four objectives:

  • Eliminate malaria from all low and moderate transmission states/union territories (UTs) by 2022;
  • Reduce the incidence of malaria to less than 1 case per 1000 population per year in all states and UTs and their districts by 2024;
  • Interrupt indigenous transmission of malaria throughout the entire country, including all high transmission states and union territories (UTs) by 2027
  • Prevent the re-establishment of local transmission of malaria in areas where it has been eliminated and maintain national malaria-free status by 2030 and beyond.

questions.text: Long term use of combined oral contraceptive pill is helpful in all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
Combined oral contraceptives do not  provide protection against breakthrough bleeding. Breakthrough bleeding is an adverse effect of COCs.

Non-contraceptive benefits of combined oral contraceptives COCs include:

A. Improvement of menstrual abnormalities such as:

  • Menorrhagia
  • Dysmenorrhoea
  • Premenstrual tension syndrome (PMS)
  • Mittelschmerz syndrome

B. Protection against health disorders

  • Iron-deficiency anemia
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Endometriosis
  • Fibroid uterus
  • Hirsutism and acne
  • Functional ovarian cysts
  • Benign breast disease
  • Osteopenia and postmenopausal osteoporotic fractures
  • Autoimmune disorders of thyroid
  • Rheumatoid arthritis

C. Prevention of malignancies

  • Endometrial cancer
  • Epithelial ovarian cancer
  • Colorectal cancer

questions.text:
Uni parental Disomy can lead to:

A. Angelman Syndrome

B. Russel Silver Syndrome

C. Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome

D. WAGR syndrome

E. Dennys Drash Syndrome
questions.solution:
Angelman syndrome, Russel silver syndrome, and Beckwith-Wiedmann syndrome can be caused by uniparental disomy.

  • Angelman syndrome can also result from the uniparental disomy of paternal chromosome 15. Similarly, Prader-Willi syndrome can result from the uniparental disomy of maternal chromosome 15.
  • Russel silver syndrome is a growth disorder characterized by slow growth before and after birth. Low birth weight and failure to thrive are often associated. Parent-specific differences in gene expression are caused due to genomic imprinting. Hence, Uniparental disomy can cause it. Genes in chromosomes 7 and 11 are involved in this.
  • Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (BWS) is used as a model for the nonclassical mechanism of tumorigenesis in humans that occurs via genomic imprinting. Though multiple WT2 region genes are associated with the tumorigenesis in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, IGF2 gene abnormalities have the strongest correlation to the development of Tumors. Loss of maternal imprinting of IGF2 and Uniparental paternal disomy of IGF2 are 2 pathways that can cause overexpression of IGF2 thus leading to tumorigenesis.

Other options:

  • WAGR syndrome is associated with germline deletions of 11p13.
  • In Denys-Drash syndrome the genetic abnormality is a dominant-negative missense mutation in the zinc-finger region of the WT1 protein that affects its DNA-binding properties.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Associations of Wilms Tumor

Syndrome Mutation Features
WAGR Syndrome
  • WT1 and PAX6 deletion on Chr11p
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Wilms tumor
  • Aniridia
  • Genital anomalies
  • Mental retardation
Denys–Drash Syndrome
  • Dominant-negative missense mutation of WT1 protein
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Gonadal dysgenesis (male pseudo hermaphroditism)
  • Early-onset nephropathy
  • Gonadoblastoma
Beckwith– Wiedemann Syndrome
  • IGF-2 overexpression onWT2 region
  • Genetic basis- genomic imprinting
  • Organomegaly
  • Macroglossia
  • Hemihypertrophy
  • Omphalocele
  • Adrenal cytomegaly
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Pancreato-blastoma
  • Adrenocortical tumors
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

Note: Wilms tumor 1 (WT1) protein is a transcriptional activator of genes involved in normal renal and gonadal development. Therefore, genitourinary abnormalities are commonly associated with WT1 gene mutations.

questions.text: Which cytokine activates macrophages via the classical pathway?
questions.solution:
IFN-Ɣ activates macrophages via the classical pathway.

Macrophages are involved in chronic inflammatory reactions, where they secrete cytokines and growth factors that eliminate microbes and damaged tissues and activate T lymphocytes. They are also involved in tissue repair. Macrophages are activated via two pathways:

  • Classical pathway: In this pathway, macrophages are activated by cytokine IFN-Ɣ secreted by Th1 cells, microbial products (endotoxin), T cell-derived signals, or foreign substances. These macrophages play an important role in host defense and inflammatory reactions. 
  • Alternate pathway: In this pathway, macrophages are activated by cytokines like IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 (options B & C) secreted by Th2 cells. These macrophages are primarily involved in tissue repair. 

T-lymphocytes and macrophages show a bidirectional interaction, where lymphocytes produce cytokines that activate macrophages and activated macrophages produce cytokines to stimulate T-lymphocyte responses.

Other options:

Option D: IL-17 is produced by Th17 cells and secrete chemokines responsible for neutrophil recruitment.

Related Pearl: T Helper cells- Types and functions

Cell Type

T helper cell 1

T helper 2

T helper 17

Major cytokines produced

IFN-γ

IL-4, IL-5, IL-13

IL-17, IL-22

Cytokines that induce this subset

IFN-γ, IL-12

IL-4

TGF-β, IL-6, IL-1, IL-23

Immunological reactions triggered

Macrophage activation, stimulation of IgG antibody production

Stimulation of IgE production, activation of mast cells and eosinophils

Recruitment of neutrophils, monocytes

Host defense against

Intracellular microbes

Helminthic parasites

Extracellular bacteria, fungi

Role in disease

Autoimmune and other chronic inflammatory diseases (such as IBD, psoriasis, granulomatous inflammation)

Allergies

Autoimmune and other chronic inflammatory diseases (such as IBD, psoriasis, MS)

 

Related Pearl: Cytokines

Interleukins Main sources

IL-2 T cells
IL-3 T cells
IL-4 TH cells
IL-5 TH cells
IL-6 TH, macrophages, fibroblasts
IL-8 Macrophages, others
IL-10 T, B cells, macrophages

Pro-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-1: induces inﬂammation, fever, and sepsis, activates TNF-α; proliferation and differentiation of T, B, and other cells; bone marrow cell proliferation
  • IL-2: promote growth and differentiation of T and B cells; cytotoxicity of T and NK cells; secretion of other lymphokines
  • IL-6: promote B cell stimulation & differentiation; mediator of acute phase reactions; IgG production
  • IL-8: attracts and activates neutrophils in inflammatory regions; neutrophil chemotaxis
  • IFN-α: antiviral, immunoregulatory (enhance MHC class I, NK-cell activity), antiproliferative
  • TNF-α: activate macrophages and cytotoxic cells, induce cachexia, acute phase proteins, cytokines such as IL-1 and IL-6

Anti-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-4: proliferation of B and cytotoxic cells; increases IgG1 and IgE production; enhances MHC-class II receptor
  • IL-10: inhibits IFN-γ and IL-12 production; inhibits IFN production and mononuclear cell functions
  • IL-13

Acute inflammation and sepsis: 

  • TNF-α
  • IL-1

Special Cytokines: 

  1. IFN-γ: 
    • Granuloma formation
    • Antiviral
    • Immunoregulatory (enhances MHC classes I and II and macrophage activation)
    • Antiproliferative
  2. TGF-β: 
    • Fibrosis 
    • Activate macrophages
  3. VEGF:
    • promotes angiogenesis

questions.text:
Starting from the lateral geniculate body to the facial area of the motor cortex, arrange the following parts of the brain in the sequence through which an impulse would travel when a person identifies a visual object and names the object out loud.

1.     Primary visual cortex

2.     Broca area

3.     Arcuate fasciculus

4.     Higher order visual cortical areas

5.     Wernicke area

6.     Angular gyrus
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of parts through which the impulse would travel is b) 1-4-6-5-3-2.

When a person looks at an object (ex.apple), the visual information travels through various parts of the brain responsible for identification and comprehension of the name of the object, until it finally reaches the motor cortex responsible for the movement of facial and laryngeal muscles causing the person to speak out loud.

The pathway along which such impulse would travel is detailed below:

  • The visual information from the lateral geniculate body reaches the primary visual cortex (area 17).
  • The impulse then travels to the higher-order visual cortical areas (area 18) and then to the angular gyrus (area 39).
  • From the angular gyrus, the impulse reaches the Wernicke area (area 22). The angular gyrus, which is located behind the Wernicke area,  is responsible for the processing of the visual information such that it can be converted into an auditory form of the word that can be processed by the Wernicke area.
  • The Wernicke's area is a region at the posterior end of the superior temporal gyrus. It is concerned with the comprehension of both auditory and visual information.
  • The impulse from the Wernicke's area travels through the arcuate fasciculus to the Broca area, which is a region in the frontal lobe immediately in front of the inferior end of the motor cortex.
  • The Broca area processes the information which is received from the Wernicke area into a detailed and coordinated pattern for vocalization.
  • This information processed by the Broca area reaches the speech articulation area in the insula and the motor cortex, which then initiates the movements of the lips, tongue, and larynx required to produce speech.

Related Pearl: Brodmann areas

Area of the Brain(Brodmann) Location
3, 1 and 2 - Primary sensory area

Postcentral gyrus

Extends to the posterior part of the paracentral lobule medially
4 - Primary motor area

Extends to the anterior part of the paracentral lobule medially

Anterior to Area 4

In the posterior parts of superior, middle and inferior frontal gyri
5 and 7 - Sensory association area Superior parietal lobule
8 - Frontal eye field Posterior part of middle frontal gyrus, anterior to the facial area of the precentral gyrus
44 and 45 - Broca’s(Motor speech) area Inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere

41 and 42 - 

Primary auditory area

 Superior surface of the superior temporal gyrus(Heschl’s gyrus)
22* - Wernicke’s(Sensory speech) area Superior temporal gyrus
17 - Primary visual(striate) area Walls and floor of the posterior part of calcarine sulcus (postcalcarine sulcus) in the occipital lobe

18 and 19- 

Visual association area

 Remaining part of the medial and superolateral surfaces of the occipital lobe
28 - Primary olfactory area Anterior part of the parahippocampal gyrus and uncus
43 - Gustatory(taste) area Inferior part of the parietal lobe, posterior to the general sensory area of the mouth

*There is uncertainty about the extent of the Wernicke's area. Some authorities consider areas 39 and 40 as part of Wernicke's area in addition to area 22.

questions.text: Tonsillectomy can be  performed in:

choices.text: Child with an impaired palatal function

questions.solution:
Diphtheria and streptococcal carriers are relative indications for tonsillectomy

Contraindications for tonsillectomy:

Three general categories of contraindications exist and they are:

  1. Velopharyngeal,
  2. Hematologic
  3. Infectious.
  4. Miscellaneous

1. Velopharyngeal

  • Overt cleft palate
  • Submucous cleft palate
  • Impaired palatal function

2. Hematologic

  • Hemoglobin level less than 10 g%.
  • Bleeding disorders, e.g. leukemia, purpura, aplastic anemia or hemophilia.

3. Infectious

  • Presence of acute infection in the upper respiratory tract, even acute tonsillitis. Bleeding is more in the presence of acute infection.
  • At the time of an epidemic of polio.

4. Miscellaneous

  • Children under 3 years of age. They are poor surgical risks.
  • Uncontrolled systemic disease, e.g. diabetes, cardiac disease, hypertension or asthma.
  • Tonsillectomy is avoided during the period of menses.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman came to the local emergency department with severe headache and stiffness of the neck. The CSF specimen is cloudy. While in the emergency room, an intern performs gram stain of the CSF but by mistake forgets the step in which iodine is added. Assuming that the women has meningitis caused by streptococcus pneumoniae,  how would the bacteria on the intern’s slide appear?

choices.text: No gram stain results would be obtained due to lysis of all cells

questions.solution:
In the above question, the intern forgot to add iodine, i.e., the second step of gram staining. As a result, the purple iodine-dye complex will not form, and the entire crystal violet dye will wash away during the decolorization step. Now when the safranin is added, all the cells will stain red.

The various steps in gram staining are as follows:

  • The crystal violet dye (basic dye) stains all cells purple.
  • The iodine solution (a mordant) is added to form a crystal violet–iodine complex. At the end of this step, all cells continue to appear purple.
  • In the decolorization step, the organic solvent, such as acetone or ethanol, extracts the blue dye complex from the lipid-rich, thin-walled gram-negative bacteria to a greater degree than from the lipid-poor, thick-walled gram-positive bacteria. At the end of this step, the gram-negative organisms appear colorless; the gram-positive bacteria remain purple.
  • The red dye safranin (counterstain) stains the decolorized gram-negative cells red/pink; the gram-positive bacteria remain purple.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: The following patients have presented to the emergency department with complaints of acute dyspnea. All of them had a positive D-dimer result. Which one of these patients requires prompt additional testing for a pulmonary embolism?

choices.text: A 23-year-old woman who is 34 weeks pregnant, G2P1L1, with gestational diabetes mellitus
A 50-year-old man with no past medical history presents with mild calf pain following prolonged air travel
A 54-year-old woman undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer
A 60-year-old man who underwent thyroid surgery 4 weeks previously

questions.solution:
The D-dimer measured by ELISA is elevated in the conditions causing breakdown of fibrin by plasmin.

The presence of a positive D-dimer can indicate the need for additional imaging for DVT and/or pulmonary embolism in specific clinical situations where the patient would be considered to have an elevation in D-dimer. However, D-dimer may be elevated in the presence of other comorbid conditions.

Some common clinical situations in which the D- dimer is elevated include sepsis, myocardial infarction, cancer, pneumonia, the postoperative state, and the second and third trimesters of pregnancy.

Of the scenarios listed in the question, the only patient D-dimer test is useful would be the patient with calf pain and recent air travel. If the d-dimer is high, imaging test is needed. In patients where there is a high clinical suspicion of DVT as in those complaining cramping calf pain over several days after prolonged immobilisation, the d-dimer test may be omitted and the imaging test may be performed directly.

In all the other scenarios, elevations in D-dimer could be related to other medical conditions and provide no diagnostic information to inform the clinician regarding the need for further evaluation.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Venous Thromboembolism

The risk factors for venous thromboembolism (pulmonary embolism and DVT) are as follows:

  • Major trauma like spinal cord injury or fracture of lower limb
  • Surgery like hip or knee replacement
  • Hospitalization for heart failure or atrial fibrillation/flutter within last 3 months
  • Myocardial infarction within last 3 months
  • Previous venous thromboembolism
  • Infections and inflammatory bowel disease
  • Autoimmune diseases:
    • Antiphospholipid antibody (APLA)
    • SLE
  • Inherited thrombophilias:
    • Factor V leiden mutation
    • Deficiency of antithrombin III
    • Deficiency of protein C or protein S
  • Hypercoagulable states:
    • Pregnancy and postpartum period
    • COPD
    • Nephrotic syndrome
    • Polycythemia vera
    • Malignancies
  • Iatrogenic:
    • OCPs
    • Hormone replacement therapy
    • Chemotherapeutic drugs
    • Insertion of central venous lines
  • Varicose veins
  • Prolonged car or air travel.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

Related Pearl: Investigation of Choice in Respiratory Diseases

Disease Investigation of choice
Interstitial lung disease HRCT
Bronchiectasis HRCT
Pulmonary embolism CT Pulmonary Angiography > Ventilation-Perfusion Scan
Calcification CT
Solitary pulmonary nodule CT > PET
Lung Malignancy CT scan
Superior sulcus tumor MRI scan > CT scan

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with medullary thyroid carcinoma. Which of the following could be used to screen the rest of her family?
questions.solution:
Screening of patients with familial MTC was historically done using pentagastrin stimulation test for calcitonin levels to make the diagnosis. 

Pentagastrin is a synthetic gastrin analogue. It acts on the CCK-B/gastrin receptor of the C cells and increases the basal rate of calcitonin secretion.

Basal calcitonin level = total C cell mass x rate of secretion.

Medullary thyroid tumors secrete calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), but also other peptides such as calcitonin gene-related peptide, histaminadases, prostaglandins E2 and F2α, and serotonin.

Another test that can be used for screening is calcium-stimulated calcitonin levels.

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text:
Elevation in which of the following laboratory studies would be indicative of liver disease?
1.	5′-Nucleotidase
2.	Aspartate aminotransferase
3.	Unconjugated bilirubin
questions.solution:
Isolated elevation in the unconjugated form of bilirubin is typically not related to liver disease but is most commonly seen in hemolysis and a number of benign genetic conditions such as Gilbert syndrome. In contrast, conjugated hyperbilirubinemia almost always indicates disease of the liver or biliary tract.

Alanine and aspartate aminotransferases are the primary enzymes that indicate hepatocyte injury.

 5′- nucleotidase and γ-glutamyl transferase are elevated in cholestatic liver disease.

CK-MB Heart and skeletal muscle, Myocardial Infarction, Muscular dystrophy
