questions.text: A 53-year-old postmenopausal woman came to the OPD with complaint of urinary leakage since 6 weeks. Which of the following is the most appropriate first step in this patient’s evaluation for incontinence?
questions.solution:
In all women who present with urinary incontinence, urinalysis and culture should be done first in order to exclude any urinary tract infection. In patients diagnosed with UTI, treatment should be initiated and then the patient should be reevaluated.

Further evaluation for incontinence is done if UTI is excluded or if the incontinence persists despite appropriate antibiotic therapy. Postvoid residual volume and urodynamic studies may be performed.

questions.text: A baby assessed at 5 minutes after birth, had HR - 120 with a slow, irregular respiratory effort. There is some flexion of extremities, grimace and cyanotic limbs with a pink body. The APGAR score would be:
questions.solution:
The APGAR score will be 6.

2 - HR - 120

1 - a slow, irregular respiratory effort.

1 - Some flexion of extremities

1 - Grimace

1 - Cyanotic limbs with a pink body

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text:
Assertion: Metastatic calcification is usually found in the interstitial tissue of gastric mucosa, kidneys, lungs, systemic arteries, and pulmonary veins.
Reason: Gastric mucosa, kidneys, lungs, systemic arteries, and pulmonary veins have an internal acidic compartment that predisposes them to metastatic calcification.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both the assertion and reason are true statements but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false statement
Assertion is false but the reason is true statement
Both assertion and reason are false statement

questions.solution:
Metastatic calcification occurs usually in the interstitial tissue of gastric mucosa, kidneys, lungs, systemic arteries, and pulmonary veins. But the reason for that is as follows:

Although quite different in location, all of these tissues have a similarity in that they excrete acid and therefore have an internal alkaline compartment that predisposes them to metastatic calcification. Interestingly, in all these sites, the calcium salts morphologically resemble the deposition pattern described in dystrophic calcification, i.e they may occur as noncrystalline amorphous deposits or, at other times, as hydroxyapatite crystals.

questions.text:
The sign shown in the image below is seen in which of the following conditions?
  1. Drowning
  2. Bacterial meningitis
  3. Birth asphyxia
  4. Encephalitis
questions.solution:
The above CT scan image shows a reversal sign or white cerebellum sign or dense cerebellum sign. It is seen in conditions causing a diffuse decrease in density of the supratentorial brain parenchyma, with a relative increase in attenuation of the thalami, brainstem, and cerebellum.  It indicates irreversible brain damage and is associated with poor prognosis.

The reversal sign is seen in the following conditions:

  • Drowning
  • Bacterial meningitis
  • Birth asphyxia
  • Encephalitis
  • Severe head injury
  • Status epilepticus

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is being assessed for developmental delay. She plays cooperatively in a group, and goes to the toilet alone, but is unable to dress or undress by herself. She tells stories and builds bridges with blocks but hasn’t built a gate with blocks yet. Also, the mother confirms the child hasn’t yet started asking for the meaning of words. What is her developmental quotient?
questions.solution:
The developmental age of the child corresponds to 4 years and the developmental quotient would, therefore, be 57.

The child meets the following milestones corresponding to 4 years:

  • Plays cooperatively in a group
  • Goes to the toilet alone
  • Tells stories
  • Builds bridges with blocks

The child does not meet the following developmental milestones corresponding to 5 years:

  • Dress or undress herself
  • Built a gate with blocks
  • Asking for the meaning of words

So, the developmental age of the child corresponds to 4 years.

DQ = Developmental age x 100⁄Chronological age

DQ = 4/7x100 = 57.14~57

questions.text:
Which of the following are used for performing a personality test on a person?
  1. Minnesota multiphasic personality inventory test
  2. Rorschach inkblot test
  3. Thematic apperception test
  4. Bender Gestalt test
  5. Sentence completion test
questions.solution:
Minnesota multiphasic personality inventory test, Rorschach inkblot test, Thematic apperception test, and  Sentence completion test are all personality tests.

  • Bender Gestalt test is a neuropsychological test, not a personality test. The test involves copying geometric figures. It is used for assessing the visuospatial function of the patient.
  • Minnesota multiphasic personality inventory test - MMPI - It is an objective personality test. It contains true or false type questions on a variety of issues.

The following are projective personality assessment tests:

  • Rorschach inkblot test - Here the patient is asked to interpret his perception of a pattern formed on paper/card by an inkblot, and psychological interpretation is made.
  • Thematic apperception test - It is a projective psychological test where the patient is given ambiguous test material. Personality assessment is made based upon the interpretation of an artistic image by the patient.
  • Sentence completion test - It is a semistructured projective technique where the patient is asked to complete a sentence in meaningful ways, which can be used for assessment.

Related Pearl: Neuropsychological tests

The neuropsychiatric evaluation combines information from neurological, neuropsychological testing, and mental status examinations.

The following are some common neuropsychological screening tests and test batteries: 

  • Wisconsin card sorting test
  • Wechsler memory scale
  • PGI memory scale
  • Bender Gestalt test or BG test
  • Benton visual retention test or BVRT
  • Luria-Nebraska neuropsychological battery
  • Halstead-Reitan neuropsychological test battery

Related Pearl: Personality tests

Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI-2)

Uses Characteristics

The most commonly used objective personality test.

Useful for primary care physicians because no training is required for administration and scoring 

Evaluating the attitude of the patient toward taking the test

Objective test

Patients answer 567 true(T) or false(F) questions about themselves.

Clinical scales include depression, paranoia, schizophrenia, and hypochondriasis.

Validity scales identify trying to look ill (faking bad or malingering) or trying to look well (faking good) 

 

Rorschach Test

Uses Characteristics

The most commonly used projective personality test. 

Used to identify thought disorders and defense mechanisms

Projective test 

Patients are asked to interpret 10 bilaterally symmetrical inkblot designs (e.g., Describe what you see in this figure)

 

 

Thematic Apperception Test (TAT)

Uses Characteristics

Stories are used to evaluate unconscious emotions and conflicts

Projective test

Patients are asked to create a verbal scenario based on 20 drawings depicting ambiguous situations (e.g., Using the picture, make up a story that has a beginning, a middle, and an end)

The image given below is the first card, drawn by Christiana D. Morgan. It is a recreation of a photograph taken by Samuel Lumiere of violinist, Yehudi Menuhin, in 1928.

Used to identify worries and problems using verbal associations

Projective test

Patients complete sentences started by the examiner

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presented with back pain radiating to the leg after lifting a heavy suitcase. There is sensory loss over the anterolateral aspect of the ​leg, dorsum of the foot, and great toe. The medial hamstring reflex is diminished. The knee and ankle jerks are normal. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this case scenario is L4-L5 disc prolapse.

The points given in the question in favor of this diagnosis are back pain radiating to the leg, sensory loss over the anterolateral aspect of the ​leg, dorsum of the foot, great toe, diminished medial hamstring reflex, and normal ankle jerk. 

The prolapsed intervertebral disc (PIVD) usually presents in adults between 20 to 40 years. The most common symptom is low back pain. It can be associated with or without pain radiating down the back of the leg (sciatica). 

Neurological features of L4-L5 PIVD are: 

  • Weakness of extensor hallucis longus and dorsiflexor muscles of the foot
  • Sensory loss over the anterolateral aspect of knee and leg, dorsum of the foot, and the great toe. One or more adjacent toes may also be involved (i.e., 1st web space) but never the little toe
  • Diminished medial hamstring reflex
  • Knee jerk and ankle jerk are normal.

Tests for diagnosis:

1. Straight Leg Raising Test (SLRT): 

This test is done to assess nerve root irritation in the lumbosacral area. The patient is made to lie on the back with the head extended, with hips and legs in a neutral position. Affected leg passively and slowly raised by the ankle with the knee fully extended. SLRT test negative if the leg can be raised 80–90 degrees without pain. SLRT test positive if pain elicited between 30-60 or 70 degrees from horizontal. Lasègue's test is a modified SLRT where the knee is bent to 90 degrees. 

2. Crossed straight-leg test: 

SLRT on the unaffected side. Pain felt on the affected side and is termed as contralateral positive SLRT or crossed SLRT positive. It is often highly specific for a large central prolapse. 

3. Bowstring sign or popliteal compression test: 

This test is more specific for disc prolapse than SLRT. It is performed by eliciting SLRT until the patient experiences sciatic pain. Now without reducing the amount of lift, the knee is bent to relax the sciatic nerve. The pain in the buttocks is immediately relieved. Following this, the popliteal fossa is pressed to stretch the lateral popliteal nerve behind the lateral tibial condyle. Tightening of the nerve like a bowstring re-induces the pain. 

MRI is the investigation of choice.

Treatment:

  • Bed rest, heat, ice, NSAIDs, muscle relaxants and/or spinal traction are commonly advised
  • Operative removal of the prolapsed disc: 
    • Absolute indication - cauda equina compression syndrome 
    • Relative indications - neurological deterioration, persistent pain and/or failed conservative treatment

questions.text: You notice a baby with Dermatomal cicatrix and atrophy of the affected limb. Which of the following infections in the mother is it characteristically associated with?
questions.solution:
Dermatomal cicatrix with atrophy of the affected limb is characteristically associated with the maternal infection of VZV.

Cicatrix is seen clinically as zigzag scarring, in a dermatomal distribution, and is associated with the atrophy of the affected limb.

Many infants with severe manifestations of congenital varicella syndrome including atrophy and scarring of a limb have significant neurologic deficiencies. In some cases, there may be neither skin nor limb abnormalities but the infant may show cataracts or even extensive aplasia of the entire brain.

questions.text:
Assertion: The mydriatic effect of α adrenergic agonists is slower in onset in humans with darkly pigmented irides compared to those with lightly pigmented irides.
Reason: Drug-melanin binding affects drug redistribution.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both the assertion and reason are true statements but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false statement
Assertion is false but the reason is true statement
Both assertion and reason are false statement

questions.solution:
Melanin binding of drugs is an important factor in some ocular compartments which affects the drug redistribution and consequently its action. The mydriatic effect of α adrenergic agonists is slower in onset in humans with darkly pigmented irides compared to those with lightly pigmented irides;

Another clinically important consideration for drug-melanin binding involves the retinal pigment epithelium. In the retinal pigment epithelium, accumulation of chloroquine causes a toxic retinal lesion known as a “bull’s-eye” maculopathy,

It is interesting to note that drug-melanin binding is a potential reservoir for sustained drug release.

questions.text: A patient was posted for D1 gastrectomy. Which of the following lymph node station is not removed during the surgery?
questions.solution:
The left gastric lymph node station (7) is removed in D2 gastrectomy not, D1.

The surgery for gastric cancer involves the removal of the primary tumor and lymph nodes.

Depending on the extent of lymph node stations removed, the surgery may be either  D1 or D2 gastrectomy.

The lymph node stations are:

  1. Right paracardiac
  2. Left paracardiac
  3. Lesser curvature
  4. Greater curvature
    1. Short gastric
    2. Left gastroepiploic
    3. Right gastroepiploic
  5. Suprapyloric
  6. Infrapyloric
  7. Left gastric artery
  8. a. Anterior hepatic artery
  9. Coeliac axis
  10. Splenic hilum
  11. Splenic artery

 

The D1 gastrectomy involves the removal of lymph node stations 1-6.

The D2 gastrectomy involves the removal of lymph node stations 1-11.

 

 

Related Pearl: Risk factors for carcinoma stomach

Risk factors for carcinoma stomach:

  • Dietary
    • Low fat or protein consumption
    • Consumption of salted meat or fish with high nitrate content
    • High complex carbohydrate consumption
    • Smoking, alcohol consumption
    • Spicy food, high salt diet
    • Lack of fresh fruits and vegetables
    • Dietary anti-oxidant deficiency
  • Genetic and familial
    • E cadherin – hereditary diffuse type of gastric cancer
    • Blood group A
    • FAP
    • Li-Fraumeni syndrome
    • HNPCC
    • BRCA 2 mutation
  • Premalignant lesions
    • Chronic atrophic gastritis
    • Adenomatous polyp (FAP)
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Intestinal metaplasia (H. pylori)
    • Menetrier’s disease
    • Stump carcinoma from stomach remnants in Billroth II GJ or vagotomy GJ
  • Others
    • Low socioeconomic status
    • Male gender
    • Rubber and coal workers
    • EBV infection

Related Pearl: Most common site of gastric malignancies

Most common site of Ca. Stomach : Proximal Stomach (Western countries)

Most common site of Ca. Stomach in Pernicious anaemia :  Fundus

Most common site of diffuse variety of Ca. Stomach : Fundus

Most common site of Gastric lymphoma : Antrum

Most common site of Burkitt’s lymphoma/EBV : Cardia / Body

questions.text: Match the following declarations to their significance.

choices.text: I – A, II – B, III – C, IV – D
I - C, II - D, III - A, IV - B
I – D, II – C, III – A, IV - B
I – B, II – A, III – D, IV - C

questions.solution:
Declaration Significance
Geneva Physician’s dedication to the humanitarian goals of medicine.
Oslo Statement on therapeutic abortion.
Tokyo Guidelines for physicians concerning torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment in relation to detainment or imprisonment.
Helsinki Set of ethical principles directed to the medical community for human experimentation.

Related Pearl: Health-related International Declarations:

  1. Declaration of Alma-Ata (1978): Identified primary health care as the key to the attainment of the goal of Health for All.
  2. Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion (1986): The aim of the conference was to continue to  achieve the objectives of the World Health Organization (WHO) Health for all by the year 2000.

3. Declaration of Oslo (1970): Related to therapeutic abortion.

4. Declaration of Tokyo (1975): Guidelines for medical doctors concerning torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment in relation to detention and imprisonment. (T – Tokyo – Torture)

5. Declaration of Helsinki (1975): Related to human experimentation. (H – Helsinki – Human experimentation)

6. Declaration of Geneva (1948): Most recent amendment was done on October 14, 2017 in Chicago. It gives the modern version of the 2500-year-old Hippocratic Oath which laid down the fundamental principles of medical ethics that any physician should follow.

7. Declaration of Malta (1991, revised in 1992): Related to hunger strikes.

8. Declaration of Lisbon: Related to rights of the patients like right to information, confidentiality, dignity, freedom of choice etc.

9. Declaration of Sydney on human death: It stated that the determination of death “will be based on clinical judgment, supplemented if necessary by a number of diagnostic aids”, emphasising the EEG. Nonetheless, it asserted that “the overall judgment of the physician” could not be replaced by any ancillary test.

The statement also recommended that two or more physicians should make the diagnosis of death when organs were removed for transplantation.

10. Declaration of Istanbul: To address the urgent and growing problems of organ sales, transplant tourism and trafficking in organ donors in the context of the global shortage of organs.

11. Declaration of Taipei: Related to ethical considerations regarding health databases and biobanks.

questions.text:
Assertion: Palpable, enlarged, non-tender gallbladder in patients with mild jaundice is unlikely due to gall stones.
Reason: Courvoisier sign is common in periampullary tumors.

choices.text: Assertion and reason are true, and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is independently true and reason is independently false
Assertion is independently false and reason is independently true
Both assertion and reason are independently false

questions.solution:
The Courvoisier law states that a palpable, enlarged gallbladder (Courvoisier sign) is unlikely due to gallstones because the common bile duct obstruction by gallstones would lead to a shrunken fibrotic gallbladder. So, the GB is not palpable.

The gallbladder is enlarged in conditions causing a slow occlusion as in tumors surrounding the distal common bile duct (Periductal Adenocarcinoma, PDAC), or periampullary tumor.

  • Abdominal X-ray: Useful in 
    • Calcified gall stones
    • Emphysematous cholecystitis
    • Porcelain gallbladder
    • Limey bile
    • Gallstone ileus
  • Radioisotope scans (HIDA/DIDA/DISIDA)
    • Indicated for confirmation of suspected acute cholecystitis
    • Useful in diagnosis of acalculous cholecystopathy

Abbreviations:

  • HIDA: Hepatobiliary IminoDiacetic Acid scan
  • DIDA/DISDA: Di-isopropyl IminoDiacetic Acid - Dynamic Tc99m DIDA Cholescintigraphy

questions.text: A person is posted for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He was placed in a surgical position as shown in the image below. Identify the position.
questions.solution:
The above image shows the reverse Trendelenburg position, where the patient's head is elevated 15-30 degrees higher than the feet.  

It is named so, as the position is reverse of the Trendelenburg position, where the head end is lower and the feet are at a higher level. In laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the patient is placed in a reverse Trendelenburg position slightly turned to the left. This exposes the fundus of the gallbladder which is retracted towards the diaphragm.

The Trendelenburg and reverse Trendelenburg positions are used in surgeries that are required to move the abdominal viscera, such as the small bowel, away from the operative field. Restraints and sideboards are placed to prevent the patient from sliding from the bed.

The below image shows the various surgical positions and the procedure they are used in:

Related Pearl: Eponyms named after Friedrich Trendelenburg

  • Trendelenburg sign: This sign is demonstrated by asking the patient to stand on one limb. When the patient stands on the affected limb, the pelvis severely drops over the swing limb. This is seen in the paralysis of gluteus medius and minimus, dislocated hip, fracture neck of femur
  • Trendelenburg gait: This gait is seen in patients with Trendelenburg sign. The body swings to the opposite side every time when the weight is borne on the same side. 
  • Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's head is lower than his feet (head-down position)
  • Reverse Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's feet are lower than his head (head-up position)
  • Brodie Trendelenburg test: It is a test for presence of incompetent valves in lower limb.

questions.text: The egg shown in the image below belongs to _________
questions.solution:
The above image shows egg packet consisting of eight eggs, characteristic of Dipylidium caninum.

Dipylidium caninum is a common tapeworm of dogs and cats, however, occasionally it may cause infections in humans. It is commonly known by other names such as ‘flea tapeworm’, ‘cucumber tapeworm’, and ‘double-pored tapeworm’.

The gravid proglottids present in the intestines of dogs and cats (definitive hosts) disintegrate and release the egg packets in the feces. Each egg packet consists of about 5 to 15 eggs. The eggs are round to oval and contains an oncosphere that has 6 hooklets.

Dipylidium caninum egg packet containing several eggs.

Dipylidium caninum eggs clumped together in a wet mount. Note the hooklets visible in the some of the eggs.

The eggs may be ingested by the larvae of fleas (intermediate host). As the larvae matures into an adult flea, the onchospheres develop into cysticercoids (infective stage). Infection in humans occurs by accidental ingestion of infected adult fleas.

Other options:

Option a: Diphyllobothrium latum egg

Option c: Hymenolepis diminuta egg

Option d: Paragonimus westermani egg

questions.text: The most important step for disease prevention and control in the post-disaster phase is:
questions.solution:
The most important step for disease prevention & control in the post-disaster phase is the chlorination of all water bodies.

After a disaster (such as a flood), the water bodies are contaminated with sewage and drainage. The mixing of feces in drinking bodies increases the risk of numerous microbial infections. The advisable level of residual chlorine in water bodies after a disaster is, therefore, higher i.e. 0.7-0.9 mg/liter.

Minimum recommended free residual chlorine levels:

Cholera epidemic: 0.5 mg/L

Disaster/ Natural calamities: 0.7 - 0.9 mg/L

In normal conditions, water should have free residual chlorine (FRC) of 0.2 - 0.5 mg/L. However, during a disaster, there is an increased risk of fecal contamination of water sources from sewage systems. Therefore, it is necessary to increase FRC to 0.7 - 0.9 mg/L.

The WHO does not recommend typhoid, cholera or tetanus vaccines for the general population after a disaster. However, healthcare workers are recommended to take these vaccines.

Supply of safe drinking water and proper disposal of excreta are the most practical and effective strategies of preventing diseases, post-disaster.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The above image shows disposable mucus sucker.

It sucks out the mucus from the naso-oropharynx following the delivery of the head of the baby. Suction of oral cavity to be done before that of nose.

The mucus should be sucked prior to the respiratory attempt, else the mucus may enter and block the tracheobronchial tree leading to asphyxia neonatorum.

questions.text: The following X-rays depicts_______?
questions.solution:
The given x ray depicts Melorheostosis.

Melorheostosis: It is also known as Leri's Disease. It is a rare mesenchymal dysplasia manifesting as regions of sclerosis of cortices with a characteristic dripping wax appearance or flowing candle wax appearance. The presentation is usually monostotic and unilateral. Symptoms include pain, deformity, skin and circulation problems and contractures.

Osteopoikilosis is a benign autosomal dominant sclerosing bone dysplasia with multiple bone islands in a peri-articular distribution in tubular bones, pelvis and scapulae. They are typically bilateral and symmetrical.

Osteopathia striata, is a rare, benign dysplasia of bone with radiographically prominent vertical striations involving the epiphysis and metaphysis of tubular bones. It is typically asymptomatic, although there can be associated joint discomfort.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male had a subarachnoid hemorrhage. There were no focal neurological deficits. On assessment, the patient opened the eyes to verbal command, was confused while speaking and localized to painful stimuli. According to the world federation of neurosurgical societies grading (WFNS), what is the grade of subarachnoid hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
The above patient has SAH of WFNS grade IV.

The World Federation of Neurological Surgeons (WFNS) grading of subarachnoid hemorrhage considers two parameters:

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Presence or absence of focal neurological deficit(in the form of dysphasia/limb weakness).

WFNS grading is as follows:

Grade Glasgow Coma Scale Focal deficits
I 15 –
II 13–14 –
III 13–14 +
IV 7–12 ±
V 3–6 ±

The GCS of the above patient is Eye-opening (3) + Verbal response (4) + Motor response (5) = 12, Hence, irrespective of the presence or absence of focal deficit, the grade of SAH in this patient is IV.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text:
Which of the following can be used to determine a chromosome analysis of the fetus:
  1. Amniocentesis
  2. Chorionic villus sampling
  3. Percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS)
questions.solution:
Fetal tissue for chromosome analysis can be obtained through any of the following methods:

  • Amniocentesis: It involves obtaining a sample of amniotic fluid, which contains fetal fibroblasts.
  • Chorionic villus sampling (CVS): It involves taking a biopsy of the placenta
  • Percutaneous umbilical blood sampling: The umbilical vein is punctured under direct ultrasound guidance near the placental origin and blood is obtained for genetic analysis
  • Direct biopsy of fetal muscle or skin.

questions.text: A trainee nursing student while working in orthopaedics ward, puts the following things in yellow bag. Which of the following should not have been put in the yellow bag?
questions.solution:
Urine bag should not be put in the yellow bag. It should be put in the red bag since it is a recyclable contaminated waste.

Rest all can be put in the yellow bag.

questions.text: A young man came for an infertility workup. Semen analysis was done and the report was normal. Which of the following findings can be expected in his semen sample?

choices.text: Sperm concentration of 35 million per mL

questions.solution:
A sperm concentration of 35 million per mL can be expected in his semen sample.

Semen analysis is an important component in evaluating the cause of male infertility. According to WHO(2021), the lower limits of the values in a semen analysis are as follows:

  • Volume of semen- 1.4 mL
  • Sperm concentration- 16 million sperm per milliliter
  • Total sperm number per ejaculate- 39 million
  • Total motility- 42%
  • Progressive forward motility- 30%
  • Vitality- 54%
  • Normal morphology- 4%

Semen is collected in a sterile cup. The male is asked to refrain from ejaculating for 3-4 days prior and the sample is obtained. It has to be sent to the lab within an hour where it undergoes liquefaction. The process takes 15-20 minutes. If parameters are normal, a single sample is sufficient, if not, two samples at an interval of one month should be taken. 

Some of the disorders of sperm are:

  • Aspermia—means no semen.
  • Azoospermia—implies no sperm in semen.
  • Oligospermia—low sperm count. It is defined as a sperm count of less than 15 million sperm per milliliter
  • Asthenospermia— diminished sperm motility
  • Teratospermia—abnormal morphology of sperms.

questions.text:
Assertion: The administration of 2 injectable/nasal live vaccines, not simultaneously administered, should be separated by a minimum duration of 6 weeks.
Reason: The immune response to one live-virus vaccine might be impaired if administered within 28 days of another live-virus vaccine.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both the assertion and reason are true statements but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false statement
Assertion is false but the reason is true statement
Both assertion and reason are false statement

questions.solution:
The administration of 2 injectable/nasal live vaccines, not simultaneously administered, should be separated by a minimum duration of 4 weeks not 6 weeks because the immune response to one of the live-virus vaccines might be impaired if administered within 28 days of another live-virus vaccine.

Guidelines for the spacing of live and inactivated antigens for the general population:

Antigen combination Recommended minimum interval between doses
Two or more inactivated May be administered simultaneously or at any interval between doses
Inactivated and live May be administered simultaneously or at any interval between doses
Two or more live injectable 28 days minimum interval, if not administered simultaneously

Note:-  The live oral vaccines Ty21a typhoid vaccine and rotavirus vaccine may be administered simultaneously with or at any interval before or after inactivated or live injectable vaccines.

questions.text: Identify the type of MRI image given below.
questions.solution:
The MRI image given above is FLAIR.

  • In FLAIR images CSF and white matter is dark.
  • FLAIR (fluid attenuated inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fluid.

In T2 images CSF is bright/hyperintense and white matter is dark whereas in T1 images CSF is dark/hypointense and white matter is white.

STIR (Short tau inversion recovery) is done to detect bone marrow oedema.

Here White matter appears darker than gray while gray matter appears gray and the fluids appear very bright.

questions.text: Portable tonometer that functions using biprisms is:
questions.solution:
Perkins tonometer is a portable tonometer that functions using biprism to split the circle of contact into mires.

Though Goldmann’s tonometer also uses biprism, it is not portable.

Schiotz and Mackay Marg tonometers are portable but do not utilize biprisms. Schiotz tonometer displays a mechanical reading while Mackay Marg tonometer records the value electronically.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries supplies the Kisselbach’s plexus and is derived from the internal carotid artery?
questions.solution:
Anterior ethmoidal artery supplies the Kisselbach’s plexus and is derived from the internal carotid artery via its ophthalmic branch.

Arterial supply of the nasal septum:

Internal carotid system

  • Branches of the ophthalmic artery
    • Anterior ethmoidal artery
    • Posterior ethmoidal artery

External carotid system

  • Sphenopalatine artery (branch of the maxillary artery) gives nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches.
  • Septal branch of greater palatine artery (branch of the maxillary artery).
  • Septal branch of the superior labial artery (branch of the facial artery).

Kiesselbach’s plexus:

Four arteries anastomose at the anterior inferior part of the nasal septum (Little's area) to form a vascular plexus called Kiesselbach’s plexus.

  • Anterior ethmoidal
  • Septal branch of the superior labial
  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine
  • Septal branch of the greater palatine

Little's area is the most common site for epistaxis in children and young adults.

questions.text: The most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery is:
questions.solution:
After-cataract is the most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery.

After cataract, otherwise known as posterior capsular opacification/ secondary cataract, is the most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery. It occurs due to the proliferation of lens epithelial cells that have been left out inside the capsular bag after cataract surgery. 

Symptoms of after cataract include:

  • Reduction of visual acuity
  • Slowly worsening blurring
  • Glare and occasionally monocular diplopia

They can present in different patterns such as:

  • Elschnig's pearls - present as vacuolated (pearl-type) grape-like clusters of swollen cells 
  • Soemmering's ring - presents as a white annular proliferation that is formed at the periphery of the capsular bag.
  • Fibrosis type - present as fibroblastic metaplasia of the epithelial cells 

The illustration given below shows different types of after-cataract.

A posterior capsulotomy (creating a hole in the posterior capsule) using an Nd: YAG laser is the mainstay of treatment. It becomes indicated when the patient is symptomatic. 

Other options: 

Option A: Retinal detachment is an uncommon late complication of cataract surgery. It may occur in people with pre-operative risk factors such as retinal breaks, high myopia, or due to vitreous loss during surgery. Retinal detachment is treated by pars plana vitrectomy.

Option B: Postoperative endophthalmitis is a complication of cataract surgery causing acute and severe intraocular inflammation. Patients complain of pain and visual loss. Clinically, there is eyelid swelling with conjunctival injection, Marcus-Gunn pupil, hypopyon, and vitritis. Intravitreal antibiotics are the key to management. Other treatment modalities include oral antibiotics and steroids, and pars plana vitrectomy.

Option C: Irvine–Gass syndrome is postoperative cystoid macular edema. It is an uncommon late complication of cataract surgery. It is clinically insignificant; resolves on its own.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not involved in iron metabolism:
questions.solution:
• Hepcidin, ceruloplasmin, and transferrin are involved in iron metabolism.
  • Transthyretin transports thyroxine and retinol-binding protein and has no role in iron metabolism

Proteins involved in iron metabolism:

  • Ferritin and hemosiderin: Iron storage
  • Transferrin: Iron transport
  • Ceruloplasmin: a copper-containing enzyme with ferroxidase activity
  • Hepcidin: Chief regulator of systemic iron homeostasis

questions.text: The image below shows the relationship between the velocity of muscle contraction to the load attached to three muscles. Assuming that same loads are attached to all the muscles, differences in which of the following causes the differences in the graphs given below?
questions.solution:
The graph shown exhibits the change in the maximum velocity of contraction, which occurs due to the change in myosin ATPase activity, provided that the load is constant.

The velocity of muscle contraction is inversely proportional to the load attached to a muscle and directly proportional to the myosin ATPase activity.

The muscles are divided into two groups 'slow' and 'fast', depending on the myosin ATPase activity and contractile speed. Slow fibers have a low myosin ATPase activity, while fast muscles have high myosin ATPase activity.

Other options:

An increase in the frequency of muscle contraction, muscle mass and recruitment of the motor units allow the muscle to lift more load within its limits but does not affect the velocity of contraction.

questions.text: The motility as shown in the time lapse video given below is characteristically seen in:
questions.solution:
The above image shows coordinated swarming or social motility, which is characteristic of African trypanosomes eg.Trypanosoma brucei.

The early procyclic forms of these bacteria when grown on semi solid agar form multicellular communities that engage in polarized migrations across the surface of the agar medium and cooperate to divert their movements in response to external signals. These movements are facilitated by the flagella.

Related Pearl: Types of motility of microorganisms

Motility Microorganism
Darting/vibratory motility  Vibrio,Campylobacter
Swarming motility Cl. septicum, B.cereus, Proteus, some Vibrio sp
Tumbling motility  Listeria monocytogenes
Stately motility Clostridia
Spinning motility Fusobacterium gyrans
Cork-screw motility  Treponema pallidum
Falling leaf motility Giardia
Twitching motility Eikenella corrodens
Differential motility (Motility varies at different temperatures) Yersinia enterocolitica & Listeria monocytogenes
Jerky motility  Trichomonas vaginalis
Gliding motility Mycoplasma, Entamoeba
Lashing motility  Saprophytic spirochetes

Related Pearl: Various morphological stages of hemoflagellates

It is based on the arrangement of the flagella in relation to the position of the nucleus and its point of emergence from the cells.

Stage Morphological characteristics Seen in
Amastigote

Rounded or ovoid, without any external flagellum.

The nucleus, kinetoplast, and axial filaments can be seen.

The axoneme extends up to the anterior end of the cell

 Trypanosoma cruzi and Leishmania as the intracellular form in the vertebrate host.
Promastigote

Lanceolate in shape.

Antenuclear kinetoplast- kinetoplast is anterior to the nucleus near the anterior end of the cell, from which flagellum emerges.

There is no undulating membrane

 It is the infective stage of Leishmania, found in the insect vector as well as in cultures in­vitro.
Epimastigote

Elongated. 

Juxtanuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast placed more posteriorly, close to and in front of the nucleus.

The flagellum runs alongside the body as a short undulating membrane, before emerging from the anterior end.

It is the form in which Trypanosoma brucei occurs in the salivary gland of the vector tsetse fly and Trypanosoma cruzi in the midgut of the vector reduviid bug.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.
Trypo-mastigote

This stage is elongated, spindle-shaped with a central nucleus.

Postnuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast is posterior to the nucleus and situated at the posterior end of the body.

The flagellum runs alongside the entire length of the cell to form a long undulating membrane before emerging as a free flagellum from the anterior end.

This is the infective stage of trypanosomes found in arthropod vector and in the blood of an infected vertebrate.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl came to the hospital with a history of upper respiratory illness since two weeks. Initially, she had a low-grade fever, sinus congestion with clear discharge which improved over a week but recurred with increased severity. Now she has a severe sore throat, enlarged and tender cervical lymph nodes, and fever (38.2degrees celsius). There is no cough or shortness of breath. Examination of the oral cavity is shown in the image below.  Based on centor criteria, what is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Triple throat swab culture and sensitivity test

questions.solution:
Empirical Penicillin V therapy is provided.

The above image shows tonsillar exudates. Based on the clinical features the patient has a centor score of 4, suggesting a high probability of group A β- hemolytic streptococcal (GABHS) pharyngitis. The treatment includes empirical antibiotic therapy with:

  • Empirical antibiotic therapy with penicillin V potassium for 5-10 days or
  • Erythromycin (in case of allergy to penicillin) or
  • Cefuroxime axetil for 5-10 days.

 

Centor criteria:

  • Absence of cough
  • Pharyngotonsillar exudate
  • Tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Fever over 38°C

One point is allotted for each criterion, and the maximum score is 4.

For the above patient, the score is: 1+1+1+1 = 4

 

Based on the centor score, the management is as follows:

Centor criteria score Management
0 or 1 No testing or treatment
2 or 3 A single Throat swab culture and Rapid streptococcal antigen testing, and if they are positive provide antibiotic treatment
4 Empirical antibiotic therapy with penicillin V potassium for 5-10 days or Erythromycin (in case of allergy to penicillin) or Cefuroxime axetil for 5-10 days

 

 

 Primary Prevention of Rheumatic Fever (Treatment of Streptococcal Tonsillopharyngitis)

Penicillins

Penicillin V 

Amoxicillin

Benzathine penicillin G

For individuals allergic to penicillin

Narrow-spectrum cephalosporin

(cephalexin, cefadroxil)

Clindamycin

Azithromycin

Clarithromycin

Related Pearl: Acid resistant penicillins: mnemonic "VODKA"

The mnemonic "VODKA" can be used to for acid-resistant penicillins that are active orally.

  • V - Penicillin V
  • O - Oxacillin
  • D - Dicloxacillin
  • K - Cloxacillin
  • A - Amoxycillin/ Ampicillin

questions.text:
Match the following structures with their respective sites of opening:

Column A:

 

  1. Nasolacrimal duct guarded by the valve of Hasner.
  2. Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, and anterior ethmoidal sinus forming the Picadle’s circle
  3. Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  4. Auditory tube

 

Column B:

 

  1. Jacobson's organ
  2. Choana
  3. Nasopharynx
  4. Superior meatus
  5. Inferior meatus
  6. Middle meatus
questions.solution:
The correct match is 

  1. Nasolacrimal duct guarded by the valve of Hasner -  E. Inferior meatus
  2. Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form an osteomeatal complex or Picadle’s circle. - F. Middle meatus 
  3. Posterior ethmoidal sinus - D. Superior meatus
  4. Auditory tube - C. Nasopharynx

Jacobson’s organ/ vomeronasal organ (VNO) is the paired auxiliary olfactory organ located in the nasal septal soft tissue, just above the hard palate.

Posterior nasal aperture is otherwise known as choanae.

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text:
Which of the following types of mutations best describe the change occurring below?

Normal Transcript: AUG UUU UGG GAG Mutant Transcript: AUG UUC UGG GAG
  1. Point mutation
  2. Base substitution
  3. Transition
  4. Silent mutation
  5. Synonymous mutation
questions.solution:
All of the given types of mutation describe the change occurring in the given data.

Point mutation: A point mutation or substitution (base substitution) is a genetic mutation where a single nucleotide base is changed, inserted or deleted from a sequence of DNA or RNA.

Transition: A given pyrimidine is changed to the other pyrimidine or a given purine is changed to the other Purine. The variant on this is the Transversions which are changes from a purine to either of the two pyrimidines or the change of a pyrimidine into either of the two purines.

Silent mutations/Synonymous mutations: Such mutations where there may be no detectable effect because of the degeneracy of the code are often referred to as silent mutations.

Both UUU and UUC code for phenylalanine.

A missense mutation will cause a different amino acid to be incorporated at the corresponding site in the protein molecule.

A nonsense codon will then result in the premature termination of translation and the production of a fragmented protein.

questions.text:
Assertion: Myelination in PNS occurs by the rotation of the oligodendrocyte on the axon.
Reason: Each oligodendrocyte is attached to myelin sheaths of as many as 60 nerve fibers.

choices.text: Assertion and reason are true, and the reason is correct explanation of assertion
Assertion and reason are true, but the reason is incorrect explanation of assertion
Assertion is true and reason is false
Assertion is false and reason is true
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.solution:
The assertion is false, as the myelination in PNS occurs due to the rotation of Schwann cell (not oligodendrocyte) around the axon.

In CNS, each oligodendrocyte is connected to the myelin sheaths of as many as 60 nerve fibers.

Therefore, it is not possible for the oligodendrocyte to myelinate the axon by rotating around it as the Schwann cell does. Instead, myelination in CNS occurs by the growth of the processes from the oligodendrocytes.

Related Pearl: Glial cells and their functions

Cells

Functions

Microglia (immune system cells)

Scavenger cells that remove debris resulting from injury, infection, and disease.

Oligodendrocytes

Myelin formation in central nervous system

Schwann cells

Myelin formation in peripheral nervous system

Astrocytes :

  • Fibrous – in white matter
  • Protoplasmic – in grey matter

Astrocytes form the tight junctions making blood–brain barrier

Produce substances that are tropic to neuron

They help maintain the appropriate concentration of ions by taking up K+

They take up glutamate and convert into  glutamine

questions.text: In a case of acute exacerbation of asthma, salbutamol was given, however, no improvement was noticed. Intravenous corticosteroids and aminophylline were given and the condition improved. What is the probable mechanism by which the corticosteroids would have improved the condition?

choices.text: Corticosteroids increase bronchial responsiveness to salbutamol
Corticosteroids cause direct bronchodilatation when used with xanthines
Corticosteroids indirectly increase the effect of xanthines on adenosine receptor

questions.solution:
Corticosteroids improved the condition by increasing the airway responsiveness to salbutamol.

Mechanism of action of corticosteroids in an acute asthma attack:

  • Increases responsiveness to β-2 agonists
  • Decreases mucous secretion
  • Decreases inflammatory cell response.

Steroids increase the transcription of β-2 receptor genes and hence increases responsiveness to β-2 agonists.

β-2 agonists increase the effect of steroids by enhancing the action of glucocorticoid receptors.

Theophylline increases the effects of steroids by activating the enzyme histone deacetylase which is the target for steroids as well.

Note: As per recent GINA 2021 guidelines, aminophyllines are no longer preferred in the management of acute severe asthma due to their low efficacy and poor safety profile.

questions.text: The deficiency of the enzyme involved in step 3 of the process illustrated below results in _____.
questions.solution:
The enzyme involved in step 3 (glycogen branching) is the branching enzyme. The deficiency of this enzyme would result in Andersen’s disease.

Andersen's disease is a type IV glycogen storage disease characterized by hepatomegaly due to the accumulation of polysaccharides with few branch points. Death usually ensues around 5 years of age.

questions.text:
Assertion: Nabilone is approved for the treatment of anorexia associated with weight loss in patients with AIDS
Reason: Nabilone is a CB1 receptor antagonist

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both the assertion and reason are true statements but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false statement
Assertion is false but the reason is true statement
Both assertion and reason are false statement

questions.solution:
Dronabinol, not nabilone is used for the treatment of anorexia associated with weight loss in patients with AIDS because it can stimulate appetite.

Both nabilone and dronabinol are CB1 receptor agonists, not antagonists.

Nabilone is used as a prophylactic antiemetic agent in cancer chemotherapy when other antiemetic medications are not effective. Dronabinol can be used for this as well.

Related Pearl: Effect of diuretics on excretion of electrolytes

Osmotic diuretics ↑↑ ↑ ↑

Thiazides ↑ ↑↑ ↓
Epithelial sodium channel blockers ↑ ↓ ↓
Aldosterone antagonists ↑ ↓ Insufficient data

Acute effects of thiazides on Ca2+ excretion are variable but when administered chronically, it decreases Ca2+ excretion.

questions.text:
Match the following laboratory results of the gram positive cocci in column A with appropriate microorganism in column B:
Column A Column B
1. Catalase negative, α haemolytic, optochin resistant a) S. epidermidis
2. Catalase negative, β haemolytic, bacitracin resistant b) S. mutans
3. Catalase positive, coagulase negative, novobiocin sensitive c) S. pneumoniae
4. Catalase positive, coagulase negative, novobiocin resistant d) S. agalactiae

questions.solution:
The correct match is:

  3. Catalase positive, coagulase negative, novobiocin sensitive - a) S. epidermidis
  4. Catalase positive, coagulase negative, novobiocin resistant - e) S. saprophyticus

questions.text:
The correct order of cognitive developmental stages as described by Jean Piaget is:

A. Formal operations

B. Preoperational thought

C. Sensorimotor stage

D. Concrete operations
questions.solution:
The correct order is C-B-D-A

  1. Sensorimotor stage
  2. Stage of preoperational thought
  3. Stage of concrete operations
  4. Stage of formal operations

There are 4 stages in the Cognitive development stages, through which the thinking process of an individual develops. They are:

Sensorimotor stage (birth – 2 years):

  • Starts with "Out of sight, out of mind" type of thinking.
  • Ends with object permanence (knowing an object exists even though it cannot be seen)
  • Symbolisation- Developing mental symbols and words for the objects.

 Pre-operational stage (2-7 years):

  • Thinking without reasoning - intuitive thinking
  • Only concerned about their own needs and perspective - egocentric thinking
  • Other thinking processes are seen -  animism, primitive thinking, centration, magical thinking.

Concrete operational stage (7-11 years):

  • Start to see things from others perspective.
  • Thinking is concrete and literal.
  • Develop conservation - understanding that despite changes in shape, the object remains the same. For eg: when water is transferred from a cup to glass, they understand that it is water only and that the volume is the same.
  • Develop the concept of reversibility - knowing that one thing can turn into another and turn back. Eg: water and ice.
  • Other processes- classification, transitivity.

Formal operational stage (>11 years):

  • Develop abstract thinking, wherein they can generalize or conceptualize.
  • Can make a hypothesis and use deductive reasoning.

questions.text: A patient with salicylic acid poisoning has the following arterial blood gas analysis report: pH = 7.1, pCO2 =18mmHg, HCO3-=12mmol/L. Identify the acid-base disorder here.

choices.text: Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis
Metabolic acidosis with uncompensated respiratory alkalosis

questions.solution:
The acid-base disorder here is a mixed disorder of metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis. 

It should not be confused with metabolic acidosis with uncompensated respiratory alkalosis. This can be understood by the following calculation:

Step 1: The pH in this patient is 7.1 (pH <7.35) which indicates acidosis

Step 2: HCO3- is 12 mmol/L (Normal HCO3- - 22–30 mmol/L). In metabolic acidosis, HCO3- levels decrease.

Hence, this is a case of metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: As per Winter's formula, the expected respiratory compensation in metabolic acidosis can be calculated using,

      pCO2 =( 1.5 x [HCO3-] ) +8 ± 2

In this case, Expected pCO2 = ( 1.5 x [12] ) +8 ± 2

                                          = 26 ± 2

                                          = 24 - 28 mmHg

The pCO2 in this patient is 18 mmHg, which implies there is an overcompensation of pCO2. This overcompensation can happen only if there is an additional component of respiratory alkalosis contributing to reduced pCO2.

Hence, this patient has a mixed disorder - metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis. 

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: Which of the following can induce all the steps necessary for angiogenesis?
questions.solution: Basic Fibroblast Growth Factor - bFGF (FGF-2) can induce all steps of angiogenesis. Acidic FGF is FGF-1.

questions.text: A 45 year old male with recurrent bloody diarrhea came to the hospital. Colonoscopy showed geographical ulcers. Histopathology is given below. Your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is Crohn's disease.

In the given history, recurrent bloody diarrhea indicates periods of active disease interrupted by asymptomatic periods. The presence of geographical ulcers indicate the presence of multiple, clearly delineated areas of disease in-between areas of normal mucosa, or skip lesions.

The histopathological image shows transmural inflammation where inflammatory cells (neutrophils) extend from mucosa through submucosa, and to the muscularis thereby, infiltrating and damaging crypt epithelium. The normally straight and parallel crypts appear distorted.
All the above features indicate Crohn’s disease to be the diagnosis.

questions.text:
Mark the following statements true or false regarding surfactant replacement therapy.
  1. The surfactant should be warmed prior to administration
  2. The surfactant vial should be shaken well to ensure good mixing
  3. Chest X-ray is not mandatory for confirmation of ET tube position
  4. ET tube position change is mandatory between the administration of each aliquot
  5. Suctioning of ET tube should be done every half an hour for 2 hours post-administration of surfactant
questions.solution:
The surfactant should be warmed prior to administration - True

The surfactant should be warmed prior to administration (for 8 minutes between the palms or for 20 minutes at room temperature.) The vial should not be heated and it should not be kept on a radiant warmer. It should not be kept in room air for more than 30 min as it increases viscosity.

The surfactant vial should be shaken well to ensure good mixing - False

The surfactant vial may be rolled but it should not be shaken.

Chest X-ray is not mandatory for confirmation of ET tube position - True

The baby is intubated with an appropriate size endotracheal tube and breath sounds equality is assessed. A chest x-ray is not mandatory for confirmation of the ET tube position.

ET tube position change is mandatory between the administration of each aliquot - False

The surfactant is administered through a feeding tube inserted in the ET tube or through the side port of the ET tube. Surfactant is given as bolus instillation in four aliquots of the total dose. No position change is required between the aliquots.

Suctioning of ET tube should be done every half an hour for 2 hours post-administration of surfactant - false

Suctioning of ET tube should be avoided at least 2 hrs following surfactant administration

questions.text:
Match the following:

Column A

A
B
C
D

 

Column B

  1. Amphotericin B
  2. Ketoconazole
  3. Flucytosine
  4. Griseofulvin
  5. Terbinafine
  6. Echinocandins
questions.solution:
The correct match is 

A - 4. Griseofulvin

B - 5. Terbinafine

C 2. Ketoconazole

D. 1. Amphotericin B

 

Griseofulvin interferes with fungal mitosis.

Mechanism of action of griseofulvin:

  • Binds to polymerized tubulin and inhibits its function
  • Metaphase arrest is not observed: Abnormal metaphase configurations are formed
  • Daughter nuclei fail to move or move an only short distance
  • Multinucleated and stunted fungal hyphae are produced

Terbinafine acts as a non-competitive inhibitor of “squalene epoxidase”, an early step enzyme in the synthesis of fungal ergosterol.

Ketoconazole is an imidazole that acts by inhibiting the fungal cytochrome P450 enzyme lanosterol-14-demethylase and resulting in impairment of ergosterol synthesis.

Amphotericin B acts on the cell membrane of the fungi.

Amphotericin B is a polyene compound obtained from Streptomyces nodosus. Polyene compounds have a high affinity for the ergosterol, which is present in the fungal cell membrane. It binds to the ergosterol and gets inserted into the cell membrane, forming a micropore.

Recent evidence suggests that the amphotericin B forms aggregates that sequester ergosterol from lipid layers much like a sponge resulting in fungal cell death.

Amphotericin B is the least toxic among polyenes and used systemically for fungal infections. Nystatin and hamycin have high systemic toxicity and are used only for local and topical actions.

Flucytosine inhibits nucleic acid synthesis while, echinocandins inhibit the activity of the glucan synthase complex, resulting in loss of the structural integrity of the cell wall.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text:
Assertion and Reason:
Assertion:-
Ultrasonography is the primary imaging modality for the screening and diagnosis of IVH and parenchymal hemorrhage in neonates.
Reason:-
The posterior fontanelle offers a good acoustic window for imaging using USG.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both the assertion and reason are true statements but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false statement
Assertion is false but the reason is true statement
Both assertion and reason are false statement

questions.solution:
Ultrasonography is the primary imaging modality for the screening and diagnosis of IVH and parenchymal hemorrhage in neonates because of the ideal acoustic window offered by the anterior(not posterior) fontanelle, easy and quick image acquisition at the bedside, and a lack of radiation hazard.

All neonates at high risk for IVH, i.e gestational age <32 weeks or birth weight <1500 g should undergo screening. More mature preterm infants (32-34 wks) should also be screened if they experience a turbulent postnatal course in the form of shock requiring inotropes, unexplained anemia, or severe RDS requiring mechanical ventilation.

questions.text: A patient has serum bilirubin of 4.9 mg/dl and serum creatinine of 5.2 mg/dl. Which of the following muscle relaxants can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Atracurium can be safely used in this patient with elevated serum bilirubin and serum creatinine as it undergoes Hofmann elimination.

Atracurium and cis-atracurium undergo plasma ester hydrolysis and Hofmann elimination at physiological pH and temperature. Hofmann elimination is a spontaneous non-enzymatic organ-independent degradation. So, the clearance of atracurium and cis-atracurium is independent of liver or kidney function. Hence, they are the agents of choice in patients with liver disease and/or renal failure.

The metabolites of atracurium and cis-atracurium are monoquaternary acrylate and laudanosine.

Some of the adverse effects of atracurium are hypotension, tachycardia, and allergic reactions (bronchospasm) due to a dose-dependent histamine release. On the other hand, these adverse effects are not seen with cis-atracurium and so it is preferred over the former.

Pancuronium, rocuronium, and vecuronium are dependent on the liver for excretion.

Related Pearl: High yield in muscle relaxants

  • Shortest acting non-depolarizing muscle relaxant:
    • Gantacurium (Not FDA approved)
    • Mivacurium: 12-20 minutes. (FDA approved)
  • Shortest acting depolarizing muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine (3-6 minutes)
  • Muscle relaxant having the maximum duration of action: Doxacurium (benzylisoquinoline) > Pancuronium (Aminosteroid)
  • Muscle relaxant causing pain on IV injection site: Rocuronium
  • Muscle relaxant which crosses placenta: Gallamine
  • Muscle relaxant acting directly on muscle: Dantrolene
  • Muscle relaxants with central action: benzodiazepine, mephenesin, baclofen, carisoprodol, metaxalone
  • Muscle relaxant and mode of clearance:
    • Hepatic clearance: Pancuronium, rapacuronium and vecuronium
    • Biliary clearance: Vecuronium and rocuronium
    • Renal clearance: Doxacurium, pancuronium, vecuronium, and pipecuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with sympathetic stimulation:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with vagolytic activity:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
    • Rocuronium (mild)

questions.text: The labor room quality improvement initiative advocates which of the following labor room practices?

choices.text: Immediate clamping and cutting of the umbilical cord
Conventional lithotomy position for the delivery
Separating the baby from the mother for routine care & procedure
Presence of birth companion during the labor

questions.solution:
The labor room quality improvement initiative, LaQshya advocates the presence of a birth companion during labor.

Do’s and Don’ts of Labour Room:

DO’s

  • Providing privacy to pregnant women during the intrapartum period (separate labor room or private cubicle)
  • Presence of birth companion during the labor
  • Freedom to choose a comfortable position during birthing (squatting, standing, etc.) (Option B)
  • Adherence to clinical protocols for the management of labor
  • Use of labour beds instead of tables
  • Placing baby on mother’s abdomen
  • Initiation of breastfeeding within one hour of birth

DON'Ts

  • Induction and augmentation of labour without sound clinical indications
  • Any verbal or physical abuse of pregnant women
  • Insisting on conventional lithotomy position for the delivery
  • Immediate clamping and cutting of the umbilical cord (Option A)
  • Separating the baby from the mother for routine care & procedure (Option C)
  • Out of Pocket Expenditures (OOPE) on drugs, diagnostics, including demand by the staff for gratuitous payment by families for the celebration of the baby’s birth.

questions.text: The Langerhans cells present in the epidermis develop from:
questions.solution:
The Langerhans cells are macrophage immune cells derived from the bone marrow. These cells first appear in the epidermis by the seventh week and later continue to migrate to the epidermis throughout life. They play a role in immune surveillance against microorganisms and play a role in the pathogenesis of contact sensitivity (allergic skin reaction).

Development of the skin:

The epidermis is derived from the surface ectoderm. These ectodermal cells differentiate into keratinocytes and Merkel cells. The melanocytes present in the epidermis are derived from the neural crest cells while the Langerhans cells are derived from the bone marrow.

The dermis (exception, face) is derived from mesoderm. The ventral dermis develops from the somatic layer of the lateral plate mesoderm, whereas the dorsal dermis develops from the dermamyotome subdivision of the somites. The dermis of the face is derived from neural crest cells.

Related Pearl: Cells of the epidermis

Cells of the epidermis Origin and location Characteristic features
Keratino-cytes

Present in- All Layers of Epidermis (90-95% of all epidermal cells)

Derived from-Ectoderm

Differentiated in situ

 Rich in the intermediate filaments called keratin that provides mechanical strength to the cell. The keratinocytes in basal layer divide and generate the upper layers. 
Melano-cytes

Present in- Stratum basale

Derived from-Neural Crest

Migrate to the epidermis

 Synthesize melanin in granules called melanosomes that is transferred to keratinocytes of epidermis through elongated processes called dendrites. Each melanocyte transfers melanosomes to 36 keratinocytes. This is called as Epidermal melanin unit (36K:1M)   

Merkel   cells

Present in-Stratum basale (RETE RIDGES)

Derived from-Ectoderm/ Neural Crest

Differentiates in-situ

 Also known as Touch cells or Haascheiban cells. They are Type 1 slow adapting touch receptors.  
Langerhans cells

Present in-Stratum spinosum

Derived from- Bone Marrow

Migrate to Epidermis

 They are dendritic Antigen Presenting Cells (APCs).   Characterized by presence of rod shaped or Tennis Racket shaped granules called Birbeck granules which are seen on electron microscopy.   Immunohistochemical Markers are CD1a, CD207(Langerin) and S100.

questions.text:
The true statements regarding the complement system are:

A.    Involved in Innate immune response

B.    CD21 serves as a receptor for complement

C.    Not a part of the adaptive immune response

D.    C1INH deficiency causes hereditary angioneurotic edema

E.    The most common complement protein deficiency is that of C2
questions.solution:
CR2 (Complement Receptor 2) or CD21,  recognizes complement products generated during innate immune responses to microbes. It also serves as the receptor for the entry of EBV into B cells.

The complement system plays a role in both innate and adaptive immune responses of the body.

C1INH (C1 Inhibitor) is the other name for C1 esterase, whose deficiency causes Hereditary Angioneurotic Edema

 

Interestingly, though C2 deficiency is the most common in the west, and worldwide, with an incidence rate of 1 case per 10,000 population,  C9 deficiency is the most common complement deficiency in Japan, excluding MBL pathway defects. 

 

 

 

Related Pearl: Complement deficiency and associated diseases

 

Complement protein Effects of deficiency
C1, C2, C4 Immune- complex disease (SLE)
C3, Factor I Susceptibility to capsulated bacteria
C5-C9 Susceptibility to Neisseria
Factor D. properdin (factor P) Susceptibility to capsulated bacteria and Neisseria.

DAF (Decay accelerating factor)

CD 59

 Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
C1-inhibitor Hereditary angioneurotic edema

 

Related Pearl: Functions of Complement

  • Inflammation: C3a, C5a, and, to a lesser extent, C4a are called anaphylatoxins.
  • C5a is also a chemotactic agent.
  • Opsonization and phagocytosis: C3b and its cleavage product iC3b (inactive C3b) act as opsonins and promote phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages.
  • Cell lysis

This role of complement is important mainly for the killing of microbes with thin cell walls, such as Neisseria species, and deficiency of the terminal components of complement predisposes to Neisseria infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor in patients with penile cancer?
questions.solution:
Inguinal lymph node status is the most important prognostic indicator in penile carcinoma.

The prognosis for tumors confined to the penis is good with 5-year survival rates in excess of 80%. With nodal involvement, the 5-year survival rate falls to around 40%.

questions.text:
Theme and Focus: Seizures

Answer option list:

A. IV phenobarbitone

B. Rectal diazepam

C. Intraosseous midazolam

D. Phenytoin IV

E. Nasal carbamazepine

F. Oral valproate

Lead in Question: A one and a half-year-old baby comes to OPD with a generalized convulsive episode which lasts for 45 min. On duty Senior Resident asked junior resident to start an IV line and left
questions.solution:
The baby presented with convulsive episodes lasting for 45 mins (>5 mins), which is suggestive of status epilepticus, which is a medical emergency and needs to be managed immediately.

The initial treatment usually involves intravenous diazepam, lorazepam, or midazolam. If the status does not improve the treatment is followed by phenytoin/fosphenytoin and phenobarbital, then valproate and levetiracetam.

In Scenario 1: If the IV line is not accessible, buccal or intranasal midazolam, intranasal lorazepam, or rectal diazepam.

In scenario 2: An initial IV treatment with diazepam was provided, but the patient has not improved. So, the next step is to administer a loading dose of IV phenytoin.
